An '''ENGO''' ('''environmental non-governmental organization''') is a [[non-governmental organization]] (NGO) in the field of [[environmentalism]]. Examples of ENGOs include the [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]], [[Greenpeace]], [[Conservation International]], [[The Nature Conservancy]], [[Friends of the Earth]] and the [[Environmental Investigation Agency]]. ==Goals== The goals of environmental NGOs include but are not limited to: creating relationships with the government and other organizations, offering training and assistance in agricultural [[Soil conservation|conservation]] to maximize the use of local resources, establishing environmental solutions, and managing projects implemented to address issues affecting a particular area.{{cite journal | title=International NGOs and Land Use Change in Southern Highland Region of Ecuador | author=Keese, James R. | journal=[[Human Ecology (journal)|Human Ecology]] | year=1998 | volume=26 | pages=451–468 | doi=10.1023/A:1018708300053}} Environmental NGOs are organizations that are not run by federal or state governments but rather have funds issued to them by governments, private donors, [[corporations]], and other institutions.[[Pamela Chasek]], ed. 2000 ''The Global Environment in the Twenty-First Century: Prospects for International Cooperation''. [[United Nations University]] In order to fully understand the social, [[economic]], and environmental effects an organization can have on a region, it is important to note that the organization can act outside the formal processes that state governments and other government institutions must comply with. ==Funding== The funds issued by various parties inevitably influence the way their efforts will be put out, the different kinds of environmental policy-making, and the activities pursued to challenge and put pressure on the states to cooperate in environmental protection. It is clear that private and non-private [[funding]] influences and affects the way environmental [[NGOs]] view and report environmental conditions. ==Approaches== The concept of what is [[Local community|local]] is crucial to the kinds of efforts and [[Goal|objectives]] environmental NGOs will carry out.{{cite journal | title=Fisher, W. 1997 Doing Good? The Politics and Antipolitics of NGO Practices | author=Fisher, William F. | journal=[[Annual Review of Anthropology]] | year=1997 | volume=26 | pages=439–464 | doi=10.1146/annurev.anthro.26.1.439}} This aim will aid how environmental NGOs will “facilitate, fund, promote, and provide planning and organizational assistance to so called grass roots organizations". Their efforts come in many forms such as: launching campaigns against [[nuclear weapons]] testing, protesting whale hunting, and "international campaigns against the degradation of environmental goods caused by practices like "clearing of timber, and criticize states for their ineffective policies or transnational corporations for environmentally damaging production". With political backup, environmental NGOs receive considerable amounts of assets and [[resources]] through [[government]] sponsors such as the [[United Nations Environment Programme]] (UNEP) and the [[Commission on Sustainable Development]] (CSD) among many others, who supersede environmental policies. ===African biodiversity=== Environmental NGOs have become increasingly aware of the loss of [[biodiversity]] in [[Africa]] and operate on conserving wild and domesticated animals and plants. By the 1980s, most of [[Zimbabwe]]'s best land had been taken control of by European settlers which have been divided into categories of "(1) large-scale commercial farm land. (2) resettlement areas, (3) communal lands, (4) national parks and safari areas, (5) forest lands, and (6) urban land" which (with the exception of communal land) is owned and operated by the state.{{cite journal | url=http://danbrockingtoncv.files.wordpress.com/2011/01/annurev-anthro-35-2006.pdf | title=Parks and Peoples: The Social Impact of Protected Areas | author1=Paige West | author2=James Igoe | author3=Dan Brockington | journal=Annual Review of Anthropology | date=October 2006 | volume=35 | pages=251–77 | doi=10.1146/annurev.anthro.35.081705.123308 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Environmental problems are defined as:
"a change in the physical environment brought about by human interferences which are perceived by people to be unacceptable with respect to a particular set of commonly shared norms".Potter, David, ed. 1996 ''NGOs and Environmental Policies: Asia and Africa''. Oregon: [[Frank Cass]].
== See also == * [[List of environmental organizations]] * [[Conservation refugee]] == References == [[Category:Environmental organizations|environmental]] [[Category:Environmentalism]] [[Category:Non-governmental organizations]]

[[Denmark|Danish]] island in the [[Kattegat]], north of [[Odense]], off the coast of [[Funen]], and west of [[Samsø]]. The island covers an area of {{convert|13.2|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} and has 185 inhabitants.
== Nature and Protected areas == Endelave and its surrounding seaside is important for many birds, both on domestic and international levels and it is therefore a [[Ramsar Convention|Ramsar]] area. The Ramsar protection is part of the Ramsar protection in [[Horsens Fjord]] and has number 152. The total area of the entire protection encompass 42,737 ha.<ref>[http://www.ramsar.org/cda/en/ramsar-documents-list-anno-denmark/main/ramsar/1-31-218%5E16427_4000_0__ The Annotated Ramsar List: Denmark] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222170305/http://www.ramsar.org/cda/en/ramsar-documents-list-anno-denmark/main/ramsar/1-31-218%5E16427_4000_0__ |date=2014-02-22 }} Ramsar, 05.08.2013</ref> The reef 'Møllegrunden' Northwest of the island is an important resting and breeding site for many [[Pinniped|seal]]s in the [[Kattegat]] sea. The bay of Endelave is comprised by a large [[intertidal zone]] similar to the [[Wadden Sea|wadden sea]] area. About ⅓ of the island itself is protected under the [[Natura 2000]] plan, housing vulnerable and outstanding nature-types such as a heather [[moorland]] thicket, a beach-[[meadow]] and [[oak]] forests for example.
Endelave is home to a population of [[European rabbit|wild rabbit]]s of variable size. It is a locally distributed animal in Denmark, but where it is found the population is usually large. The rabbits on Endelave are hunted when in season and in the last few years, more than half of the total rabbit [[Bag (fishing & hunting)|bag]] in Denmark (a stable level of 5000 animal pro anno), was from Endelave. <ref>[http://www2.dmu.dk/Pub/FR742.pdf Stock of Game and Hunting-seasons in Denmark: The Biological Foundation for the Hunting-season-revision 2010]; DMU (2009), p.77-78 {{da icon}}</ref>

'''Gans theory''' or Mie-Gans theory is the extension of [[Mie theory]] for the case of spheroidal particles. It gives the scattering characteristics of both [[Oblate spheroid|oblate]] and [[prolate]] spheroidal particles much smaller than the excitation wavelength. Since it is a solution of the [[Maxwell equations]] it should technically not be called a theory.
The theory is named after [[Richard Gans]] who first published the solution for gold particles in 1912 in an article entitled "Über die Form ultramikroskopischer Goldteilchen".<ref>Gans, R. Ann. Phys. 1912, 342, 881</ref> A subsequent article in 1915 discussed the case of silver particles.<ref>Gans, R. Ann. Phys. 1915, 352, 270</ref>
In Gans theory, the [[absorption (electromagnetic radiation)|absorption]] is only dependent on the aspect ratio of the particles and not on the absolute dimensions. This dependence is introduced through so called polarization- or shape factors related to the three dimensions of the particle. For the case of spheroids, this reduces to only two different factors since the particle is [[rotational symmetry|rotational symmetric]] around one axis.
It is currently being applied in the field of [[nanotechnology]] to characterize silver and gold [[nanorod]]s.<ref>Eustis, S., El-Sayed, M.A. J. Appl. Phys., 2006, 100, 044324 {{Cite journal | last1 = Eustis | first1 = S. | last2 = El-Sayed | first2 = M. A. | doi = 10.1063/1.2244520 | title = Determination of the aspect ratio statistical distribution of gold nanorods in solution from a theoretical fit of the observed inhomogeneously broadened longitudinal plasmon resonance absorption spectrum | journal = Journal of Applied Physics | volume = 100 | issue = 4 | pages = 044324 | year = 2006 | pmid = | pmc = |bibcode = 2006JAP...100d4324E }}</ref> A popular alternative for this is the [[Discrete dipole approximation]] (DDA) method. Gans theory gives the exact solution for spheroidal particles; real nanorods, however, have a more cylindrical shape. Using DDA, it is possible to better model the exact shape of the particles. As the name suggests, this will only give an approximation.

{{See also|Winter of 2009–10 in Great Britain and Ireland|Winter storms of 2009–10 in East Asia|Winter of 2009–10 in Europe}} {{Use American English|date=May 2012}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} {{multiple issues| {{cleanup|reason=the article needs better sections|date=May 2012}} {{Globalize/Northern|article|date=October 2010}} }} {{Weather}} {{Infobox winter storm |name = Winter storms of 2009–2010 |image location = Great Britain Snowy.jpg |image name = A [[satellite]] photo showing most of the UK. It shows the extent of snow cover across the entire island. From Plymouth in the south to Aberdeen in the north, the UK was hit with the heaviest snowfall in 32 years. |alt = |stormtype = |date formed = August 21, 2009 |date dissipated = August 31, 2010 |maximum amount = {{convert|53.0|in|cm|abbr=on}} (The town of [[Potter Hollow, New York]]) |pressure = {{convert|945|mbar|inHg}} over the North Atlantic<ref name="extremely intense bomb cyclone over the North Atlantic">http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Analyse_20100206.gif</ref> |lowest temperature = {{convert|-45.6|C|F|abbr=on}} ([[Folldal]], Norway) |sustained wind = |gust = |total damages (USD) = Unknown |total fatalities = More than 400, mostly in the [[People's Republic of China]], [[Afghanistan]], India, Poland, and [[Mongolia]] (and many more indirectly). |areas affected = [[Northern Hemisphere]] }}
The '''global storm activity of 2010''' includes major [[meteorological]] events in the [[Earth's atmosphere]] during the year, including [[winter storm]]s ([[blizzard]]s, [[ice storm]]s, [[European windstorm]]s), [[hail]]storms, out of season [[monsoon]] rain storms, [[extratropical cyclone]]s, [[gale]]s, [[microburst]]s, [[flooding]], [[rainstorm]]s, [[tropical cyclone]]s, and other [[severe weather]] events.
The thunderstorm season for the Northern Hemisphere began near spring, beginning on March 1, and ending on August 31.
==January== {{See also|Winter of 2009–2010 in the United Kingdom|Winter storms of 2009–2010 in East Asia|Winter of 2009–2010 in Europe}}
===January 1–3=== {{main|2010 Rio de Janeiro floods and mudslides}}
Fresh overnight snowfall on New Year's Eve and New Year's Day caused disruption in north east England, with roads across [[Northumberland]], [[Tyne and Wear]], [[County Durham]] and [[Teesside]] affected. Snow also fell in parts of East [[Cumbria]]. In places it was as deep as {{convert|10|cm}} and motorists were warned not to travel unless their journey was absolutely necessary.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/8436969.stm |title=Heavy snow prompts travel warning in North East |publisher=BBC News |date=January 1, 2010 |accessdate=January 1, 2010}}</ref>
A major snow-related weather warning was put out in [[Alaska]] on December 30.<ref name="arh.noaa.gov">{{cite web |url=http://www.arh.noaa.gov/ |title=National Weather Service, Alaska Region Headquarters, AK |publisher=Arh.noaa.gov |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> The expected [[snowstorm]] was probably part of the same [[weather system]] that hit the [[Russian Far East]] from December 30 to January 5.
Between January 1 and 2, 2010, 50- and 70-year record low temperatures and snowfall hit northern China and [[Korea]] starting January 1.<ref name="China1"/> Blizzards also hit [[Mongolia]]'s [[Dundgobi]] province.
A heavy [[storm surge]] hit northeastern [[New Brunswick]] on January 2, leading to over $750,000 in damage in the community of [[Port Elgin, New Brunswick|Port Elgin]].<ref name="cbcmaritimes"/><ref>{{cite news |title=N.B. village seeks $750K in flood aid |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/new-brunswick/story/2010/01/08/nb-port-elgin-flood-assistance-551.html |accessdate=December 22, 2010 |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=January 8, 2010}}</ref>
Heavy record-breaking snow also fell in Moscow in early January 2010.<ref name="CCTV1"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.cctv.com/program/worldwidewatch/20100109/101338.shtml |title=Europe: Severe winter weather continues making life difficult for people |last=Special report |first=CCTV |author2=Du Xiaodan |author3=Yu Ze |date=January 9, 2010 |work=CCTV 9 |publisher=China Central Television |accessdate=January 11, 2010}}</ref> and light snow briefly fell in Greece and Turkey.
On January 2, a weather front with a northerly wind brought heavy snow to the northwest of England. [[Wythenshawe]] near [[Manchester Airport]] had {{convert|5|in}} of snow. This affected road transport on January 2, particularly in the [[Greater Manchester]] area<ref name=BBC02Jan10a >{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/8437584.stm |title=Six vehicles crash in snow on the M6 near Manchester |publisher=BBC News |date=January 2, 2010 |accessdate=January 2, 2010}}</ref> with conditions on the [[M60 motorway|M60]], [[M602 motorway|M602]] and [[M66 motorway|M66]] reported to be poor, while [[Snake Pass]], which links [[Manchester]] with [[Sheffield]] was closed.<ref name=BBC02Jan10a />
As a snowstorm entered Scotland, a number of roads across the country were closed including three junctions of the [[M9 motorway (Scotland)|M9]]<ref name=stv02Jan10 /> while the motorway was shut in both directions at the [[Newbridge, Edinburgh|Newbridge Roundabout]] in [[Edinburgh]] during the evening because of heavy snow, and did not open again until the following day. Problems were also reported on the A96 and the A939.<ref name=stv02Jan10 /> Rail services between [[Inverness]] and Central Scotland were also affected by poor weather.<ref name=stv02Jan10>{{cite news |url=http://news.stv.tv/scotland/147689-widespread-problems-on-scotlands-roads-as-cold-spell-continues/ |title=Widespread problems on Scotland's roads as cold spell continues |publisher=stv |first=Graham |last=Fraser |date=January 2, 2010 |accessdate=January 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100117195607/http://news.stv.tv/scotland/147689-widespread-problems-on-scotlands-roads-as-cold-spell-continues/ |archivedate=January 17, 2010 |df=}}</ref>
Possibly more than 200 people died in northern India, mostly in [[Uttar Pradesh]] after a cold snap and accidents in heavy [[fog]] around January 2 and 3.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/Asia/Story/STIStory_473475.html |title=33 dead in Indian cold snap |last=Breaking News |first=AFP |date=January 4, 2010 |work=Agence France-Presse |publisher=The Straits Times |accessdate=January 9, 2010}}</ref>
Heavy rain fell in parts of southwestern [[Brazil]]. The worst affected municipality has been [[Angra dos Reis]], about {{convert|150|km|mi}} southwest of the city of [[Rio de Janeiro]]. At least 35 people were killed at a resort on [[Ilha Grande]]:<ref name="Reuters">{{Cite journal |title=Brazil death toll from floods, mudslides rises to 64 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6000RD20100102 |publisher=Reuters |date=January 2, 2010}}</ref> about 40 people were staying in the hotel which was buried under a mudslide, and the death toll is expected to rise further.<ref name="France24">{{Cite journal |title=Scores are killed in flooding and mudslides |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20100102-scores-are-killed-flooding-mudslides-brazil |publisher=France24 |date=January 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100103080005/http://www.france24.com/en/20100102-scores-are-killed-flooding-mudslides-brazil |archivedate=January 3, 2010 |df=}}</ref> In [[Rio Grande do Sul]], at least seven people are dead and 20 missing after a bridge collapsed due to heavy rains.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/world/2010-01/06/content_9269924.htm |title=At least 7 killed in Bridge collapse in Brazil |last=Xinhua |first=China Daily |date=January 6, 2010 |publisher=China Daily |accessdate=January 10, 2010}}</ref> It is reported to be one of the worst mudslides in Reo De Janero's history.
===January 4–5===
On January 4, heavy rain fell in [[Brazil]].<ref name="CCTV1"/>
Heavy snow fell in northern China and grounded hundreds of flights on the 4th. It and forced [[Hong Kong]]'s [[Financial Secretary]] [[John Tsang]] and [[Monetary Authority Chief Executive Officer]] [[Norman Chan]] to cancel a trip to [[Beijing]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-01-03/heavy-snow-hits-chinese-capital-115-flights-canceled-update1-.html |title=Snowstorms Force Hong Kong's Tsang, Chan to Cancel Beijing Trip |publisher=BusinessWeek |date=January 4, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Beijing was hit by a blizzard starting the evening of the 2nd, with 70–80% of flights cancelled out of [[Beijing Capital International Airport]] on January 4.<ref name="China1"/> Close to 20 cm of snow fell in the north of the city, and close to 25 cm in Seoul.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/Asia/Story/STIStory_473375.html |title=Icy cold snap hits Beijing |last=Breaking News |first=Reuters |date=January 4, 2010 |agency=Reuters |publisher=The Straits Times |accessdate=January 10, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/Asia/Story/STIStory_473504.html |title=Big chill grips Asia |last=Breaking News |first=Reuters |date=January 4, 2010 |agency=Reuters |publisher=The Straits Times |accessdate=January 9, 2010}}</ref> Schools across the area were closed, and [[Wen Jiabao|Premier Wen]] asked local governments to ensure safe transportation, continued food supplies, and continued agricultural production.<ref name="China1">{{cite news |title=Snowstorms Force Hong Kong's Tsang, Chan to Cancel Beijing Trip |author=Tian Ying |newspaper=BusinessWeek |date=January 4, 2010 |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-01-03/heavy-snow-hits-chinese-capital-115-flights-canceled-update1-.html |accessdate=January 6, 2009}}</ref> Continued snowstorms were forecast for the city of Beijing and the province of [[Inner Mongolia]]. It was also predicted on January 7 for snow to reach the provinces of [[Jiangsu]], [[Anhui]], [[Henan]] and [[Hubei]] on January 9 according to [[China National Radio]].<ref name="Martin">{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601082&sid=avRatOmGvB1o |title=Icy Weather Boosts Power Demand, Slows Coal Shipments |last=Martin |first=Christopher |author2=Whitney McFerron |date=January 7, 2009 |publisher=Bloomberg.com |accessdate=January 10, 2010}}</ref> One person was killed in [[Xinjiang Autonomous Region]] as a result of the storm.<ref name="News">{{cite news |url=http://www.weather.com.cn/static/html/article/20100110/177506.shtml|script-title=zh:新疆发生雪灾5000余人转移 1人死亡 |date=January 10, 2010 |work=weather.com.cn |publisher=The Public Weather Service Center of CMA |language=Chinese |accessdate=January 10, 2010}}</ref> Emergency services handed out extra cattle [[fodder]] in Tibet.
Japan's [[Hokkaido]] island was hit by heavier snowfall, causing heavy travel disruption and some airport closures.
By January 4 about 30 people, including 28 children and an elderly man, died from cold-related causes in the last 11 days across [[Bangladesh]] as snow and a [[cold wave]] swept over the north and centre of the nation. Freezing fog also occurred on the 4th in [[Punjab (India)|Punjab]], India.<ref name="xinhuanet2">{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/05/content_12756225_1.htm |title=Strong cold wave strikes India_English_Xinhua |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=January 5, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106231714/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/05/content_12756225_1.htm |archive-date=November 6, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Some parts of Bangladesh were the hardest hit with temperatures plummeting as low as 6 °C according to meteorologist Sanaul Haque, who predicted the cold wave may continue for another day.<ref name="CCTV1"/><ref name="Xinhua">{{cite news |url=http://english.cctv.com/20100104/103329.shtml |title=Cold snap claims 30 lives in N Bangladesh |last=Xinhua |first=CCTV |author2=Zhang Pengfei |date=January 4, 2010 |work=Xinhua |publisher=China Central Television |accessdate=January 11, 2010}}</ref>
The [[New Brunswick]] villages of [[Upper Cape]] and [[Port Elgin, New Brunswick|Port Elgin]] were devastated<ref name="cbcmaritimes">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/01/04/storm-maritimes.html |title=CBC News - Canada - Maritimes recover after 'weather bomb' |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=January 4, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> as a massive [[hurricane]]-strength [[blizzard]] hit [[Nova Scotia]], New Brunswick and [[Prince Edward Island]] on January 4, causing massive [[Power outage|blackout]]s in its wake.<ref name="cbcmaritimes"/>
Light snow briefly fell in [[Lebanon]], [[Jordan]], [[Israel]] and [[State of Palestine|Palestine]] and further snow was reported in [[Niigata Prefecture|Niigata]], Japan.
By January 4 about 30 people, including 28 children and an elderly man, died from [[cold-related causes]] in the last 11 days across [[Bangladesh]] as snow and a [[cold wave]] swept over the north and centre of the nation. Freezing fog also occurred on the 4th in [[Punjab (India)|Punjab]], India.<ref name="xinhuanet2"/> Some parts of Bangladesh were the hardest hit with temperatures plummeting as low as 6 °C according to meteorologist Sanaul Haque, who predicted the cold wave may continue for another day.<ref name="Xinhua"/><ref name=disrupts>{{cite news |url=http://english.cctv.com/20100105/101447.shtml |title=Unusual weather disrupts normal life worldwide |date=January 5, 2010 |work=Xinhua |publisher=China Central Television}}</ref>
Heavy rain and severe cold hit southern [[Bangladesh]] and [[Italy]].<ref name="CCTV1"/><ref name=disrupts/>
On the 4th, the UN issued a [[Green Alert]] in [[Albania]] as northern rivers swell with melt water<ref>[http://www.gdacs.org/reports.asp?eventType=FL&ID=2010_2&system=asgard&alertlevel=Green&glide_no=&location=&country=Albania GDACS impact assessment: Green Flood alert in Albania] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100116104357/http://www.gdacs.org/reports.asp?eventType=FL&ID=2010_2&system=asgard&alertlevel=Green&glide_no=&location=&country=Albania |date=January 16, 2010 }}. Gdacs.org. Retrieved August 16, 2010.</ref>
In its monthly summary, [[Met Éireann]], [[Ireland]]'s weather service, said December was the coldest month for 28 years for most of the country and the coldest of any month since February 1986 at a few stations.<ref name="irishtimes.com">{{cite news |title=December was coldest month in 28 years |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0104/breaking26.html?via=rel |publisher=Irish Times |date=January 4, 2010 |accessdate=January 4, 2010}}</ref>
In Scotland, [[Fife]] Council became the first local authority to confirm that its supply of grit was exhausted on January 4, after it received less than it had ordered from suppliers. Government Ministers denied there was a shortage of grit and salt and insisted there were "very substantial" supplies for [[Scotland]]'s roads.<ref name="Ministers deny salt supply crisis">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/8438717.stm |title=Ministers deny salt supply crisis |publisher=BBC News |date=January 4, 2010 |accessdate=January 5, 2010}}</ref><ref name="Ministers deny salt supply crisis"/>
Italy suffered from both heavy rain in the south and heavy snow in the north.<ref name="CCTV1"/>
January 4 saw four villages in Sakhalin lose power as a result of a storm. The 2,000 strong town of [[Tomari, Russia|Tomari]] was worst hit. Blizzard struck [[Sakhalin]] island, a narrow island in the stormy [[Sea of Okhotsk]], off the coast of [[Siberia]] and just 25 miles north of Japan's snowy Hokkaido island.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/04/world/europe/04sakhalin.html |work=The New York Times |title=Harsh Storm Batters Island Off the Coast of Russia |first=Ellen |last=Barry |date=January 4, 2010 |accessdate=April 6, 2010}}</ref>
On the 4th, many motorways in [[Shandong]] were closed and 19 flights cancelled in the [[Yantai International Airport]]. Eventually the No. 1820 train, carrying more than 800 passengers, started off at after being stranded for 12 hours.
January 4 saw [[Seoul]]'s heaviest snowfall since 1937 according to the [[Korea Meteorological Administration]] (KMA). The blizzard dumped {{convert|25.8|cm|in}} of snow on the town.<ref name="xinhuanet1">{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/04/content_12752746.htm |title=Snowstorm blasts South Korea_English_Xinhua |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=January 4, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100124110214/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/04/content_12752746.htm |archive-date=January 24, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Avalanches and heavy snow hit the Russian's [[Sakhalin Island]], which was smothered by a snow cyclone and blizzard, the Island's emergency officials said.
Civil authorities were put on a major alert in the snow-torn province of [[Shandong]]<ref>{{cite web |last=Sina |first=Xinhua English |url=http://english.sina.com/china/p/2010/0104/297504.html |title=Snowstorm raids Shandong Province - China News |publisher=SINA English |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> on January 4 as more snow fell in both Shandong and [[Beijing]]. Travel was affected as the snowstorm paralyzed Beijing on January 4, 2010.
January 5 in northeastern China saw a smooth flow of traffic, with no [[gridlock]] or serious traffic accidents being reported<ref name="en.ce.cn">{{cite web |url=http://en.ce.cn/National/Local/201001/05/t20100105_20745268.shtml |title=Traffic smooth after snow storm in Beijing _Localâ€"China Economic Net |publisher=En.ce.cn |date=January 5, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> after the snowstorm that caused traffic chaos on the 4th, according to the [[Beijing Traffic Management Bureau]].<ref name="en.ce.cn"/> The city's bus and [[subway train]] services were up and running according as plan.<ref name="en.ce.cn"/> During the peak hours on Monday morning, the [[Beijing Subway Operating Company]] dispatched 20 additional trains to ease the heavy passenger flow.<ref name="en.ce.cn"/> The bus of all routes started off on time that morning, according to the [[Beijing Public Transport Holdings]].<ref name="en.ce.cn"/> [[Inner Mongolia]] was still in a critical situation as teams batteled to clear severe rural snow drifts.
4–8 inches (10–20 centimeters) of snow fell in Beijing on the 5th, in the largest snowfall since 1951.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.mongabay.com/2010/0105-hance_extreme.html |title=Chinese official links extreme snowstorm to global warming |publisher=News.mongabay.com |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
The 2,000 weather modification offices in China, which are responsible for bombing the skies with [[silver iodide]] to induce rain or snow, were put into use.<ref name="smh.com.au">{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/china-blames-freak-storm-on-global-warming-20100104-lq6t.html |title=China blames freak storm on global warming |publisher=Smh.com.au |date=January 5, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Schools in [[Beijing]] and [[Tianjin]] closed and because the cities' traffic was in chaos. The capital received the harshest Siberian winds in decades.<ref name="smh.com.au"/> Temperatures for the 5th were forecast to plunge to −16 °C, a 40-year record low, after a daytime maximum of −8 °C.<ref name="smh.com.au"/> The head of the Beijing Meteorological Bureau, [[Guo Hu]], linked the blizzard-like conditions of the first week of January to unusual atmospheric patterns caused by [[global warming]].<ref name="smh.com.au"/>
Heavy snow started to fall in [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.cctv.com/20100105/101447.shtml |title=Unusual weather disrupts normal life worldwide CCTV-International |publisher=English.cctv.com |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> and it was reported that a leading [[North Korea]]n [[Workers' Party of Korea|Communist party]] official had frozen to death, in his home, situated in the country's [[Sepo County|Sepo]] [[Administrative divisions of North Korea|kun]] (or county).
During the traffic peak hours of Monday morning, the Beijing Subway Operating Company dispatched 20 additional subway trains to ease the heavy passenger flow. City workers were deployed to clean the snow in the city's main roads with about 15,710 tonnes of snow-dissolving agent, Beijing Environmental Sanitation Group Co., Ltd. official [[Zhang Zhiqiang]] said.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90776/90882/6859327.html |title=Traffic smooth after snow storm in Beijing - People's Daily Online |publisher=English.peopledaily.com.cn |date=January 5, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> On the 4th, many motorways in Shandong were closed and 19 flights were cancelled at [[Yantai International Airport]].
In [[Inner Mongolia]], 13 trains were delayed that Monday in [[Hohhot]], the regional capital, according to the Hohhot railway authorities.
[[File:Aa snow 2010 01 05 00.jpg|right|thumb|[[Manchester]], England, on 5 January.]] The [[Met Office]] issued weather warnings for every region in the UK except the [[Northern Isles]]. An extreme weather warning was issued for southern areas for overnight snowfall which could bring accumulations from {{convert|25|to|40|cm|in}}.<ref name=Times05Jan10 >{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article6976571.ece |title=Met Office warns of 40 cm of snow within hours in South East |publisher=Times Online |date=January 5, 2010 |accessdate=January 5, 2010 |location=London |first1=Nico |last1=Hines |first2=Simon |last2=de Bruxelles |first3=Charlene |last3=Sweeney}}</ref> BBC Weather and the Met Office also warned that temperatures in the Highlands of Scotland could drop to {{convert|-20|C|F}} later in the week. The Met Office also confirmed that the UK is experiencing the longest prolonged cold spell since December 1981.<ref name=Bloomberg06Jan10update2 /> The Harrogate district endured over six inches and had been a regular feature on [[BBC News]] broadcasts.
A local record of {{convert|48|cm}} of snow was lying in [[Aviemore]] and {{convert|3|to|4|ft}} of snow was recorded within the [[Cairngorms National Park]]. Most parts of Scotland had further snowfalls during the night of January 4/5.
Due to shortage of road grit conventionally made from [[rock salt]], road grit was being made by or for road-gritters from cooking-type salt mixed with builders' sand;<ref name="BBC TV news">[[BBC TV]] news</ref> and the public bought up large amounts of [[cooking salt]] and [[table salt]] from food shops to put on their paths and drives. The Government was reported to have reallocated reserve supplies of road salt and grit from Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire and sent it to [[Cumbria]] and Fife due to the higher priority of even lower salt and grit reserves, along with the greater snow clearance work, according to [[Radio Oxford]].<ref name="BBC TV news">[[BBC TV]] news</ref>
A heat wave and/or unforeseen [[monsoon]] weather also hit parts of Australia in early 2010. Victoria, the scene of horrific bushfires the year before, had a far colder summer, with hot weather arriving more than a month later than usual in 2009.<ref name="CCTV1">{{cite news |url=http://english.cctv.com/20100105/101447.shtml |title=Unusual weather disrupts normal life worldwide |last=Xinhuanet |first=CCTV |author2=Du Xiaodan |date=January 5, 2010 |work=Xinhua |publisher=China Central Television |accessdate=January 11, 2010}}</ref><ref name="CCTV1"/> August 17 saw a dust storm at [[Laguna Mar Chiquita]] as a major drought hit [[Argentina]],<ref>[http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/NaturalHazards/view.php?id=39827 Dust Storm in Argentina : Natural Hazards]. Earthobservatory.nasa.gov. Retrieved August 16, 2010.</ref> and [[2010 Victorian storms|flooding and hailstorms]] hit southeastern Australia and [[March 2010 Queensland floods|Queensland]] in March 2010. The lack of winter precipitation in parts of China, however, contributed to a [[2010 China drought and dust storms|severe drought]] in the southwest. [[Bolivia]], [[Venezuela]], [[Mali]], [[Mauritania]], [[Morocco]] and Spain have also seen periods of drought in 2009 and 2010. On between May 12 and 26, both [[Mauritania]], the [[Sénégal River drainage basin|Sénégal River Area]] and neighbouring parts of both [[Senegal]] and [[Mali]] faced both a drought and famine in 2010.<ref>[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/fromthefield/222031/127409150030.htm AlertNet]</ref><ref>[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/fromthefield/222031/127549655260.htm AlertNet]</ref>
===January 6–9=== Snow and fog occurred in Germany from January 3 to January 10.<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/10/content_12784362.htm Freezing weather grips parts of Europe, no signs of easing] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100326200600/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/10/content_12784362.htm |date=March 26, 2010 }} January 10, 2010</ref> The Finnish railways and [[Helsinki]] airport are disrupted by further snowfall and record low temperatures for the Helsinki region.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/08/content_12774402.htm |title=Blizzard sweeps Southern Finland_English_Xinhua |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=January 8, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110222202325/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/08/content_12774402.htm |archive-date=February 22, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On January 6, the [[London Borough of Harrow]] closed 58 schools and 73 flights were cancelled at Heathrow as 3 cm of snow fell at [[Heathrow Airport]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/8442884.stm |title=Further snow forecast for London |publisher=BBC News |date=January 6, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
Continued snowstorms were forecast for the city of [[Beijing]] and the province of [[Inner Mongolia]]. Electricity rationing started on January 7.<ref name="Bloomberg">{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601082&sid=avRatOmGvB1o |title=Icy Weather Boosts Power Demand, Slows Coal Shipments (Update2) |publisher=Bloomberg.com |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Snow had started falling in [[Gangsu]] province by January 7. It also was projected on January 7 to have reached the provinces of [[Jiangsu]], [[Anhui]], [[Henan]] and [[Hubei]] on January 9 according to [[China National Radio]].<ref name="Bloomberg"/>
The Chinese government said that China faced its worst ice risk in 30 years. By the night of January 8–9, the major snowstorms predicted on January 7 for the provinces of [[Jiangsu]] and [[Anhui]], had arrived and the emergency services were put on alert.
Continued snowstorms were forecast for the city of [[Beijing]] and the province of [[Inner Mongolia]]. Snow reached the provinces of [[Jiangsu]], [[Anhui]], [[Henan]] and [[Hubei]] on January 9.<ref name="Martin"/> One person was killed in [[Xinjiang Autonomous Region]] as a result of the storm.<ref name="News"/>
[[File:Hamburg Germany Jan 6.jpg|thumb|[[Port of Hamburg]], Germany, on January 6]] The [[synoptic scale meteorology|synoptic]] situation in northern Europe settled to a steady northeast wind which brought snow showers and belts of snow.
The [[British Armed Forces|British Army]] had to help stranded motorists in southern areas.<ref name=Bloomberg06Jan10update2>{{cite news |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-01-06/army-rescues-u-k-drivers-as-snow-snarls-transport-update2-.html |title=Army Rescues U.K. Drivers as Snow Snarls Transport (Update2) |publisher=Bloomberg News |date=January 6, 2010 |accessdate=January 6, 2010 |first=Alex |last=Morales |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100110005019/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-01-06/army-rescues-u-k-drivers-as-snow-snarls-transport-update2-.html |archivedate=January 10, 2010}}</ref> The Met Office confirmed that {{convert|40|cm}} of snow fell in some parts of southern England.<ref name=BBC06Jan10a>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8444399.stm |title=Severe weather continues to grip the UK and cause havoc |publisher=BBC News |date=January 6, 2010 |accessdate=January 6, 2010}}</ref>
A "severe" warning issued by the [[Met Office]] was in place for every region in the UK.{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} Scottish [[First Minister of Scotland|First Minister]] [[Alex Salmond]] said [[Scotland]] was experiencing its worst winter since [[Winter of 1962–1963 in the United Kingdom|1963]].<ref name=BBC06Jan10a />
Further deaths in Wales, Shetland and Aberdeenshire were recorded. Roads in the southeast were left with long [[traffic jam]]s and abandoned cars. 8,000 schools were closed.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8442739.stm |title=Schools closed and travellers hit as snow continues |publisher=BBC News |date=January 6, 2010 |accessdate=January 7, 2010}}</ref>
In Eastern Parts, there were accumulations of 40 cm to 50 cm in places. In Kent, six inches of snow fell in four hours in the early evening.
By January 7, 2010, 22 people had died in the UK because of the freezing conditions.<ref name="Deaths during Britain's big freeze">[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/weather/article6979895.ece Deaths during Britain's big freeze]</ref>
Heavy snow blocked many roads in the [[Irish Republic]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://buzz.yahoo.com/article/1:irishcentralc825:f4afc239da3c5eccb1b7470c87d3a46a/Ireland-at-a-standstill-as-snow-storm-pummels-country--Irish-News--Weather |title=Ireland at a standstill as snow storm pummels country (IrishCentral) - IrishCentral.com - Yahoo! Buzz |publisher=Buzz.yahoo.com |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Dublin Airport]] closed on Wednesday January 6<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.eircom.net/breakingnews/17075655/?view=Standard |title=Dublin Airport closed until at least 8pm |publisher=Eircom.net |date=January 6, 2010 |accessdate=January 7, 2010}}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> and again on Friday January 9. [[Cork Airport]] closed on Sunday January 10, at 6:30 pm and did not re-open until 12:30 pm on Monday January 11.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0111/breaking10.htm |title=Munster feels brunt of Cold weather as Cork Airport opens after 18hours of closure |publisher=The Irish Times |date=January 11, 2010 |accessdate=January 11, 2010}}</ref> [[Dublin Bus]] canceled all services for a time.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.eircom.net/breakingnews/17075398/ |title=All Dublin Bus services halted |publisher=Eircom.net |date=January 6, 2010 |accessdate=January 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100109031220/http://news.eircom.net/breakingnews/17075398/ |archivedate=January 9, 2010 |df=}}</ref> [[Ireland West Airport Knock]] was also closed.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/knock-airport-closed-441052.html |title=Knock airport closed |publisher=Breaking News Ireland |date=January 7, 2010 |accessdate=January 7, 2010}}</ref> A new Irish record low temperature of {{convert|-9|C}} was also recorded in [[Dublin]], Ireland. Temperatures in County [[Limerick]] dropped to {{convert|-11.1|C}}. Varying amounts of snow fell across Ireland on the 7th and 8th and [[road salt]] reserves began to run low.
The snow fell heavily in some places of Spain including [[Prades, Tarragona|Prades]] ([[Tarragona]], southern [[Catalonia]]) which received 120 cm of snow after a storm lasting over 30 hours. The [[BBC News]] reported heavy snowfall as far south as [[Granada]], in Spain.
{{main|Severe weather of the Indian subcontinent during 2010}} 25 Nepalese people, mostly children, died as a blizzard swept over most of [[Nepal]] on January 7.<ref name="news.xinhuanet.com">{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/07/content_12767369.htm |title=Cold wave kills 25 in Nepal_English_Xinhua |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=January 7, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100124021618/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/07/content_12767369.htm |archive-date=January 24, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="news.xinhuanet.com"/><ref name="无标题文档">{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/08/content_12774807.htm |title=无标题文档 |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=December 31, 2009 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100114051142/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/08/content_12774807.htm |archive-date=January 14, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Snowstorms probably also occurred in mountainous [[Bhutan]] and [[Sikkim]], but no reports were forthcoming.
Heavy snow also fell in [[Chicago]] on the 7th <ref name="huffingtonpost.com">[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/01/07/chicago-snow-2010-stunnin_n_415315.html Huffington Post]</ref>
In Norway, temperatures hit −42 °C on the 7th in the central village of [[Folldal]]a as snow fell across [[Scandinavia]]<ref name="mb.com.ph"/> and {{convert|-42.4|C}} at [[Tynset]].<ref>[http://www.yr.no/place/Norway/Hedmark/Tynset/Tynset~186990/statistics.html Tynset, [[Norway]] weather statistics]</ref> on the 8th as [[Kuusamo]] in Finland, the lowest registered temperature was {{convert|-37.1|C}}.<ref name="HS_2010-01-08">{{cite web |url=http://www.hs.fi/kotimaa/artikkeli/1135251983884 |title=Kuusamossa talven uusi pakkasennätys |author=[[Suomen Tietotoimisto|STT]] |date=January 8, 2010 |accessdate=January 8, 2010 |publisher=[[Helsingin Sanomat]] |language=Finnish}}</cite></ref> Heavy blizzards and snow storms raged across Germany, [[Scandinavia]] and the northwestern parts of [[European Russia]].
In Poland, more snow hit the [[Lower Silesian Voivodeship]], and nine people died across the country in a 48-hour period, bringing the total weather-related deaths to 139 since the start of November, a police spokesman said.<ref name="mb.com.ph"/> Most of the victims were [[vagrants]], whose tragic lifestyle left them prone to the cold.<ref name="mb.com.ph"/>
Switzerland's {{convert|24.5|km|mi|adj=on}} [[Gotthard Road Tunnel]] reopened to trucks on the 8th, following heavy snowfalls over the previous 2 days.<ref name="mb.com.ph"/>
A heavy and snowy [[cyclone]] hit the [[Aleutian Islands]] on January 7 and 8. Snow accompanied a cold wave moving south through North America on January 8, and [[Mexico City]] received snowfall accumulations. In the mountainous regions, temperatures dropped to −10 °C, killing nine people.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/302898,nine-dead-in-mexico-from-frigid-weather.html |title=Nine dead in Mexico from frigid weather |last=DPA |first=Nature Environment News |date=January 10, 2010 |publisher=EarthTimes |accessdate=January 11, 2010}}</ref> The snow continued to fall on the 10th.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/11/content_12792508.htm |title=Mexicans have fun with snow_English_Xinhua |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=January 11, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115170824/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/11/content_12792508.htm |archive-date=January 15, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Bitter weather may have wiped out some [[Alaska]]n [[reindeer]]<ref name="capitalcityweekly.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.capitalcityweekly.com/stories/011310/out_548661429.shtml |title=Southeast Alaska's Online Newspaper |publisher=CapitalCityWeekly.com |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> as temperatures and snow depths exceeded those of the extraordinarily harsh winter of 1963 to 1964.<ref name="capitalcityweekly.com"/>
January 7 saw the snow and ice continuing to affect the snow-tormented counties of [[Oxfordshire]], [[Warwickshire]], [[Buckinghamshire]], [[Gloucestershire]] and [[Northamptonshire]].<ref name="banburyguardian.co.uk">{{cite web |url=http://www.banburyguardian.co.uk/news/Snow-update.5963846.jp |title=Snow update - Banbury Today - Back to Home Page |publisher=Banburyguardian.co.uk |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Because of the dangerous conditions concerning the build-up of snow and [[black ice]], [[Banbury Museum]], the Cherwell District Council customer service centre and Cherwell District Council tourist information centre were closed.<ref name="banburyguardian.co.uk"/> Many Oxfordshire locations had between 1 and 2 ft of unmelted snow by then.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/oxford/hi/people_and_places/nature/newsid_8443000/8443957.stm |title=BBC - In Pictures: Oxfordshire snow 07 Jan 2010 |publisher=BBC News |date=January 6, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> [[Cherwell District]] Council workers began using a mixture of [[table salt]] and [[sand]] instead of their diminishing [[road grit]] and [[rock salt]] supplies.
Record overnight temperature lows of {{convert|-22.3|C}} were recorded in [[Altnaharra]], [[Caithness]]shire, in the [[Scottish Highlands]] on the 7th.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/topics/weather/6949626/Big-freeze-ice-warning-as-temperatures-hit-winter-low-of--22.3hC.html |title=Big freeze: ice warning as temperatures hit winter low of −22.3hC |last=Adams |first=Stephen |date=January 8, 2010 |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |accessdate=January 9, 2010 |location=London}}</ref> as another area of low pressure over the [[North Sea]] started bringing further fronts of snow over the east of Great Britain on January 7, accompanied with cold, easterly winds. The snow continued in to the 9th and the UK almost ran out of [[road salt]], rock salt,<ref name="saltinstitute.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.saltinstitute.org/ |title=Salt & Sodium Chloride for safe winter roads |publisher=Saltinstitute.org |date=February 22, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> table salt and road grit supplies due to the heavy demand from various agencies and local government bodies.<ref name="independent.co.uk">{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/road-users-grit-their-teeth-as-salt-supplies-dwindle-1861397.html |title=Road users grit their teeth as salt supplies dwindle - Home News, UK |publisher=The Independent |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |location=London |first1=Nigel |last1=Morris |first2=Sarah |last2=Cassidy |date=January 8, 2010}}</ref>
By January 7, 2010 twenty-two people had officially died in the UK because of the freezing conditions.<ref name="Deaths during Britain's big freeze"/> The [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Department of Health]] wildly overestimated that the cold weather could cause up to 40,000 excess deaths in the UK if it continued much longer.<ref name="NZ_Herald_10619380">{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10619380&pnum=2 |title=UK winter set to be the coldest in 40 years |author=Emily Dugan, Andrew Johnson and Susie Mesure |date=January 10, 2010 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=October 1, 2011}}</ref> 122 people had already died in Poland, most of them reportedly homeless<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8445613.stm |title=Airport chaos as icy weather grips northern Europe |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=January 9, 2010 |date=January 7, 2010}}</ref> and 11 had died in [[Romania]]. Deaths in [[Bosnia]] and Austria luckily stood at only 4, with Kosovo only losing 1 life so far.
The heavy snowfall across the British Isles between January 6 to 9, resulted in large-scale traffic disruption, closed airports, many canceled trains and hundreds of school closures.<ref name="Britain January 4">{{cite news |title=Britain paralysed by snow and freezing weather |author=Murray Wardrop |newspaper=Telegraph |date=January 5, 2010 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/topics/weather/6935965/Britain-paralysed-by-snow-and-freezing-weather.html |accessdate=January 6, 2009 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/07/content_12769372.htm |title=Heavy snow causes transport havoc in England _English_Xinhua |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=January 7, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100326200553/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/07/content_12769372.htm |archive-date=March 26, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> A [[polar low]] developing in the [[English Channel]] brought fronts of snow over southern England before moving south and dissipating. Two middle-aged men died after falling into a frozen lake in [[Leicester]], in the English Midlands.<ref name="mb.com.ph"/> 27 major companies in Britain were ordered to halt using gas on the 9th in order to maintain supplies amid unprecedented levels of demand and major companies had their gas turned off on the 8th, in the first such move since 2003, although there was no immediate danger for households of supplies running out.<ref name="mb.com.ph"/> [[The Automobile Association]], a motor vehicle breakdown service, said they had dealt with about 340,000 breakdowns since December 17,<ref name="mb.com.ph"/> including a [[local government]] [[snow plough]] that had overturned after it had hit black ice near [[Huddersfield]].<ref name="mb.com.ph"/> A representative from [[Oxfordshire]] also confessed to the [[local media]] that they had a snowplough breakdown earlier in the day.<ref name="mb.com.ph"/> Several thousand schools remained closed and several of the weekend's [[Premier League]] football matches were cancelled.<ref name="mb.com.ph"/>
[[File:River Severn Ice.jpg|thumb|right|175px|Ice on [[River Severn]] at [[Shrewsbury]], England on January 8.]]
[[File:St marks church worsley winter 2010.jpg|left|thumb|175px|[[Worsley]], [[Greater Manchester]], England, on the 8th of January.]]
Overnight temperatures of {{convert|-22.3|C}} were recorded in [[Altnaharra]] in the [[Scottish Highlands]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/topics/weather/6949626/Big-freeze-ice-warning-as-temperatures-hit-winter-low-of--22.3hC.html |title=Big freeze: ice warning as temperatures hit winter low of −22.3 °C |location=London |last=Adams |first=Stephen |date=January 8, 2010 |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |accessdate=January 9, 2010}}</ref> Heavy snow fell in the North of England throughout the day giving significant accumulations. A high of −7.7 °C was recorded at Tulloch Bridge.
Heavy snow fell in Denmark on the 8th. By the evening of January 8, the [[Rügen]] Islands off the northeast coast of Germany was covered, on average, in 30 centimetres of snow while the capital Berlin was carpeted with snow and ice.<ref name="mb.com.ph"/><ref name="BBC News">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8448095.stm |title=Germany prepares to face blizzard |publisher=BBC News |date=January 8, 2010 |accessdate=January 9, 2010}}</ref> Autoclub Europa warned that chaotic traffic conditions could potentially leave large parts of Germany completely paralysed as the country prepared for further freezing conditions as forecasters warned that temperatures would drop below −20 degrees Celsius (−4 degrees Fahrenheit) overnight.<ref name="mb.com.ph"/> German officials had also acknowledged a shortage of grit and fear that high winds and drifting snow had closed may German [[Autobahn|autoroutes]] and roads, along with parts of [[Frankfurt airport]].<ref name="BBC News"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0,1518,670947,00.html |title=400 Fahrer verbringen eisige Nacht an der Grenze |publisher=spiegel.de |date=January 9, 2010 |language=German |accessdate=January 9, 2010}}</ref> As shortages in road salt and grit were already being feared, while the authorities recommended that people consider stocking up with a few days' worth of food and water. The A5 autoroute leading from [[Baden-Württemberg]] into France was closed on Friday afternoon, leading to a queue of hundreds of lorries building up.<ref name="thelocal.de">{{cite web |url=http://www.thelocal.de/society/20100109-24467.html |title=Winter storm freezes nation's transport - The Local |publisher=Thelocal.de |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> The road was opened again on Saturday morning, enabling careful drivers to proceed with their journeys. Snow was also proving to be a major problem in [[Saxony]] and the [[Rhineland]].<ref name="thelocal.de"/> The country's nature protection group [[NABU|N.A.B.U.]] has recommended that people put out food for birds since the cold and snowy weather had ruined their usual feeding patterns.<ref name="thelocal.de"/>
[[File:Denmark on 8 January 2010.jpg|thumb|right|175px|A snow-covered Denmark on January 8.]]
Meanwhile, some light snow also fell in Kosovo, [[Udmurtia]] and [[Ryazan Oblast]], but heavier snow fell in many parts of Ukraine. Temperatures fell as low as −30 °C and −29 °C in parts of Ukraine and similar temperatures occurred in neighbouring parts of Russia. Heavy show would hit Moscow on the 9th.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.rian.ru/video/20091209/157170066.html |title=Snow storm and crawling traffic don't bring down Moscow's spirit | Top Russian news and analysis online | 'RIA Novosti' newswire |publisher=En.rian.ru |date=February 19, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
A [[husky]] [[dog race]] took place in [[Thetford]] on the 8th.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8449162.stm |title=Suffolk huskies enjoying the snow at Thetford Forest |publisher=BBC News |date=January 8, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
On Saturday, the 9th of January, [[Banbury]] officer PC Paul Froggatt urged people not to try walking on the frozen [[Oxford Canal]] by the Castle Quay Shopping Centre in Banbury or in [[Oxford]] city.<ref name="oxfordmail.co.uk">{{cite web |url=http://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/archive/2010/01/09/News+%28Cakenews%29/4842952.Snow__Police_warn_people_to_keep_off_canal/ |title=Snow: Police warn people to keep off canal (From Oxford Mail) |publisher=Oxfordmail.co.uk |date=January 9, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite web |url=http://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/news/4842971.SNOW__Police_warning_about_canal/ |title=SNOW: Police warning about canal (From Oxford Mail) |publisher=Oxfordmail.co.uk |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> [[Thames Valley Police]] had also logged cases of people falling through the ice in [[Milton Keynes]], [[Bracknell]] and [[Aylesbury]].<ref name="oxfordmail.co.uk"/><ref name="ReferenceC"/> One man even tried to drive his car down a part of the frozen canal in [[Oxford]] and nearly died after it fell through the ice, while another man died on [[Teesside]] as he tried to rescue some puppies that were stranded on melting ice on the [[River Tees]]. Oxford City Council also warned of the dangers of playing on the frozen [[canal]] and/or frozen lakes.
A new wave of heavy snow was first reported in central and northern of France on the 9th, with both the [[Cotentin Peninsula]] and Paris being the worst-affected parts of France.<ref name="mb.com.ph">{{cite web |url=http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/237646/germany-braces-blizzard-freezing-europe-shivers |title=Germany braces for blizzard as freezing Europe shivers | Manila Bulletin |publisher=Mb.com.ph |date=January 9, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120606234839/http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/237646/germany-braces-blizzard-freezing-europe-shivers |archivedate=June 6, 2012 |df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/07/content_12772399.htm |title=Paris braces for heavy snow _English_Xinhua |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=January 7, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100121122524/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/07/content_12772399.htm |archive-date=January 21, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The French government said all non-essential travel should be avoided in these localities.<ref name="mb.com.ph"/> Significant snowfalls caused major delays to train services, blocked roads and some 15,000 people in areas around city of [[Arles]] experienced power cuts power lines collapsed under the weight 30 centimetres of snow.<ref name="mb.com.ph"/> Airlines cancelled a quarter of flights on Paris's main [[Charles de Gaulle airport]].<ref name="mb.com.ph"/> Road salt and grit supplies were running low in some districts due to their unexpectedly heavy use.
===January 10–11=== {{main|2010 Albania floods}} [[Image:albaniatrucks.jpg|thumb|right|175px|alt=Albanian army rescuers and villagers pass by a convoy of trucks pushed to the side of the road by flood water on the outskirts of Bacalledk, near the city of Shkodra, Sunday, January 10, 2010.|Albanian army rescuers and villagers pass by a convoy of trucks pushed to the side of the road by flood water on the outskirts of Bacalledk, near the city of Shkodra, Sunday, January 10, 2010.<ref>[http://english.cctv.com/program/worldwidewatch/20100111/101124.shtml Torrential rains bring heavy floods in Albania CCTV-International]. English.cctv.com (January 11, 2010). Retrieved December 3, 2010.</ref>]]
Heavy rain and melt water caused the worst floods in [[Albania]] in nearly 50 years, as 2, 500 homes being evacuated. An artificial lake in the [[Kosinj valley]] overflowed after it rose by 8 centimetres in 1 hour. The worst hit areas in Albania were the [[Shkodra]] district and to a lesser degree [[Tirana]].<ref name="euronews.net">{{cite web |url=http://www.euronews.net/2010/01/10/albania-hit-by-worst-floods-in-almost-half-a-century/ |title=Albania hit by worst floods in almost half a century | euronews, world news |publisher=Euronews.net |accessdate=January 5, 2014}}</ref>
On January 10, Croatia declared a national [[flood emergency]] as the [[Neretva river valley]] is flooded. The town of [[Metkovic]] was also flooded as the river reached a near-record high level.<ref>[http://english.ruvr.ru/2010/01/10/3480320.html Croatia declares flood emergency : Voice of Russia]. : (January 10, 2010). Retrieved August 16, 2010.</ref> Northern [[Croatia]] also got flooded in related storm system. Heavy hailstorms also hit the [[Dubrovnik]] that day.<ref name="euronews.net"/>
Snow hit the [[Czech Republic]] on January 10.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/10/content_12784362_4.htm |title=Freezing weather grips parts of Europe, no signs of easing _English_Xinhua |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=January 10, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110224190149/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/10/content_12784362_4.htm |archive-date=February 24, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
During the early hours of January 10, light snow showers spread across parts of [[Central England]] and [[Wales]]. The maximum temperature was {{convert|-13.5|°C|1}} in [[Altnaharra]] and low of {{convert|-18.4|°C|1}} was recorded at [[Kinbrace]]. On the 11th rain, sleet and snow travelled northwards throughout the early hours. [[Allenheads]] in England had fears over a potential {{convert|15|ft|m|abbr=on}} [[snowdrift]]. A low of {{convert|-21.0|°C|1}} was recorded in Altnaharra in [[Highland Region]].
More than 300 flights were cancelled in the 10th and 11th at Germany's [[Frankfurt Airport]]. All three runways were cleared and being used by the 12th despite of light snow falls that day.
[[File:Alton 10 Jan.JPG|thumb|175px|right|[[Icicles]] in [[Alton, Hampshire|Alton]], England, on January 10.]]
The snowstorms and blizzards of the 11th brought widespread travel chaos to Germany, Austria, Switzerland and Hungary.<ref name="english.cctv.com">{{cite web |url=http://english.cctv.com/program/worldwidewatch/20100111/101122.shtml |title=Intense snowstorms beleaguer Europe CCTV-International |publisher=English.cctv.com |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> [[Airport]]s, [[Motorway]]s and [[railway]]s were closed en masse due to heavy snow and ice.<ref name="english.cctv.com"/> [[Lithuania]], [[Latvia]], [[Estonia]], Finland, [[Liechtenstein]], the [[Czech Republic]] and [[Slovakia]] also reported some snowfall.
The ''[[Banbury Guardian]]'' and ''[[Oxford Mail]]'' released videos and photos of Oxford and Banbury on the 11th as part of a [[name and shame]] campaign against the idiotic people walking on the frozen canal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.banburyguardian.co.uk/news/Police-release-canal-skaters-video.5972782.jp |title=Police release canal skaters video - Banbury Today - Back to Home Page |publisher=Banburyguardian.co.uk |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.banburyguardian.co.uk/news/39Don39t-walk-on-frozen-canal39.5971199.jp |title='Don't walk on frozen canal' - Banbury Today - Back to Home Page |publisher=Banburyguardian.co.uk |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
January 10 saw heavy snow fall in Chicago.<ref name="huffingtonpost.com"/>
On January 10, Los Angeles Mayor [[Antonio Villaraigosa]] cancelled a trip to Washington to monitor L.A.'s response to the [[Southern California]] rainstorms.<ref name="latimesblogs.latimes.com">{{cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/01/los-angeles-mayor-antonio-villaraigosa-today-canceled-a-trip-to-washington-to-monitor-the-citys-response-to-the-southern-c.html |title=Rainstorms prompt Villaraigosa to cancel Washington trip | L.A. NOW | Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimesblogs.latimes.com |date=January 19, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Villaraigosa had been scheduled to address the U.S. Conference of Mayors' winter meeting at the nation's capital on Wednesday and was going speak about the success of the city's summer jobs program for [[at-risk youth]].<ref name="latimesblogs.latimes.com"/>
[[Freezing rain]] storms battered parts of [[Sichuan]], [[Yunnan]] and [[Hubei]], killing dozens of people.
On January 10, 1 person died and 5,435 were evacuated after a snowstorm in [[Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region]] according to the [[Ministry of Civil Affairs of the People's Republic of China|Ministry of Civil Affairs]]. A total of 261,800 people in 12 counties or cities were affected by the blizzards.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2010-01/10/content_9293681.htm |title=1 dead, over 5,000 evacuated after snowstorm in Xinjiang |publisher=Chinadaily.com.cn |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
On January 11, intense snowstorms hit a still beleaguered Europe. Many cars and a lorry were stuck in drifting snow near the northern German town of [[Soehlen]]. The German transport ministry warned people to travel on essential journey only.<ref name="english.cctv.com"/> Polish authorities reported that there were about 140 [[hypothermia]] deaths in Poland, that nearly 50,000 Polish residents without electricity, that the [[PKP Intercity|PKP trains]] were delayed by as much as 9 hours and that most of Poland's homeless shelters were overflowing. Some shops were running out of [[drinking chocolate]].<ref>[http://www.masterpage.com.pl/outlook/201001/poland-freezing-to-death.html Poland freezing to death]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> A similar situation was also occurring in the shops and homeless shelters of the Czech Republic. Snow also fell in [[Belarus]].
Coal supplies ran low at power plants as the death toll rose to two in the strong snowstorm in the [[Altay Prefecture|Altai]] and temperatures fell to −40 °C on January 12.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/bizchina/2010-01/12/content_9304533.htm |title=Coal supplies run low at power plants |publisher=Chinadaily.com.cn |date=January 12, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
===January 12–14=== On January 12, heavy snow caused hundreds of accidents, halted flights, and downed power lines in Poland; more than 160 people were trapped overnight on a frozen stretch of German roadway. Hundreds of road accidents were also reported in Germany over the weekend, especially along the [[Baltic Sea|Baltic]] Coast, where two men were killed in a car they were driving when it hit a tree in [[Nordvorpommern]] after skidding in the treacherous conditions. Austria, Switzerland and [[Liechtenstein]] were also badly hit by snowy and freezing conditions.
[[File:Staffordsnowbackyard.JPG|thumb|175px|right|Snow in [[Stafford]], England, on January 12]]
Both the [[National Beef Association]] and National Farmers' Union Scotland asked for the [[Scottish Government]] to help rebuild steadings, which in some cases are not covered by insurance. Heavy snowfall continued for a second day in [[Aberdeenshire]], [[Aberdeen]] and [[Rutland]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Barford |first=Vanessa |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8451952.stm |title=How are farmers coping with the snow? |publisher=BBC News |date=January 12, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
A further 5 to 10 cm of snow fell across the UK during the midday of January 12, including [[Stafford]] in [[Staffordshire]]. Many schools were once again closed across England and Wales. There were many road accidents and closures; the [[M25 motorway]] was down to one lane between [[Leatherhead]] and [[Reigate]] whilst roads stretching right across southern Great Britain were untreated causing havoc for commuters. [[Gatwick]] and [[Birmingham]] airports were closed and many flights were delayed at [[Heathrow]].
During January 13, the weather system continued north affecting much of [[Northern England]] before reaching [[Scotland]].<ref>{{cite news |title=More roads misery on "coldest day" |url=http://uk.news.yahoo.com/21/20100113/tuk-more-roads-misery-on-coldest-day-6323e80.html |date=January 13, 2010 |newspaper=[[Press Association]] |accessdate=January 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115115647/http://uk.news.yahoo.com/21/20100113/tuk-more-roads-misery-on-coldest-day-6323e80.html |archivedate=January 15, 2010}}</ref>
Eight of [[Oxfordshire]]'s 33,000-[[volt]] [[electrical substation|electricity substations]], which were situated in [[Kennington, Oxfordshire|Kennington]], [[Kidlington]], [[Wheatley, Oxfordshire|Wheatley]], [[Wantage]], [[Deddington]], [[Eynsham]], [[Berinsfield]] and [[Cholsey]], near [[Wallingford, Oxfordshire|Wallingford]] failed apparently due to an [[electrical overload]], causing several local [[power cut|blackouts]]; later saboteurs were officially blamed in the damage, and not an overload or mechanical failure as initially thought, according to ''[[Oxford Mail]]''.<ref name="oxfordmail1">{{cite web |url=http://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/news/4881651.Electricity_station_break_ins_cause_outages/ |title=Electricity station break-ins cause outages (From ''Oxford Mail'') |publisher=Oxfordmail.co.uk |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> The only way into the [[Wye Valley]] on the 13th, was by [[snow plough]], [[tractor]] or [[quad bike]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8457957.stm |title=BBC reporter's quad bike tour of cut-off Wye Valley |publisher=BBC News |date=January 13, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Teachers and parents helped dig out [[Princes Risborough School]] as about 6 inches of snow falls across [[Buckinghamshire]] and Oxfordshire, according to ''[[The Oxford Times|Bicester Advertiser]]'' and ''[[Bucks Herald]]'' newspaper. Peter Cornal of [[Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents]] and Principal Jonathan Johnson of [[Aylesbury Vale Academy]] both warned people not to skate on [[Watermead Lake]] in Buckinghamshire.
[[File:Bretchill pot hole 2011.jpg|thumb|right|175px|A picture of a [[Banbury]] road's pot-holes during 2010. The ''[[Banbury Cake (newspaper)|Banbury Cake]]'' and the ''[[Banbury Review Newspaper|Banbury Review]]'' newspapers did an exposé on the weather-induced potholes during the second week of January 2010. They were filled in by May 2010, due to media pressure. The filled in one is from 2011.]]
On January 14, southerly to south-easterly winds brought bands of snow to northern parts of Britain. An inch of snow fell in [[Glasgow]] with further accumulations in areas outside the other towns and cities. Travel was disrupted somewhat.
About 440 Welsh schools were either fully or partially closed on Thursday the 14th.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/8458059.stm |title=Ice causing disruption on Welsh roads |publisher=BBC News |date=January 14, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
The English snowfall began to ease on the 14th and the British government ordered an inquiry into the road salt and grit shortage scandal crisis, travel disruption and the poor handling of the disaster by various British companies and agencies.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601080&sid=a.rcXt3Jenhs |title=Snowstorm Response Investigated After U.K. Cold Wave (Update1) |publisher=Bloomberg.com |date=January 14, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
As the thaw took hold in the UK and France, rain began to fall across the UK. An 11-year-old girl named Naeemah Achha slid up on a patch of ice outside [[St. Michael]] from [[St. John Primary School]] in [[Blackburn]], [[Lancashire]] on the 14th and died later in [[Royal Manchester Children's Hospital]] the next day.<ref name="autogenerated1">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8457458.stm BBC]</ref><ref name="news.bbc.co.uk">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/lancashire/8462009.stm |title=Girl dies 'after falling on ice' near Blackburn school |publisher=BBC News |date=January 15, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> [[Head teacher]] Kay Cant described her as an intelligent, vivacious, kind and popular girl. Blackburn with [[Darwen Council]]'s leader Michael Lee described her death as a very shocking incident.<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk"/>
It was revealed on the 14th that all of the British [[county councils]], [[London boroughs]] and [[unitary authorities]] were advised by the government to have six days' supplies of [[road salt]] in 2009.<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web |url=http://vladivostoktimes.com/content/photo.php?id=46237&f=64121&mode=pub |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717230155/http://vladivostoktimes.com/content/photo.php?id=46237&f=64121&mode=pub |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 17, 2011 |title=Фото 25 декабря 2009, 12{{nbsp}}noon. At Weekend Primorye to be Covered with Snow - PrimaMedia. Последние новости Владивостока, Приморский край, Приморье, Дальний Восток |publisher=Vladivostoktimes.com |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Up to 30 councils rejected last year's offer of thousands of tonnes of [[road salt|de-icing salt]] at a reduced price, to use on the roads this winter according to the [[BBC]].<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref name="ReferenceA"/> The [[British Salt]] Director David Stephen made an offer out of the firm's 60,000 tonnes stockpile at [[Middlewich]], [[Cheshire]], in April 2009, but virtually no one to take up the offer.<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref name="ReferenceA"/> Evidence suggests that only a few took up the government's advice. The [[Highways Agency]] had 13 days worth of road salt, while [[Glasgow]], [[Kirklees]], [[Derbyshire]], [[Derby]] City, [[Buckinghamshire]], [[Cherwell District]] and the [[London Borough of Harrow]] took up the offer and raised their [[stock pile]]s to seven days worth. The [[Cherwell (district)|Cherwell Borough]], [[Bicester Parish]], [[Oxfordshire]], [[Slough]] borough, Harrow, [[Leicestershire]], [[Buckinghamshire]], [[Fife]], [[Brighton and Hove|Brighton and Hove unitary authority]], [[Liverpool]] city, [[Pembrokeshire]], [[Lancashire]], [[Belfast]] city and [[Perth and Kinross]] councils nearly to run out of [[salt]].<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref name="ReferenceA"/> Scotland, Cumbria, Northumbria and Northern Ireland were getting priority access to salt due to the severity of the local landscape and storm activity.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
There were also road closures in [[Ceredigion]] including the A4120 at [[Ponterwyd]], and the A4086 at [[Nant Peris]] in [[Gwynedd]] had been shut down due to hazardous driving conditions. All of [[Caerphilly]]'s 90 schools and Rhondda Cynon Taf's (RTC) 130 schools either were fully or partially shut except to pupils sitting there.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> To Wales' [[Education Minister]] [[Leighton Andrews]], Welsh [[First Minister]] [[Carwyn Jones]] and the [[WJEC exam board]] helped organise the Welsh [[GCSE]]s and [[A-level]] exam locations.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> A [[Merthyr Tydfil]] exam was held in a local [[sports centre]]'s [[hockey]] arena according to the BBC.
Temperatures of +43.6C were reported in parts of Australia as a heat wave hit most of the country.<ref name="bloomberg.com">[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601080&sid=a.rcXt3Jenhs Bloomberg]</ref> Heavy rain also fell in parts of [[Indonesia]] and [[Queensland]], Australia.<ref name="bloomberg.com"/>
===January 15–18===
As the snow cleared from the United States, the British Isles and Europe, rain began to fall in place on the 14th and the snow also began to relent in both China, [[Korea]] and Japan on the 15th. Light snow was reported in [[Latvia]] on the 14th and 15th.
On the 15th, [[Greater Manchester Police]] said seven people had been injured when 10 cars crashed on the A627(M) in Oldham.<ref name="Motorway crash BBC">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8459746.stm |title=Motorway crash in Oldham amid further ice warnings |publisher=BBC News |date=January 15, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> [[Met Office]] [[severe weather warning]]s covered Wales and western parts of England and Scotland and snow was forecast for the [[Pennines]] and Scottish and Welsh hills. The [[Environment Agency]] has warned about flooding in some areas of England and Wales. BBC weather forecaster Sarah Keith-Lucas warned of localised flooding in western parts of the UK caused by melting snow, rain and gale-force winds.<ref name="Motorway crash BBC" />
Later on, the Environment Agency warned that heavy rain and snow melting in slightly warmer temperatures meant that there was a risk of some localised flooding from drains, especially in Wales and parts of England, but homes were unlikely to be affected as 15 flood watches were put in place.<ref name="BBC Flood warning">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8462372.stm |title=Flood warning as snow thaws over weekend |publisher=BBC News |date=January 15, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> They warned that flood warnings for possible isolated river flooding in these areas, as heavy rain moves in from the south west on Friday evening.<ref name="BBC Flood warning" /> The [[Met Office]] and said heavy rain would move in from the west accompanied by strong to gale-force winds on Saturday.<ref name="BBC Flood warning" /> The [[Scottish Environment Protection Agency]] had five [[flood watch]]es under way.<ref name="BBC Flood warning" /> [[Thames Valley Police]] warned motorists about surface flooding and [[aquaplaning]] on [[Oxfordshire]]'s roads.
The 15th brought rain and thawing to much of southwest England and a pocket around [[Greater Manchester]]. In the city of [[Manchester]] rain on frozen ground had overnight caused [[glazed frost]] which had largely (but not completely) gone by morning, and at midday the clouds were running fast from the south; the January snowfall was melting fast, but the pre-Christmas snowfall, which was trodden had half thawed to slush and then frozen hard to solid ice overnight, was slower to melt. In Scotland the thaw melted fresh snow. Flood warnings were issued.
Snow fell in parts of southern [[Scotland]] and [[Yorkshire]] on the 16th. The [[Cairngorm Ski Centre]] was closed as an army of diggers was trying to clear its car park after further snowfalls. The river [[River Derwent, Cumbria|Derwent]] was put under a [[flood watch]] in places on the 16th.
On January 17, [[Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region]] was given more than 850 tons of grain, edible oil and other daily supplies, 4,950 tons of coal and 900 tons of emergency cattle fodder.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sourcejuice.com/1296265/2010/01/17/Inner-Mongolia-snowstorms-across-face-disaster-self-help/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716112153/http://www.sourcejuice.com/1296265/2010/01/17/Inner-Mongolia-snowstorms-across-face-disaster-self-help/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 16, 2011 |title=Inner Mongolia snowstorms across the face of all-out disaster self-help |publisher=Sourcejuice.com |date=January 17, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
On January 17, both melting snow, heavy rain and frozen ground have caused flooding in much of England, Scotland and Wales.<ref name="BBC flood warnings after thaws">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8463887.stm |title=Flood warnings issued after heavy rain and snow thaws |publisher=BBC News |date=January 17, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> The Environment Agency issued a total of 23 flood warnings were issued in England, one in force for Scotland and two in Wales.<ref name="BBC flood warnings after thaws" /> In Scotland a landslide led to the temporally closure of the A76 in [[Dumfries and Galloway]], while a section of the M74 was shut temporally shut due to flooding.<ref name="BBC flood warnings after thaws" />
[[File:Banbury pothole in 2010.png|thumb|right|175px|The ''Banbury Cake'' and ''[[The Banbury Review Newspaper|The Banbury Review]]'' newspapers did an exposé on the weather induced [[potholes]] during the second week of January 2010.]]
Many properties in [[Maesteg]], [[Bridgend]], [[Ebbw Vale]] and [[Monmouth]] were also flooded. [[Mid and West Wales Fire service]] sent extra appliances to the [[Carmarthen Bay]] [[holiday village]] at [[Kidwelly]], where the flooding was described as 'major to severe'.<ref name="BBC flood warnings after thaws" /> The [[River Wye]], [[River Dee, Wales|River Dee]] (''Welsh: Afon Dyfrdwy'') in the lower [[Dee Valley]], [[River Cherwell]] (at [[Banbury]]) and [[River Severn]] were all in full flood.<ref name="BBC flood warnings after thaws" />
