[[Severn Trent Water]], which provides water to central England and parts of [[Wales]], said it had drafted in extra staff as ruptured and frozen pipes began to thaw.<ref name="BBC flood warnings after thaws" /> Many pipes had ruptured in the [[Welsh Marches]] and a sewerage pipe had become blocked in outer [[Birmingham]].<ref name="BBC flood warnings after thaws" /> The company's [[senior operations manager]], Fraser Pithie, said the firm had been called out to more than 470 burst and ruptured pipes since the 10th and their call centre staff had taken more than 10,000 calls.<ref name="BBC flood warnings after thaws" />
===January 17–24=== From Sunday, January 17 to Saturday, January 24, a series of five very powerful winter storms bore down on the Western United States (especially Southern California), and spread eastward on the 20th which is the atmospheric river storms in California, piling more snow across the [[Great Plains]] and even as far as parts of [[Pennsylvania]] and [[New Jersey]].<ref name="businessweek.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-01-19/california-storms-to-head-east-bringing-high-winds-rain-snow.html |title=California Storms to Head East, Bringing Rain, Snow (Update2) |publisher=BusinessWeek |date=January 19, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> 200 homes were evacuated as floods hit parts of California as up to {{convert|6|in|cm}} of rain fell in the first of the storms.<ref name="businessweek.com"/> Rescue and flood prevention services soon got everything under control, but one man was killed when a tree fell onto his house.<ref name="businessweek.com"/> Two horses died after being hit by lighting in a [[Santa Barbara, California|Santa Barbara]] field. Rare [[tornado warning]]s were enforced in parts of Southern California, including southern Los Angeles, [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]], southeastern San Diego County, and [[Anaheim, California|Anaheim]]. [[Flash flood]] watches covered Los Angeles, [[Santa Barbara County, California|Santa Barbara]], and [[Ventura County, California|Ventura]] counties.<ref name="businessweek.com"/> An EF-0 tornado was reported in southeastern San Diego County that lasted for 1 minute, 30 seconds. Jim Rouiller, the senior energy meteorologist at Planalytics Inc., said that the storms (more specifically, the fifth storm, which was the strongest one) were the worst series of storms since 1997 (the one that caused the [[Floods in California#New Year's Day 1997: Northern California Flood|1997 Northern California New Year's Day Flood]]). The fifth storm also neared the record of the lowest pressure system ever experienced in San Diego, registering a minimum pressure of {{convert|973|mbar|inHg}} while it was in the Pacific.<ref name="businessweek.com"/> Rouiller expected that evening's storm to bring from {{convert|4|to|12|in}} of rain, severe [[mudslide]]s, a few [[tornado]]es and heavy mountain snow ranging from {{convert|6|to|15|ft}} across the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]].<ref name="businessweek.com"/> A heavy rain storm hit [[Santee, California]], on January 19.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://video.aol.co.uk/video-detail/santee-ca-rainstorm-1192010/1675306506 |title=Santee, California Rainstorm 1/19/2010 - AOL Video |publisher=Video.aol.co.uk |date=January 19, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
Heavy rain fell in [[Oxfordshire]] and [[King's Sutton]], causing some flooding. The [[River Cherwell]] nearly flooded [[Banbury]] and parts of [[Oxford]]. Light snow fell in the [[Pennines]] the 19th.
[[California]] state water officials warned on January 21 that one week of heavy rain and snow was not enough to end the [[drought]],<ref name="reuters.com">{{cite news |first=Dan |last=Whitcomb |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN2116009120100121 |title=Storms bring badly needed snow, rain to California |publisher=Reuters |date=January 25, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref><ref name="scientificamerican.com">{{cite web |title=Storms bring badly needed rain |url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=storms-bring-badly-needed |accessdate=June 15, 2010}}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> which is entering its fourth year by 2010.<ref name="reuters.com"/><ref name="scientificamerican.com"/> According to measurements on the Thursday, the average water content of state's mountain ranges' [[snowpack]]s, considered the state's biggest ''de facto'' 'reservoir', was at 107% percent of normal capacity.<ref name="reuters.com"/><ref name="scientificamerican.com"/> As the fourth and second strongest of the week's storms slammed into California, officials predicted as much as four feet (1.2 metres) of snow would fall in [[Northern California]].<ref name="reuters.com"/><ref name="scientificamerican.com"/>
Freshly fallen snow blanketed the north side of the [[San Gabriel Mountains]] on the morning after the fourth storm of the week dissipated on January 23, 2010, northwest of [[Wrightwood, California]].<ref name="en.apa.az">{{cite web |url=http://en.apa.az/news.php?id=114567 |title=APA - Storms trash California beaches, bring snow |publisher=En.apa.az |date=January 24, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311004853/http://en.apa.az/news.php?id=114567 |archivedate=March 11, 2012 |df=}}</ref><ref name="talktalk.co.uk">{{cite web |url=http://www.talktalk.co.uk/news/daily/photos/galleries/view/daily/20100124/browse/750084 |title=January 24, 2010 gallery - Severe Rain Storms Continue To Threaten The Los Angeles Area |publisher=Talktalk.co.uk |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Snow was reported in many parts of California.<ref name="en.apa.az"/> On January 24, the 5th and strongest storm caused heavy rain fell in parts of Los Angeles.<ref name="en.apa.az"/><ref name="talktalk.co.uk"/> 500 people were evacuated from a small village in [[La Paz County, Arizona]] due to a [[flash flood]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.apa.az/news.php?id=114567 |title=APA |publisher=En.apa.az |date=January 1, 1970 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311004853/http://en.apa.az/news.php?id=114567 |archivedate=March 11, 2012 |df=}}</ref>
===January 19–30=== On January 20, heavy rainstorms wreaked havoc in [[Haifa]], Israel, as snow covered [[Mount Hermon]] in the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights.
Both [[Wakehurst Place]], near [[Ardingly]], [[West Sussex]] and [[Bedgebury Pinetum]], near [[Lamberhurst]] in [[Kent]], were damaged.<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/sussex/8471070.stm |title=Snow damages hundreds of trees |publisher=BBC News |date=January 20, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Iain Parkinson, [[Wakehurst Place|Wakehurst]]'s woodland and conservation manager who has worked on the estate for 23 years, said it was the worst storm he had ever seen in the park.<ref name="autogenerated2"/>
A new snow storm came over the [[Peter the Great Gulf]], near [[Vladivostok]] on January 21.<ref name="eosnap.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.eosnap.com/?tag=Vladivostok |title=Earth Snapshot • |publisher=Eosnap.com |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The [[Onland Mountains]] and [[Sikhote-Alin Mountains]] were buried in snow as the [[weather system]] swept through Primorsky and Khabarovsk Krais, Russia. [[Lake Khanka]] froze over and was then covered in snow.<ref name="eosnap.com"/> The ice on the lake was reported to be several inches thick and the snow was spreading into China's [[Heilongjiang]] province.
January 21 witnessed the final day of some [[Banbury]] schools remaining closed, after 2 weeks of general closure, in which most remained closed throughout the fortnight. The video of people [[Ice skating|skating]] and walking on the [[Oxford Canal]] was shown on [[regional TV]] again, along with a nationwide online version.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.banburyguardian.co.uk/news/Snow-to-last-all-day.4936021.jp |title=Snow to last all day: Pictures and school closures - Banbury Today - Back to Home Page |publisher=Banburyguardian.co.uk |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Heavy rain fell in [[Oxfordshire]], [[Warwickshire]] and [[Leicestershire]] as light snow fell in the Pennines on the 22nd.
The snowstorm that began on Friday night, the 22nd was also hitting parts of [[Bulgaria]], where a man suffering from a [[heart attack]] died in the country's northeastern region of [[Silistra]], when the [[ambulance]] he was being carried on was road that was blocked by several [[snow drift]]s.<ref name="news.az">{{cite web |url=http://www.news.az/articles/7415 |title=Snow storms claim four lives in Turkey |publisher=News.Az |date=January 25, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314220750/http://www.news.az/articles/7415 |archivedate=March 14, 2012 |df=}}</ref> Power, gas and water cuts occurred in [[Istanbul]].<ref name="news.az"/> In Turkey's western region, near the [[Greece|Greek]] and [[Bulgaria]]n borders, villages were cut off and all the major roads were blocked by heavy snow.<ref name="news.az"/> A bus overturned in Istanbul, injuring 10 people; Bulgarian authorities urged people to avoid travel due to heavy snowfall.<ref name="news.az"/> Dozens of stranded cars and trucks were abandoned due to heavy snow in eastern Bulgaria and a train was trapped near the border with [[Romania]].<ref name="news.az"/> Some snow was also reported in neighboring parts of Romania.
A total of four people died on the 24th and 25th as snowstorms hit Turkey.<ref name="news.az"/> The frozen body of 78-year-old Mehmet Aksit was found outside the small town of [[Akkisla]] in central [[Kayseri]] province after relatives reported him missing.<ref name="news.az"/> On the 24th, Nuri Turhan, an 81-year-old [[Korean War]] veteran's corpse was found in a mountainous region of Turkey's [[Aydin]] province, where he had gotten lost walking the day before<ref name="news.az"/> and a 75-year-old man died of [[hypothermia]] in the northwestern Turkish province of [[Tekirdag]].<ref name="news.az"/> The 4th person was found dead in a fierce snowstorm that caused power outages in Turkey and traffic chaos in neighbouring Bulgaria on the 25th.<ref name="news.az"/>
Turkish [[climatologists]] working for Istanbul's [[Natural Disaster Coordination Committee]] told Turkey's ''[[Hurriyet Daily News]]'' that snowfall was predicted to continue until Monday evening and reach about {{convert|35|cm|in|abbr=off}} in parts of Istanbul.<ref name="news.az"/>
It was revealed that at least 22 people had died due to extremely cold temperatures in [[Romania]] in the last five days by January 25.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-ultima_ora-6843711-gerul-provocat-22-decese-ultimele-cinci-zile.htm |title=Gerul a provocat 22 de decese in ultimele cinci zile |publisher=Hotnews.ro |language=Romanian |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.antena3.ro/stiri/meteo/mai-frig-ca-la-polul-nord-temperaturile-din-romania-mai-scazute-ca-in-nordul-continentului_90311.html |title=Mai frig ca la Polul Nord Temperaturile din Romania mai scazute ca in Alaska |publisher=Antena3.ro |language=Romanian |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100128200122/http://www.antena3.ro/stiri/meteo/mai-frig-ca-la-polul-nord-temperaturile-din-romania-mai-scazute-ca-in-nordul-continentului_90311.html |archivedate=January 28, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.antena3.ro/stiri/romania/au-murit-de-frig-11-decese-din-cauza-gerului-in-ultimele-24-de-ore_90318.html |title=Au murit de frig 11 decese din cauza gerului in ultimele 24 de ore |publisher=Antena3.ro |language=Romanian |date=January 25, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mediafax.ro/english/cold-weather-kills-11-people-in-romania-health-ministry-5194135 |title=Cold Weather Kills 11 People In Romania – Health Ministry - Mediafax |publisher=Mediafax.ro |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
From late 2009 through early 2010, a series of massive snow and ice storms that swept the [[Dakotas]] caused a number of [[Indian Reservation]]s to lose power, heat, and running water for an extended period of time. The storms were most severe in both [[Ziebach County|Ziebach]] and [[Dewey County, South Dakota|Dewey]] counties, [[South Dakota]]. The heavy snow, ice storms and low temperatures of January 26 led to [[Interstate 90]] being closed from [[Chamberlain, South Dakota|Chamberlain]] to the [[Minnesota]] border.<ref name="rapidcityjournal.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.rapidcityjournal.com/news/article_6dd91054-09fb-11df-8bdc-001cc4c03286.html |title=Power and water shortages cripple reservation |publisher=Rapidcityjournal.com |date=January 25, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> At nightfall on Monday the 25th, [[Interstate 29]] was closed from [[Sioux Falls]] to the [[North Dakota]] border.<ref name="rapidcityjournal.com"/>
Power company officials estimated that about 7,600 customers in [[South Dakota]] and 100 in [[North Dakota]] did not have power on Monday. Some phone systems have also experienced brief [[telecommunications outages]].<ref name="rapidcityjournal.com"/> Kristi Truman, director of the [[North Dakota Office of Emergency Management]] was concerned about failing water and power supplies.<ref name="rapidcityjournal.com"/>
Power outages began with a storm in December knocking down around 5,000 power poles, and has been accelerated by an ice storm on January 22 knocking down another 3,000 power lines on the reservation. Among the tribes of South Dakota said to be suffering from the multiple storms are the [[Cheyenne River Sioux]], [[Crow Creek Sioux]] Tribe, Flandreau-Santee Sioux Tribe, Lower Brule Sioux Tribe, Rosebud Sioux Tribe, [[Sisseton-Wahpeton Oyate]] and [[Standing Rock Sioux Tribe]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Baumgart |first=Don |url=http://www.indiancountrytoday.com/national/plains/83646472.html |title=Major storm recovery effort underway for SD reservations | Indian Country Today | Plains |publisher=Indian Country Today |date=February 5, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
"There's been winters this bad before, but not with rain so bad it freezes the power lines and snaps the poles", said Joseph Brings Plenty, the 38-year-old chairman of the Cheyenne River Sioux tribe.<ref>{{cite news |last=Millman |first=Joel |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704094304575029450101290726?mod=rss_Today's_Most_Popular |title=Lakota Sioux Lose Heat, Water Amid Storms - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=January 28, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> The worst day was on the 28th, when a [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] froze to death in his home after running out of fuel.
The reservations were further buffeted by the [[February 5–6, 2010 North American blizzard]], which further depleted foodstocks and exacerbated the power problems.
25 Nepalese people, mostly children, died as a blizzard swept over most of [[Nepal]] on January 7.<ref name="news.xinhuanet.com"/><ref name="无标题文档"/> Snowstorms probably also occurred in mountainous [[Bhutan]] and [[Sikkim]], but no reports were forthcoming.
===January 28–31=== On January 28 floods tore through the [[Dnieper River|River Dnieper]]'s and [[Prypiat River]]'s [[floodplains]]. [[Climatologist]]s from the Ukrainian Hydro-meteorological Centre warned that the 2010 spring flood could be most severe in the past 10 years and that snow packs in some regions are more than usual.<ref name="forua.wordpress.com">{{cite web |url=http://forua.wordpress.com/2010/01/28/ukraine-faces-worst-flood-in-10-years/ |title=Ukraine faces worst flood in 10 years Alternative Review |publisher=For-UA (Ukraine English News) |date=January 28, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ifrc.org/where/country/cn6.asp?countryid=1 |title=Red Cross Red Crescent - Field operations in Ukraine |publisher=Ifrc.org |date=April 28, 2009 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> They also told the Ukrainian news agency [[UKRINFORM]] that February would bring more snow.<ref name="forua.wordpress.com"/> Weather forecasters said that the abnormal winter in Ukraine has seen severe snowfalls being replaced with long-lasting frosts and temperatures as low as −30 °C<ref name="forua.wordpress.com"/> and the predicted flooding was an inevitability, both along the Prypiat River in the [[Volyn Oblast]] and in [[Ternopil Oblast]] and the River Dnieper in [[Kiev]] as the snow layer is twice as high than in recent years.<ref name="forua.wordpress.com"/>
A stiff [[frost]], temperatures of −2 °C to −3 °C and a light mist occurred in [[Oxfordshire]] and western [[Northamptonshire]], during the night as a [[cold front]] crossed the UK. Several cars crashed due to skidding on [[black ice]].
On January 28, blizzards and severe sub-zero temperatures that have killed more than a million livestock in [[Mongolia]] would force thousands of herders to migrate to shantytowns near the capital city of [[Ulan Bator]].<ref name="hurriyetdailynews1">{{cite web |url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/wires.php?id=3497201_mongolia-cold-weather-beijing-severe-snowstorms-freezing-temperatures-may-force-mongolian-herders-into-cities |title=Severe snowstorms, freezing temperatures may force Mongolian herders into cities |publisher=Hurriyetdailynews.com |date=January 28, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Extreme winter weather that began in December and followed a hard summer drought that prevented farmers from stockpiling food for their livestock.<ref name="hurriyetdailynews1"/> Dangerously heavy snow and temperatures as low as −40 °C have affected 19 of Mongolia's 21 provinces, with more than 14,000 Mongolian and [[China|Chinese]] [[Red Cross]] volunteers across the region scrambling to deliver emergency food aid to impoverished herders who have lost nearly all their cattle.<ref name="hurriyetdailynews1"/>
The extreme weather had killed more than one million livestock, the herders' main source of income, according to the [[National Emergency Management Agency]] (NEMA) on the 29th.<ref name="english.people.com.cn">{{cite web |url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90851/6883420.html |title=Mongolian herders move to cities as snowstorms kill livestock - People's Daily Online |work=Xinhua |publisher=English.people.com.cn |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> The bad weather has also reduced food security, intensified poverty and increased domestic rural-urban migration for many families.<ref name="english.people.com.cn"/> Central [[Dundgobi]] Province is one of those in the grip of a 'dzud' event (that is to say a 'major natural disaster').<ref name="english.people.com.cn"/> A local herder named Javzmaa Batbold, a herder in [[Adaatsag County]], Dundgobi province said that 120 of his 500 cattle had died so far.<ref name="english.people.com.cn"/> His [[Yurt|ger]] (a traditional Mongolian felt and wood dwelling) was completely covered in snow, and only when the door's side cleared off did it reveal a dwelling lay underneath. The weather became rather extreme as 80 percent of Mongolia's territory was covered by snow, with depths of 20 to 90 centimetres.<ref name="english.people.com.cn"/>
The [[State Emergency Commission]] issued an appeal to Mongolia's people to launch a campaign to offer aid to herders and called for the [[international community]] to donate food, medicines and equipment as well as funds to help herders.<ref name="english.people.com.cn"/> Most cattle in Adaatsag county of Dundgovi Province (Central Gobi), Mongolia died of [[hypothermia]] on the 30th.<ref name="english.people.com.cn"/> Fuel supplies were also running low.<ref name="english.people.com.cn"/>
Snowstorms hit the east coast of the United States and the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]] of California on the 30th and 31st.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pedigreedatabase.com/gsd/bulletins_read/358978.html?pagen=1 |title=Snow storm on the east coast ... - German shepherd dog |publisher=Pedigreedatabase.com |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Heavy snow fell in the German [[Rhineland]] on the 30th and 31st. Travel chaos was widespread as the snow spread into Hungary and the rest of Germany.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Snow-And-Ice-In-Germany-And-Hungary-Causes-Travel-Chaos-And-Hundreds-Of-Accidents/Article/201001415539024?lpos=World_News_Third_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_15539024_Snow_And_Ice_In_Germany_And_Hungary_Causes_Travel_Chaos_And_Hundreds_Of_Accidents |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120715111603/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Snow-And-Ice-In-Germany-And-Hungary-Causes-Travel-Chaos-And-Hundreds-Of-Accidents/Article/201001415539024?lpos=World_News_Third_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_15539024_Snow_And_Ice_In_Germany_And_Hungary_Causes_Travel_Chaos_And_Hundreds_Of_Accidents |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 15, 2012 |title=Snow And Ice In Germany And Hungary Causes Travel Chaos And Hundreds Of Accidents | World News | Sky News |publisher=News.sky.com |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
Heavy snow storms also hit [[Luxembourg]] on January 31.<ref>{{youtube|id=9FYqhQD0EJo|title=Driving in snow at night in Luxembourg Blizzard PART3 CCC}}</ref>
The 30th saw heavy snow storms hit the [[East Coast of America]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/US/weather/01/30/winter.storms/index.html |work=CNN |title=Winter storm hits mid-South hard |date=January 31, 2010}}</ref>
A [[nor'easter]] dumped tons of snow over much of central and eastern parts of the United States. The nor'easter unleashed heavy snow over the Central United States, and left some places with over {{convert|15|in|cm}} of snow. It then moved eastward and made a sly turn up the coast of America, and left some places with over 12 inches of snow on Saturday, January 30, 2010. Rain and floods also hit [[Southern California]]. 6 inches of rain and temperatures of 15 °C were recorded at [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]] and [[Los Angeles|L.A.]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/8487473.stm |title=Who said it never rains in Southern California? |publisher=BBC News |date=January 31, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> on the 31st.
== February ==
===February 1–4=== On February 1, the [[Government of the People's Republic of China|Chinese government]] aid arrived in Mongolia and included 10 million [[Chinese yuan|Yuan]]'s (1.46 million [[US Dollar|U.S. dollars]]') worth of food, [[portable power generators]] and [[quilt]]s.<ref name="reliefweb.int">{{cite web |url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900sid/MUMA-82A7C9?OpenDocument |title=ReliefWeb ť Document ť Chinese aid arrives in Mongolia to help combat snowstorms |publisher=Reliefweb.int |date=February 1, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Mr. [[Miyeegombyn Enkhbold]], Deputy [[Prime Minister of Mongolia]] and head of the State Emergency Commission,<ref name="reliefweb.int"/> said the aid given showed an embodiment of brotherhood between China and Mongolia, and Chinese Ambassador Yu Hongyao said he was confident that Mongolians would overcome the disaster in time.<ref name="reliefweb.int"/> It was said to be the worst snow storms in both [[Mongolia]] and [[Inner Mongolia]] in at least 30 years.<ref name="reliefweb.int"/> The [[Red Cross Society of China]] has also announced a donation of 30,000 dollars for Mongolia,<ref name="reliefweb.int"/> and [[Kazakhstan]] sent several hundred tonnes of food aid to the country. Mongolia formally requested aid from the [[United Nations]] on the 2nd, after the extreme cold is calculated to have killed about 3% of the nation's 44,000,000 head of cattle thus far.<ref>[http://www.unmultimedia.org/radio/english/detail/90216.html Mongolians seek to protect their livestock against freezing winters]. United Nations Radio. February 2, 2010.</ref>
{{Main|February 5–6, 2010 North American blizzard}} [[File:North American blizzard 2010 Feb 6 0531 UTC.jpg|thumb|175px|right|North American blizzard of 2010, imaged by [[NOAA]] [[GOES 12]] on February 6, 2010 at 0531 [[UTC]].]]
On February 1, utility crews were working overtime to get power back to the 14,000 residents of [[Cheyenne River Sioux Reservation]].<ref name="video.aol.co.uk">{{cite web |url=http://video.aol.co.uk/video-detail/crst-2010-interview-with-powerline-crew-foreman/3845718451 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130419145143/http://video.aol.co.uk/video-detail/crst-2010-interview-with-powerline-crew-foreman/3845718451 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=April 19, 2013 |title=CRST 2010 - Interview with Powerline Crew Foreman - AOL Video |publisher=Video.aol.co.uk |date=February 1, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> The [[wind chill]] factor averaged about −25° and there was about 1-foot of snow on the ground on average.<ref name="video.aol.co.uk"/>
A powerful [[Alberta clipper]]-type storm came from the north and headed towards an area of moist air left over from the previous day's thunderstorm over the [[Midwest]] on February 1, and was merging over central North America. It was estimated that it could potentially drop up to 6 inches on the [[Canadian Prairies]] and [[North Dakota]] initially and eventually add 2 more inches as it hung around overnight.
February 1 saw the earlier [[California]]n storm track its way through northern Mexico and [[New Mexico]]. It would shortly hit the east coast and cause chaos in the Washington, D.C., Virginia and Maryland areas by the February 6.
A cyclone and heavy rain-induced floods hit the [[Canary islands]] on February 1 and 2.<ref name="euronews1">{{cite web |url=http://www.euronews.net/2010/02/02/canary-islands-rocked-by-floods/ |title=Canary Islands rocked by floods - Flood : news, world |publisher=euronews |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> An unusual event dropped 82 mm of rain and flooded out 27,000 homes over a 24-hour period. Some mobile phones become inoperable due to storm-related interference and power supplies were cut overnight in some places. The average February rainfall is only 36 millimetres.<ref name="euronews1"/>
February 4 saw the worst winter in [[Beijing]] in 50 years, worst in [[Seoul]] in 70 years.<ref name="dailymail.co.uk">[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1248425/Vancouver-Olympic-chiefs-truck-snow-combat-citys-warmest-winter-record.html Vancouver Olympic chiefs truck snow, combat city's warmest winter record]</ref>
The snow and frost activity was proving to be exceptionally bad that winter across northern India. Official reports suggest that the states of [[Punjab (Indian state)|Punjab]], [[Bihar]], [[Haryana]] and [[Uttar Pradesh]] have borne the brunt of the freezing temperatures in India.<ref name="dailymail.co.uk"/>
Officials at Canada's [[Vancouver Games]] were also worried about the lack of snow and frost as the city experienced its warmest January ever as the temperature never went below −2 °C. The average daily high and low for January 2010 was 9.7 and 4.3 °C at the airport, which was way above the average high of 5 °C and the average low of −1 °C for January. No snow was also recorded in January compared to an average of about 17 cm and an average snow depth of 1 cm.<ref name="dailymail.co.uk"/>
The east coast had records various record low temperatures in southern states such as [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] [[Alabama]] and [[Florida]] in the US.<ref name="dailymail.co.uk"/> The [[East Coast of the United States|eastern seaboard]], had like the [[West Coast of the United States|Western Seaboard]] also suffered one of the worst winters on record. An already snow bound Washington, D.C. was expected to receive up to another 20 inches of snow that weekend. Snow was also threatening the [[American football]] championship event known as the [[Super Bowl]].<ref name="dailymail.co.uk"/>
11 were killed by avalanches in [[Farah Province|Farah]], [[Bamyan Province|Bamyan]], [[Ghor]] and [[Daykundi]] provinces between the 4th and the 8th a spokesman of the [[Afghanistan National Disasters Management Authority]] said.<ref name=20dead/> The Afghan [[flash flood]]s and avalanches left 20 others dead in the rest of the country on February 8.<ref name=20dead/> The provincial authorities had summoned an emergency meeting and [[loya Jurga]] to discuss responses on February 8. Both [[Shah Wali Kot]] and [[Shorandam]] districts were the worst affected. Afghanistan generally expects about 400,000 people every year, according to experts at the [[United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]] (OCHA).<ref name=20dead/>
A series of [[avalanches]] caused by a storm in eastern [[Afghanistan]] killed 172 people on February 8 and 9.<ref name="nz.news.yahoo.com">[http://nz.news.yahoo.com/a/-/world/6792599/kabul-fears-avalanche-toll-could-rise/ Kabul fears avalanche toll could rise] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100331160047/http://nz.news.yahoo.com/a/-/world/6792599/kabul-fears-avalanche-toll-could-rise/ |date=March 31, 2010 }}</ref><ref name="trend"/><ref name="thestar1"/>
===February 5–11=== Power outages in both the Dakotas now covered only 100 rural electric customers and minimal numbers in [[Bismarck, North Dakota]] by February 5.<ref>[http://www.kxnet.com/getArticle.asp?ArticleId=516417 Latest North Dakota news, sports, business and entertainment: ...], February 5, 2010.</ref>
The second big snowstorm of the winter hammered the Washington, D.C. area on February 5.<ref name="google.com">{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hOMT99CyfOsuNNKI4p5im39YrfHw |title=AFP: El Niño had a role in US snow storm, expert says |publisher=Google.com |date=February 5, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> The [[El Nino|El Niño]] phenomenon was blamed for the unusually high [[sea surface temperature]]s in the Pacific Ocean that moved east, thus pulling rainfall along with it.<ref name="google.com"/> Normally, El Niño brings increased rainfall across the east-central and [[eastern Pacific]], leading to drier than normal conditions over northern Australia, Indonesia and the Philippines.<ref name="google.com"/>
The storm created historic snowfall totals in the [[Middle Atlantic]] states, rivaling the [[Knickerbocker Storm]] of 1922, as well as extensive flooding and landslides in Mexico. The blizzard stretched from Mexico and New Mexico to [[New Jersey]], killing forty-one people in Mexico, [[New Mexico]], [[Maryland]], [[Virginia]] and other places along its track.
Some places across [[Eastern Panhandle of West Virginia|Eastern West Virginia]], [[Maryland]], [[Northern Virginia]], Washington, D.C., and [[Delaware]] were buried in between {{convert|2|and|3|ft|m}} of snow,<ref name="autogenerated3">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/8501246.stm |title=Snowstorm paralyses Washington, D.C. and eastern US |publisher=BBC News |date=February 6, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> causing air, rail, and [[Interstate Highway System|Interstate highway]] travel to come to a halt.<ref name="Reuters snowstorm">{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN0614831920100206 |title=Powerful snowstorm hits U.S. East Coast |authors=David Morgan and Eric Beech |date=February 6, 2010 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=February 6, 2010}}</ref> On February 6, authorities said about 4 inches of rain fell in [[Hollywood Hills]] and 3.2 inches in Santa Barbara.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goldenyearsofhollywood.com/5153/storms-bring-high-rain-totals-to-la-4-inches-in-hollywood-hills-3-2-in-santa-los-angeles-times/ |title=Storms bring high rain totals to LA: 4 inches in Hollywood Hills; 3.2 in Santa … – Los Angeles Times |publisher=Golden Years of Hollywood |date=February 6, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711104553/http://www.goldenyearsofhollywood.com/5153/storms-bring-high-rain-totals-to-la-4-inches-in-hollywood-hills-3-2-in-santa-los-angeles-times/ |archivedate=July 11, 2011 |df=}}</ref>
[[File:Snow-in-Maryland-Feb-09.JPG|thumb|right|In [[Rockville, Maryland]], cars were buried under more than {{convert|20|in|cm}} of snow by 8:45 am EST on February 6]]
The snow storms of February 6 and 7 left record levels of snow in many cities. Approximately {{convert|2|ft|cm|abbr=on}} of snow had fallen by midday on Saturday.<ref name="autogenerated3"/> The mayor of Washington, D.C., and the governors of [[Virginia]] and [[Maryland]] declared states of emergency as the storm hit both Washington, D.C., Virginia, Maryland, [[West Virginia]], [[Delaware]], [[Pennsylvania]] and [[New Jersey]].<ref name="autogenerated3"/> [[Amtrak]] canceled several trains between New York and Washington, D.C., and also between Washington, D.C. and some southern destinations.<ref name="autogenerated3"/> The storm arrived less than two months after a December storm dumped more than {{convert|16|in|cm}} of snow in Washington, D.C.. Many [[power outages]] were also reported in the city.<ref name="autogenerated3"/>
February 7 saw yet more major power outages in the Washington, D.C. region. At least 420,000 homes were under a blackout as the snow felled trees and cut power lines.<ref name="autogenerated4">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/8502700.stm |title=US snowstorm causes power cuts in Washington, D.C. region |publisher=BBC News |date=February 7, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Some 300,000 homes were without electricity in Maryland and neighboring Virginia, while Washington, D.C. was reporting an initial figure of 100,000 power outages for that day.<ref name="autogenerated4"/> Emergency workers struggled to restore power as {{convert|2|ft|cm|abbr=on}} of snow and a record snowfall of {{convert|3|ft|cm|abbr=on}} fell on Maryland. Transport was badly disrupted from West Virginia to southern New Jersey.<ref name="autogenerated4"/> Washington, D.C., Virginia and Maryland have declared a short term [[state of emergency]], allowing them to activate the [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] in order to help cope with the storm's onslaught.<ref name="autogenerated4"/>
A father and daughter of [[McKeesport, Pennsylvania|McKeesport]] were killed by [[carbon monoxide poisoning]] after improperly using a domestic [[petrol]] generator after a power outage.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thepittsburghchannel.com/news/22490185/detail.html |title=Father, Daughter Dead In McKeesport; Carbon Monoxide Suspected - Pittsburgh News Story - WTAE Pittsburgh |publisher=Thepittsburghchannel.com |date=February 8, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100210071459/http://www.thepittsburghchannel.com/news/22490185/detail.html |archivedate=February 10, 2010 |df=mdy}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/10039/1034340-114.stm |title=Two dead, dozens sickened trying to keep warm |publisher=Post-gazette.com |date=February 8, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |first=Karen |last=Kane}}</ref> On February 7 two children drowned trying to cross the swollen [[Chapulin River]] in the central state of [[Guanajuato]], and other child deaths occurred in [[Angangueo]], [[Zitácuaro]], and [[Ocampo, Guanajuato|Ocampo]]. In total, twenty-eight deaths in the states of [[Michoacán]], [[Mexico State]], and the [[Mexican Federal District|Distrito Federal]] (Mexico City) in Mexico have been attributed to the storm on February 6 and 7.<ref name="intensas">{{cite news |title=Intensas lluvias en México han dejado 28 muertos |url=http://www.cronica.com.mx/nota.php?id_nota=486028 |agency=EFE |newspaper=La Crónica |location=Mexico City |date=February 5, 2010 |accessdate=February 7, 2010 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Intense rains have left 28 dead}}</ref>

[[File:More snow comeing.jpg|thumb|175px|right|The weather conditions as of February 7, 2010 at 4:00 pm [[Central Time Zone (Americas)|CST]].]]
A powerful [[Alberta clipper]] from western Canada and moist air from a line of [[thunderstorms]] over the mid-western United States merged over the central US on the 7th. In some places this dropped {{convert|6|in|cm}} over the Central and Eastern United States, much of it over areas already hit by the previous blizzard. {{convert|10|-|15|in|cm}} was expected to fall on Washington, D.C., and up to {{convert|1|-|2|ft|m}} of snow was forecast from New York City northward into [[New England]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.weather.com/multimedia/videoplayer.html?clip=2907 |title=BlueBox Video Player |publisher=weather.com |date=January 8, 2007 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100301102345/http://www.weather.com/multimedia/videoplayer.html?clip=2907 |archivedate=March 1, 2010 |df=}}</ref> Several inches of snow fell in both Washington, D.C. and New York City on the night of February 10 and 11.
On February 8, there was nearly {{convert|45|cm|in}} of snow recorded at [[Reagan National Airport]], and nearby [[Dulles International Airport]] recorded a local record of {{convert|80|cm|in}}.<ref name="thestar.co.za">{{cite web |url=http://www.thestar.co.za/index.php?fArticleId=5342796 |title='Snowmageddon' calms US capital |publisher=Star |date=February 8, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> The storms were dubbed "[[Snowmageddon]]", by US president [[Barack Obama]], after an [[SUV]] in his motorcade carrying journalists was damaged by a snapped limb, injuring one person.<ref name="thestar.co.za"/> An area all the way from [[Pennsylvania]] to [[New Jersey]], across the [[BosWash]] corridor and south down to [[Virginia]], was under at least {{convert|60|cm|in}} of snow. Parts of Northern Maryland had {{convert|90|cm|in}}.<ref name="thestar.co.za"/> The storm killed three people.
Snow began to fall throughout [[Oxfordshire]], [[North London]], and [[Bavaria]] on February 8 and February 10. Heavy winds and snow flurries also hit parts of [[Leicestershire]], [[Northamptonshire]], in Turkey, and [[Amur Krai]], on February 9. 1 person suffered moderate injuries after slipping on ice in one of the rural northern districts of Amur Krai. On February 10 a deep cyclone formed over the [[Adriatic Sea]] bringing heavy snowfall over large parts of [[Bulgaria]], [[Serbia]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] and lesser parts of [[Romania]]. Severe weather warnings have been issued in these countries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.focus-fen.net/?id=n209732 |title=FOCUS Information Agency |publisher=Focus-fen.net |date=February 10, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> In Western Bulgaria it snowed non-stop for more than 48 hours, with up to a metre of snow accumulation in [[Kyustendil]].
United States federal government activities were ground to a halt by the, in some places 3 ft deep, snowfall in Washington, D.C. on the 10th.<ref>{{cite news |last=Frei |first=Matt |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/world_news_america/8509658.stm |title=World News America - Matt Frei's diary: White noiseless |publisher=BBC News |date=February 10, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>

===February 12–19===
Following a storm in the southeast United States on February 12–13, snow was on the ground simultaneously in all 50 [[U.S. states]], an event believed never to have occurred previously.<ref name="marsh">{{cite web |url=http://newsok.com/ou-student-found-snow-in-50-states/article/3440383?custom_click=rss |title=OU student found snow in 50 states |author=Matt Dinger |date=February 18, 2010 |publisher=NewsOK |accessdate=February 18, 2010}}</ref> Snow was confirmed in 49 states by February 13, and small patches of remnant snow on the north face of [[Mauna Kea]] in [[Hawaii|Hawai'i]] were confirmed soon after. The snow on February 12–13 forced the cancellation of [[Bi-Lo (United States)|Bi-Lo]] [[Myrtle Beach, South Carolina|Myrtle Beach]] Marathon XIII after the 5k portion had been run the previous night. A record depth of 12.5 inches of snow fell within 24 hours in the [[Dallas]]–[[Fort Worth]] urban metro on the 13th.<ref>[http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2010/0212/Snow-in-all-50-states-New-storm-could-make-that-true. Snow in all 50 states? New storm could make that true], February 12, 2010</ref> The result of the massive snowstorm led to whole school districts being shut down and over 200,000 buildings were left without power, and forced to use fire and candles to light and heat their homes. A 1 ft tall wind-induced wave swept 3 people off of various southern Californian beaches on the 14th, slightly injuring one. Light snow fell in both parts of [[Hampshire]] and [[Fife]], and heavily in the mountainous regions of [[Sakhalin Island]] on the 15th. About 1800 out of 2400 flights at Hartsfield Jackson Atlanta Airport were cancelled on February 13. Numerous minor car accidents happened all around the Metro Atlanta area.
Moderate amounts of snow fell in [[Gwent (county)|Gwent]] and [[Northamptonshire]] on the 16th. Weather forecasters warned of more snow predicted across [[South East Wales]] and parts of [[Central England]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.westerntelegraph.co.uk/archive/2010/02/17/Latest+News+%28swa_news%29/5013645.More_snow_forecast_for_tomorrow/ |title=More snow forecast for tomorrow (From Western Telegraph) |publisher=Westerntelegraph.co.uk |date=February 17, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Moderate snow fall was reported in both [[Oxfordshire]], [[Northamptonshire]], [[Leicestershire]], the [[Malvern Hills]], [[Pembrokeshire]], [[Bristol]], [[Aberdeenshire]] and [[Greater London]] on February 17 and 18. The various London Authorities warned of growing travel chaos in London on the 18th.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/8521408.stm |title=London Assembly warns against train snow chaos repeat |publisher=BBC News |date=February 18, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
Over two inches of snow had fallen in part of Gwent,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.westerntelegraph.co.uk/archive/2010/02/18/Latest+News+%28swa_news%29/5015837.Heavy_snow_falls_across_Gwent/ |title=Heavy snow falls across Gwent (From Western Telegraph) |publisher=Westerntelegraph.co.uk |date=February 18, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> [[Pembrokeshire]]<ref>[http://www.westerntelegraph.co.uk/news/picturegalleries/2010_snow/ 2010 snow]</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.westerntelegraph.co.uk/news/picturegalleries/north_pembrokeshire_blizzards/ |title=Local News |publisher=Western Telegraph |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> and [[Gloucestershire]] on the 18th. The roadways in the Gloucestershire town of [[Dursley]] had been quickly covered in snow that as a [[cold front|cold weather front]] moved over the west of the county of Gloucestershire,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.westerntelegraph.co.uk/archive/2010/02/18/Gloucestershire+News+%28gaz_gloucestershirenews%29/5015678.Motorists_warned_to_take_care_on_snowy_roads/ |title=Motorists warned to take care on snowy roads (From Western Telegraph) |publisher=Westerntelegraph.co.uk |date=February 18, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Chief Inspector Steve Porter, of [[Gloucestershire Constabulary]] told motorists to take care and warned that many roads including the [[B4221 road|B4221]] at [[Gorsley]] and the [[A4136 road|A4136]] at [[Longhope]] had had major accidents.<ref name="westerntelegraph.co.uk">{{cite web |url=http://www.westerntelegraph.co.uk/archive/2010/02/18/News+%28snj_news%29/5016023.Snow_causes_road_traffic_collisions_near_Dursley/ |title=Snow causes road traffic collisions near Dursley (From Western Telegraph) |publisher=Westerntelegraph.co.uk |date=February 18, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> Most of the roads would be closed due to heavy snow for the next few days.<ref name="westerntelegraph.co.uk"/> Moderate amounts of snow also fell in part of Oxfordshire and Northamptonshire on the 19th.
===February 20–22=== Heavy snowfall occurred in Wales and the Midlands between February 18 and 20.<ref name="Review of UK weather on 18/02/10">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/weather/hi/uk_reviews/newsid_8527000/8527020.stm |work=BBC News |title=Review of UK weather on 18/02/10 |date=February 21, 2010 |accessdate=April 6, 2010}}</ref><ref name="Review of UK weather on 19/02/10">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/weather/hi/uk_reviews/newsid_8526000/8526247.stm |work=BBC News |title=Review of UK weather on 19/02/10 |date=February 20, 2010 |accessdate=April 6, 2010}}</ref><ref name="Review of UK weather on 20/02/10">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/weather/hi/uk_reviews/newsid_8527000/8527039.stm |work=BBC News |title=Review of UK weather on 20/02/10 |date=February 21, 2010 |accessdate=April 6, 2010}}</ref> including in the Welsh town of [[Pant Glas]], [[Gwynedd]] between the 18th and 20th.<ref name="Review of UK weather on 18/02/10"/><ref name="Review of UK weather on 19/02/10"/><ref name="Review of UK weather on 20/02/10"/>

Light snow fell in [[Oxfordshire]] overnight on the 20th and 21st, causing minor traffic disruption. [[Manchester Airport]] was heavily disrupted late on the 20th, closed at 7.10{{nbsp}}am on the 21st, but opened later that morning after much heavy work clearing the snow off of the [[runways]]. Flights were still disrupted by midday.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/8526745.stm |title=Manchester Airport reopens after overnight snowfall |publisher=BBC News |date=February 21, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
A [[Eurostar]] train, with between 700,<ref name="google1">{{cite web |author=(UKPA) – 2 days ago |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5jTwk2gNgyAj9XKOvvmGIr0bJ7_cQ |title=The Press Association: More delays after Eurostar problems |publisher=Google.com |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> 740 <ref name="thesun.co.uk">{{cite news |last=Phillips |first=Rhodri |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/2863286/2hr-ordeal-for-740-on-Eurostar.html |title=2hr ordeal for 740 on Eurostar | The Sun |News |publisher=The Sun |date=February 22, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |location=London}}</ref> and 800 passengers<ref name="ft.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/ddde193c-1fc0-11df-8975-00144feab49a.html |title=/ UK - Journey on ill-starred Eurostar train |publisher=Ft.com |date=February 22, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> on board, broke down in [[Kent]] due to the extremely cold weather and heavy snow in the United Kingdom.<ref name="google1"/>
The Paris-to-London service eventually left [[Gare du Nord]] [[railway station]]<ref name="autogenerated7">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/kent/8528140.stm |title=Eurostar investigates after train breaks down in Kent |publisher=BBC News |date=February 22, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> in Paris two hours late at about 8.15{{nbsp}}pm<ref name="ft.com"/> UK time<ref name="ft.com"/> after an unattended bag caused a security alert.<ref name="autogenerated7"/> Everything was going according to plan, until they were two minutes away from [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]] at 10.15 pm,<ref name="google1"/><ref name="ft.com"/> when the train suddenly stopped, the lights flicked briefly and all power failed, leaving the victims in complete darkness<ref name="ft.com"/> at around 10.45 pm.<ref name="ft.com"/> Passengers reported that the lighting was flickering on and off in a "very spooky manner" throughout the journey, until the Eurostar suddenly stopped,<ref name="ft.com"/> and the lights finally went out completely.<ref name="thesun.co.uk"/> It then became stiflingly hot inside the train<ref name="thesun.co.uk"/><ref name="autogenerated7"/> as the [[ventilation system]] shut down due to the [[power outage]] on board the stricken [[Eurostar]] train. The chaos grew when most of the [[toilets]] stopped working and the staff struggled to find [[emergency lighting]] switches.<ref name="autogenerated7"/> Eventually the train manager walked through all the train carriages, using his emergency torch, announcing that another train and a bus were being sent to rescue them.<ref name="ft.com"/> Passengers carrying luggage then had to clamber down ladders onto the tracks and then back up onto the rescue train that arrived alongside the failed one.<ref name="autogenerated7"/><ref name="autogenerated7"/> The rescue train arrived at [[St Pancras station|St Pancras]] just after 2.30am on the 22nd, more than four-and-a-half hours later than the scheduled arrival time<ref name="google1"/> and the bus also took a few to Ashford, where they took local trains to London. Eurostar technical spokesman, Mr. Bram Smets, said it has stopped in what he described as a "major [[technical problem]]".<ref name="google1"/> Eurostar has launched a probe into the breakdown which left passengers stranded for 4 hours.<ref name="google1"/>

Portugal |date=February 20, 2010 |accessdate=February 22, 2010}}</ref> The average rainfall in Funchal for the whole of February is {{convert|88.0|mm|in|frac=2|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldclimate.com/cgi-bin/data.pl?ref=N32W016+2100+08521W |title=Weather station FUNCHAL/S.CATARINA Average Rainfall |publisher=worldclimate.com |accessdate=February 22, 2010}}</ref> Damage was confined to the southern half of the island.<ref name="BBCnews">{{Cite journal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8526700.stm |title=Britons in Madeira warned after deadly floods |publisher=BBC News |date=February 21, 2010}}</ref>

About 42 people were reported dead<ref name="publico26">{{Cite news |url=http://www.publico.pt/Sociedade/madeira-numero-de-mortos-aumentou-para-42_1424675 |title=Madeira: Número de mortos aumentou para 42 |newspaper=Público |language=Portuguese |date=February 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100611132524/http://publico.pt/Sociedade/madeira-numero-de-mortos-aumentou-para-42_1424675 |archivedate=June 11, 2010 |df=}}</ref><ref name="publico26"/><ref name="publico21">{{Cite news |url=http://www.publico.pt/Sociedade/sobe-para-43-o-numero-de-mortos-na-madeira_1423727 |title=Sobe para 43 o número de mortos, já se contam mais de 100 feridos |newspaper=Público |language=Portuguese |date=February 21, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110919060337/http://www.publico.pt/Sociedade/sobe-para-43-o-numero-de-mortos-na-madeira_1423727 |archivedate=September 19, 2011 |df=}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated6">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8526288.stm |title=Madeira floods and mudslides kill 32 |publisher=BBC News |date=February 20, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref><ref name="timesonline.co.uk">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article7035248.ece |title=Briton among 42 killed as flooding truns Madeira into sea of mud |publisher=Times Online |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |location=London |date=February 22, 2010 |first=Graham |last=Keeley}}</ref> and about 68<ref name="autogenerated6"/> to 100 <ref name="timesonline.co.uk"/> injured as rain-induced floods and mudslides hit the Portuguese island of Madeira on the 20th,<ref name="autogenerated6"/><ref name="timesonline.co.uk"/> local authorities said. The [[floodwater]]s tore down buildings, overturned [[Automobile|cars]] and knocked down [[trees]].<ref name="cnn.com">{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/europe/02/21/portugal.mudslide/index.html?hpt=C1 |title=Death toll rises after mudslides on Portuguese island |publisher=CNN.com |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |date=February 21, 2010}}</ref> The local civil protection service declared that it was "overwhelmed" by emergency calls, according to a duty [[police officer]] in an interview with a journalist from the [[Reuters]] news agency.<ref name="autogenerated6"/> According to Portuguese media, the storms were the deadliest on the east Atlantic island since prior to October 1993,<ref name="autogenerated6"/> when 8 people died and 19 were injured.<ref name="autogenerated6"/>
The [[Portuguese military]] sent specialist rescue teams to the island of [[Madeira]] on the 21st, when it was estimated that least 38 people were known to have died<ref name="autogenerated8">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8526679.stm |title=Portugal rushes aid to Madeira after deadly floods |publisher=BBC News |date=February 21, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> in the most extreme rainstorms in 17 years<ref name="timesonline.co.uk"/> as tonnes of mud and stones brought down the slopes of the island, flooding the streets of the regional capital, [[Funchal]], and other towns.<ref name="autogenerated8"/> All utilities were knocked out across large swathes of the island.<ref name="autogenerated8"/> [[Ribeira Brava, Madeira Islands|Ribeira Brava]] was also badly flooded on the 21st.<ref name="cnn.com"/> [[Prime Minister of Portugal|Portuguese Prime Minister]] [[Jose Socrates]], who was in Madeira, ordered an immediate rescue and aid mission for the island.<ref name="autogenerated8"/> [[Portuguese President]] [[Cavaco Silva]] expressed his condolences in a televised statement.<ref name="cnn.com"/>
A [[Portuguese Navy]] [[Replenishment oiler|supply ship]], with a [[helicopter]], food and [[medical equipment]] was sent to the islands that lie about 900 km/560miles from the Portuguese mainland.<ref name="autogenerated8"/> The Island is very popular with foreign tourists.<ref name="autogenerated8"/> Officials from the [[Portuguese Department of Emergencies]] said that emergency teams, 56 [[military rescuer]]s, [[search dog]]s and 36 [[firefighter]]s were being sent to the island straight away.<ref name="autogenerated8"/>
The Island's authorities and the local civil protection board told [[CNN]] that one British tourist was missing.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8526700.stm |title=Briton 'missing' in Madeira floods |publisher=BBC News |date=February 21, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/portugal/7285239/Madeira-floods-Briton-reported-missing-in-floods-that-kill-dozens.html |title=Madeira floods: Briton reported missing in floods that kill dozens |publisher=Telegraph |date=February 21, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010 |location=London |first=Andrew |last=Hough}}</ref> 10 British music students from a religious school in the [[Channel Islands]] were found alive in [[Funchal]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/jersey/8527178.stm |title=Music students from Jersey visiting Madeira 'are safe' |publisher=BBC News |date=February 21, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> along with an Irish tourist as the city is thrown into meteorological chaos. Local authorities informed the [[Agence France-Presse|AFP news agency]] that 70 people were hospitalized.<ref>{{cite web |author=(AFP) – 5 days ago |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gvAvS5vV9gca-eKTyq3GvR5Ps7Bw |title=AFP: Govt probes report of missing national in Madeira |publisher=Google.com |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
On February 22, 102<ref name="http">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8527732.stm |title=Madeira flooding: Foreign Office team checks hospitals |publisher=BBC News |date=February 22, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> to 120<ref name="autogenerated9">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/humber/8528506.stm |title=East Yorkshire family's shock at Madeira death |publisher=BBC News |date=February 22, 2010 |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> were confirmed injured and 42 were confirmed dead in Madeira.<ref name="http"/> 2 British tourists were among the dead.<ref name="autogenerated9"/>
===February 23–28=== Heavy snow fell in [[Oxfordshire]], the [[English Midlands]] and [[Merseyside]] on the 23rd and heavy snow fell in the [[Scottish Highlands]] on the 24th.
[[File:Hartford-Warwickshire snow 2010.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Pictures of snow fall from the last week of February 2010. Top left- A peace of landscapes between Hatton and Lapworh in [[Warwickshire]], top right- Hartford in [[Cheshire]] station, bottom left- Hatton station and bottom right- Lapworth station under snow.]]
On February 24, a meteorological state of emergency was declared in 21 Mongolia's provinces due to the exceptionally cold conditions. It is purported to be the coldest snap for 50 years and that a person has already died of hypothermia.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/weather/storms/winter/2010-02-24-mongolian-winter_N.htm |work=USA Today |title=Winter in Mongolia is 'an unfolding disaster' |first=Calum |last=MacLeod |date=February 25, 2010}}</ref>
{{main|February 25–27, 2010 North American blizzard}} A major [[winter storm]] started plowing its way through upstate [[New York (state)|New York]], southern [[Vermont]] and [[Berkshire County, Massachusetts]] on the 23rd. [[Colonie, New York]] saw a total of 17 inches of snow. [[Hancock, Massachusetts]] had seen 9.5 inches, with the forecast total at 10-15 inches, and [[Stamford, Vermont]] had seen 9 inches.
[[Salem County]], [[New Jersey]] was hit by heavy snow fall on the 24th,<ref name="nj.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.nj.com/salem/index.ssf/2010/02/another_major_snowstorm_could.html |title=Another major snowstorm could strike Salem County beginning tonight |publisher=NJ.com |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref> and 4 to 12 inches of snow were predicted to fall the next day by weather forecasters.<ref name="nj.com"/> Just under 1,000,000 were left without electricity in [[New England]], [[Pennsylvania]] and [[New York (state)|New York]].<ref>[http://www.kwtx.com/weather/headlines/85550177.html Winter Storm Leaves A Million In The Dark] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307122109/http://www.kwtx.com/weather/headlines/85550177.html |date=March 7, 2012 }}. KTWX. February 26, 2010.</ref>
On February 23, snow fell in Southeast [[Texas]]. Snow accumulated in counties north of Houston such as [[Conroe, Texas]], which received 2 inches of snow. [[Huntsville, Texas]] had seen about 2 to 3 inches as well as [[College Station, Texas|College Station]]. Only a trace of snowfall fell in [[Houston, Texas]].
A winter storm warning was issued for counties north of Houston, while Houston had a winter weather advisory.
The extreme [[winter storm]] spun around the [[Northeastern United States|Northeast]] by the 25th. [[Oneonta, New York]] had seen {{convert|44.5|in|cm|abbr=on}} of snow from this storm. New York City had seen {{convert|20.9|in|cm|abbr=on}}, and [[Philadelphia]] had seen {{convert|11.5|in|cm|abbr=on}} of snow. Washington, D.C. and [[Baltimore]] had remained under light rain. [[Boston]] has seen {{convert|4.5|in|cm|abbr=on}} of rain from this storm, and {{convert|9.2|in|cm|abbr=on}} was reported in [[Belfast, Maine]]. Major flooding prevailed along coastal [[New England]]. The [[Shawsheen River]] at [[Wilmington, Massachusetts]] was at 8 feet above its banks, and the [[Merrimack River]] at [[Amesbury, Massachusetts]] was at 20 feet above banks. On Friday morning and night, most of [[Massachusetts]], [[New Hampshire]] and [[Maine]] were without power. Sustained winds of up to 65 mph pounded the [[Cape Ann]] area of eastern Massachusetts. Wind gusts of up to 95 mph were reported in [[Gloucester, Massachusetts]] and [[Rockport, Massachusetts]]. Millions of trees were felled in the wind from [[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]] to [[Bangor, Maine|Bangor]]. [[Boston]] received 52 mph sustained winds and 74 mph gusts. Between February 25 and 26 [[flood warning]]s covered most of [[Rhode island]], the [[Pawtuxet River]] valley, [[Boston]] and [[Norfolk County, Massachusetts|Norfolk County]] in eastern [[Massachusetts]].<ref>[http://www.nws.noaa.gov/alerts/ri.html Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for Rhode Island Issued by the National Weather Service]. Retrieved February 26.</ref> [[Orange County, New York]] saw 2 to 3 feet of snow in [[Montgomery (town), New York|Montgomery]] and [[Bullville, New York|Bullville]].
Widespread [[snowfall]] across [[Scotland]] brought extreme disruption. 61 cm of snow was recorded in [[Aviemore]] as hundreds of people were stranded in cars in [[Dunblane]]. Schools and transport services were disrupted. Two people died in [[Glen Coe|Glencoe]] in an [[avalanche]]. [[Temperature]]s reached −19.2 °C in [[Braemar]]. Some people in [[Perthshire]] were stranded in their cars for 17 hours. 45,000 homes in [[Scotland]] were left without power. 30 schools were closed on the 25th.
On February 26, heavy snow hit New York and more was forecast for the next day.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN2618855320100226 |agency=Reuters |title=UPDATE 2-Heavy winter storms wreak havoc in U.S. Northeast |date=February 26, 2010 |first=Michelle |last=Nichols}}</ref>
{{main|Haitian floods of 2010}} On February 27, unusually heavy monsoon rains hit [[Haiti]]. 11 people died the town in [[Les Cayes]], 3 died in the village of [[Torbeck]], 5 died in the village of [[Les Cayes's Gelee]] as rain induced mudslides and flood waters hit them.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5ioUdZ805IFDzMiAQecr2PmCEBMTA |title='Grave' flooding in quake-hit Haiti kills 11: officials |last=Renois |first=Clarens |date=February 27, 2010 |work=Agence France-Presse |publisher=Google News |accessdate=March 20, 2010}}</ref>
{{Main|Machu Picchu#January 2010 evacuation}} In January 2010, heavy rain caused flooding which buried or washed away roads and railways leading to the ancient city of [[Machu Picchu]], trapping over 2,000 tourists in addition to 2,000 locals. Machu Picchu was temporarily closed,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ubalert.com/a/14452 |title=Machu Picchu Airlift Rescues 1,400 Tourists |last=BBC |first=jhayzee27 |date=January 29, 2010 |work=Disaster Alert Network LLC |publisher=UBAlert |accessdate=February 7, 2010}}</ref> but it reopened on February 28, 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/travel/2010992388_webperu05.html?syndication=rss |title=Machu Picchu to reopen earlier than expected after storms |last=travel staff |first=Seattle Times |date=February 5, 2010 |publisher=The Seattle Times |accessdate=February 7, 2010}}</ref> Peru's rail crew has been hard at work since then, and Machu Picchu reopened to tourists on April 1, 2010.
=== February 28 – March 2===
====Xynthia==== {{main|Xynthia (storm)}} [[File:Xynthia animated small.gif|thumb|right|175px|24-hour animation from 5{{nbsp}}pm, February 27.]]
51 were killed, 59 injured<ref name="bbc0762">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8540762.stm At least 50 dead in western Europe storms]. February 28, 2010.</ref> and 12 are missing in France, 6 killed in Germany, 3 killed and 2 severely injured in Spain, 1 killed in Portugal, 1 in Belgium, 1 in the Netherlands and 1 in England<ref name="bbc0762"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-03/03/c_13194575.htm |title=Violent winter storm kills 62 in western Europe |last=English.news.cn |first=Xinhuanet |date=March 3, 2010 |publisher=Xinhua News Agency |accessdate=March 18, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100426223243/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-03/03/c_13194575.htm |archivedate=April 26, 2010 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> as heavy rainstorms hit the [[Bay of Biscay]] and central France on the 27th. Winds of up to {{convert|140|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} caused chaos as the storm moved from Portugal up through the Bay of Biscay, while a maximum gust of {{convert|228|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} in Spain and {{convert|241|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} in France were recorded. Both Belgium and Denmark were hit by heavy rainstorms overnight as the windstorm moved further northeast.<ref name="bbc0762"/> The storm system moved across the [[Massif Central]] into the [[Brittany]] peninsula, and areas of France bordering Belgium and Germany are on alert for heavy rain and high winds. An [[Italians|Italian]] was also [[injured]] when a [[hurricane]]-force wind capsized his [[yacht]] off the coast of Portugal. The [[President of France|French President]] [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] expressed his condolences to relatives of victims, and said that he would visit the stricken area on Monday.<ref name="bbc0762"/> The [[French Prime Minister]] [[François Fillon]] said France would formally declare the storm a natural disaster, freeing up funds to help communities rebuild themselves.<ref name="bbc0762"/> Rail services were severely affected in northern Spain and a number of trains in western France were delayed because of flooded tracks in southern and western France.<ref name="bbc0762"/> [[British Airways]] canceled several flights and [[Air France]] said 100 of its flights had been cancelled from [[Charles de Gaulle airport]] in Paris. Wind speeds hit 175 km/h at the top of the [[Eiffel Tower]], French radio reported on the 28th.<ref name="bbc0762"/> The French meteorological service said that shortly after 1700 local time (1600 GMT) the storm passed into Germany, Belgium and the Netherlands, and there also were reports of high winds in the [[Swiss Alps]] on March 1. Spain's [[Canary Islands]], particularly [[La Palma]], [[Gran Canaria]] and [[Tenerife]], were also hit by the storm, although there was no great damage.<ref name="bbc0762"/> The French Departments of [[Vendée]] and [[Charente-Maritime]] were in ruins and over 1 million homes lost electricity supplies.<ref name="bbc0762"/> Television, radio and mobile phone service were also disrupted in some places.
On February 28, the French storms killed 7 people who drowned in various villages in the [[Vendée]] region, while 3 seniors and a child were found dead in [[Charente Maritime]] near [[La Rochelle]]. A man was killed by a falling tree branch in the south-western town of [[Luchon]], where winds reached 90 mph. At least five other people were reported missing and dozens others injured and a kid died in Northern Portugal <ref name="guardian.co.uk">[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/feb/28/gale-force-winds-sweep-france Gale force winds sweep France]</ref> 5 people were missing and 1 was injured in [[Aytre]]. The [[French Interior Minister]] [[Brice Hortefeux]] declared the storm as a natural catastrophe.<ref name="chinapost.com.tw">[http://www.chinapost.com.tw/international/europe/2010/03/03/246631/Sarkozy-seeks.htm China Post]</ref><ref name="chinapost.com.tw"/><ref>[http://www.wimp.com/solutionoil/ Cool solution to clean up oil disaster. [VIDEO]]. Wimp.com. Retrieved August 16, 2010.</ref> The [[Météo France]] [[weather agency]] predicted the storm was by then heading towards Denmark.<ref name="guardian.co.uk"/>
==March==
===March 1–5===
It was confirmed on March 1 that 45-52 (reports vary) French people had died, and that the French government had launched an equine in to why the incident had been so disastrously mishandled.<ref>[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LDE6202CH.htm Reuters AlertNet - Sarkozy seeks answers over French flood damage]. Alertnet.org (March 1, 2010). Retrieved August 16, 2010.</ref> especially around [[La Rochelle]] and [[L'Aiguillon-sur-Mer]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE62042B20100301 |agency=Reuters |title=Sarkozy seeks answers over French flood damage |date=March 1, 2010}}</ref> [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] visited the coastal town of Aiguillon-sur-Mer, the hardest hit area of France where a total 25 had died in the storm.<ref>[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LDE6201CY.htm Reuters AlertNet - Sarkozy pledges help for French flood victims]. Alertnet.org (March 1, 2010). Retrieved August 16, 2010.</ref>
{{main|March 2010 Queensland floods}}
The [[March 2010 Queensland floods|2010 Queensland floods]] saw inundation of the towns of [[Charleville, Queensland|Charleville]], [[Roma, Queensland|Roma]], [[St George, Queensland|St George]] and [[Theodore, Queensland|Theodore]] among others.<ref name="ABC6Mar">{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/03/06/2838492.htm?section=justin |title=Flood threat not over yet in southern Qld |date=March 6, 2010 |work=ABC News |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=March 20, 2010}}</ref> The floods were caused by rainfall generated by a monsoon trough described by a [[Bureau of Meteorology]] forecaster as "almost like a tropical cyclone over land".<ref name="landcyclone">{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/03/01/2832617.htm?site=news |title=Flooding predicted as deluge dumps across Qld |date=March 1, 2010 |work=ABC News |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=March 20, 2010}}</ref> Over the period March 1–3, rainfall totals of between {{convert|100|–|300|mm|in|abbr=on}} were observed in the area.<ref name="landcyclone" /><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/03/02/2833768.htm?site=news |title=Flood fears grow as rain saturates southern Queensland |date=March 2, 2010 |work=ABC News |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=March 20, 2010}}</ref> This water ran into already saturated rivers and creeks in the area.<ref name="landcyclone" /> Losses from cotton crops destroyed at Theodore and the area around St George and Dirranbandi are expected to be significant.<ref name="cotton">{{cite news |url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/cotton-crop-takes-hit-from-qld-floods-20100316-qatu.html |title=Cotton crop takes hit from Qld floods |date=March 16, 2010 |work=Sydney Morning Herald |publisher=Fairfax |accessdate=March 20, 2010}}</ref>
The floods, described by the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries [[Tim Mulherin]] as the "worst flood in 120 years" are however expected to provide a billion dollar boost to the local economy, following the "worst drought since [[Federation of Australia|Federation]]"<ref name="Billion$Boost">{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/rural/news/content/201003/s2847524.htm |title=Flood gives Queensland economy a billion-dollar boost |date=March 16, 2010 |work=ABC Rural |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=March 20, 2010}}</ref> The floods have seen a large increase in the [[Australian plague locust]] population and the [[Australian Plague Locust Commission]] is concerned the locusts will head south and destroy what is expected to be a bumper winter grain crop.<ref name="Locusts">{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/rural/news/content/201003/s2850527.htm |title=Locust explosion after floods |date=March 19, 2010 |work=ABC Rural |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=March 20, 2010}}</ref> On March 21,
{{main|2010 Uganda landslide}} The [[2010 Uganda landslide]] occurred in the district of [[Bududa District|Bududa]] in eastern [[Uganda]] on 1 March 2010.<ref name="Deadly landslide hits east Uganda">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8545005.stm |title=Deadly landslide hits east Uganda |date=March 2, 2010 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=March 2, 2010}}</ref><ref name="Hundreds Missing in Uganda Landslides">{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703807904575097120320491994?mod=googlenews_wsj |title=Hundreds Missing in Uganda Landslides |date=March 2, 2010 |publisher=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=March 2, 2010 |first=<Cite>A |last=Roundup</Cite>}}</ref> The [[landslide]] was triggered by heavy rain between 12 pm and 7 pm that day.<ref name="51 die, 300 missing in Bududa landslide">{{cite news |url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/-/688334/871634/-/wj4p83/-/ |title=51 die, 300 missing in Bududa landslide |author=David Mafabi |date=March 2, 2010 |publisher=Monitor.uk |accessdate=March 2, 2010}}</ref> At least 100 people were believed to have been killed.<ref name="Deadly landslide hits east Uganda"/>
The [[Uganda Red Cross Society|Ugandan Red Cross]] stated that rescuers had recovered 50 bodies, whilst a Ugandan government minister has put the death toll at over 100.<ref name="45 dead, hundreds missing in Uganda landslide-minister">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/03/02/AR2010030200512.html |title=45 dead, hundreds missing in Uganda landslide-minister |date=March 2, 2010 |work=Washington Post |accessdate=March 2, 2010}} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref><ref name="Fifty bodies found in landslide in eastern Uganda">{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-03/02/c_13194463.htm |title=Fifty bodies found in landslide in eastern Uganda |date=March 2, 2010 |publisher=[[Xinhua]] |accessdate=March 2, 2010}}</ref> The chairman of the eastern Bududa district suggested that the death toll could be as high as 300.<ref name="300 feared dead in Uganda">{{cite web |url=http://www.news24.com/Content/Africa/News/965/208ab7dd48e44107bf9ac7f0d2a81f58/02-03-2010-01-20/300_feared_dead_in_Uganda |title=300 feared dead in Uganda |date=March 2, 2010 |publisher=[[News24]] |accessdate=March 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100305103741/http://www.news24.com/Content/Africa/News/965/208ab7dd48e44107bf9ac7f0d2a81f58/02-03-2010-01-20/300_feared_dead_in_Uganda |archivedate=March 5, 2010 |df=mdy}}</ref> The landslide struck villages on the slopes of [[Mount Elgon]], including [[Nameti]], [[Kubewo]], and [[Nankobe]].<ref name="300 feared dead in Uganda"/> Officials and aid workers have warned that there may be further landslides, as heavy rain continues to fall in the region.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKLDE621183._CH_.2420 |title=Ugandan landslide kills scores, many missing-minister |date=March 2, 2010 |publisher=[[Reuters UK]] |accessdate=March 2, 2010}}</ref>
[[AirTran Airways]] cancelled several flights out of [[Atlanta Airport]] due to bad weather<ref name="marketwatch">[http://www.marketwatch.com/story/airtran-airways-customers-affected-by-winter-storms-in-atlanta-may-change-travel-plans-without-penalty-2010-03-01?reflink=MW_news_stmp AirTran Airways Customers Affected by Winter Storms in Atlanta May Change Travel Plans Without Penalty]. March 1, 2010.</ref> on March 1 and 2.<ref name="marketwatch"/>
On March 1, the [[Environment Agency]] issued 169 [[flood warning]]s in over [[East Anglia]], [[Yorkshire]], [[Wrexham]], [[Tyne and Wear]], [[Cambridgeshire]], [[Bedfordshire]], [[Oxfordshire]], [[Kent]] and [[West Sussex]].<ref name="guardian">[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/feedarticle/8967969 Flood warning issued across country]. March 1, 2010.</ref> The [[Thames Flood Barrier]] closed twice in less than 24 hours to protect London from a combined high tide and tidal surge in the [[Thames estuary]], where it had been predicted that the water would rise by another 50 cm.<ref name="guardian"/> Andy Batchelor, Tidal Area Flood Risk Manager, said that the Thames Barrier would close yet again should we need to protect the 1.25 million people living and working in London's [[floodplain]].<ref name="guardian"/>
On March 2, heavy snowstorms struck the [[Virginia]]s and parts of [[Maryland]].<ref>{{youtube|id=LSPI12zcyoM}}</ref>
The [[Ewaso Nyiro River]] in [[Kenya]] burst its banks and flooded a [[safari park]]'s [[guest house (lodging)|guest house]] on the 3rd,<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/newsid_8550000/newsid_8551700/8551753.stm Tourists airlifted from flooding]. March 5, 2010.</ref> killing nine people.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/news/Kenyanews/Kenya-floods-toll-rises-to-nine-7715.html |title=Kenya floods toll rises to nine |last=Karong'o |first=Catherine |date=March 8, 2010 |work=Capital FM Kenya |publisher=Capital News |accessdate=March 20, 2010}}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
On March 4, 20 people died in [[Afghanistan]], when an avalanche struck 2 villages in the [[Wakhan|Wakhan Mountains]].
Several dozen ships, some with nearly one thousand passengers were stranded in rapidly forming [[sea ice]] due to cold weather and strong winds in the [[Gulf of Bothnia]], between Sweden and Finland and near the [[Baltic Sea]]. Some of the ships were freed by [[icebreaker]]s on March 5.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8550687.stm |title=Dozens of ships freed from Baltic Sea ice |date=March 5, 2010 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=March 21, 2010}}</ref>
On March 5, 20,000 people were left homeless when flood-induced landslides struck Bududa, [[Uganda]].<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/35725434/ Uganda floods displace 20,000 - Weather - msnbc.com]. MSNBC. Retrieved August 16, 2010.</ref>
===March 6–20=== {{main|2010 Victorian storms}}
