The [[2010 Victorian storms]] were a series of [[storm]]s that passed through much of the Australian state of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] on March 6 and 7, 2010. One of the most severe storms passed directly over [[Greater Melbourne]], bringing [[lightning]], [[flash flooding]], very large [[hail]] and strong winds to the state's capital.<ref name="MPL1">{{cite news |url=http://mornington-peninsula-leader.whereilive.com.au/news/story/storm-pummels-melbourne/ |title=Storms pummel Melbourne |date=March 6, 2010 |publisher=Mornington Peninsula Leader |accessdate=March 6, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100308054434/http://mornington-peninsula-leader.whereilive.com.au/news/story/storm-pummels-melbourne/ |archivedate=March 8, 2010 |df=mdy}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/australiaandthepacific/australia/7394608/Super-storm-and-giant-hailstones-lash-Melbourne.html |title=Super storm and giant hailstones lash Melbourne |date=March 8, 2010 |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |accessdate=March 11, 2010 |location=London}}</ref> It was described as a "mini-cyclone".<ref>{{cite news |title=Flood Fears After Giant Hail Lashes Melbourne |publisher=Sky News Online |first=Gregor |last=Hunter |date=March 7, 2010 |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Flooding-In-Australia-Melbourne-Hit-By-Torrential-Storms-Marble-Sized-Hailstones/Article/201003115568356?lpos=World_News_Second_Home_Page_Article_Teaser_Region_4&lid=ARTICLE_15568356_Flooding_In_Australia%3A_Melbourne_Hit_By_Torrential_Storms%2C_Marble-Sized_Hailstones |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120729011213/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Flooding-In-Australia-Melbourne-Hit-By-Torrential-Storms-Marble-Sized-Hailstones/Article/201003115568356?lpos=World_News_Second_Home_Page_Article_Teaser_Region_4&lid=ARTICLE_15568356_Flooding_In_Australia:_Melbourne_Hit_By_Torrential_Storms,_Marble-Sized_Hailstones |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 29, 2012 |df=}}</ref>
On March 8, [[Catalonia]] saw its heaviest snowfall in 25 years; up to 50 centimetres fell in [[Barcelona]]. Over 200,000 residents of North-Eastern Spain were left without power, and up to 500 passengers were evacuated from a train travelling to Southern France, which also was experiencing blizzard conditions, with many schools closing. [[Nîmes]] and [[Perpignan]] were the worst-hit.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8557570.stm?ls Snow hits Mediterranean coast]. March 9, 2010.</ref>
A state of emergency was declared in Northern Spain, on the 10th of March, due to the unseasonal blizzards. Forty roads in France were closed with snow reportedly 3 ft deep in some areas. Italy also experienced the effects of the Arctic blast; there was traffic chaos in [[Siena]], [[Assisi]] and [[Pisa]], with snowstorms stretching as far south as Rome. On the sunshine island of [[Majorca]], havoc ensued with 6 major roads closing, due to unseasonal snowfall.
On March 10, transportation and power supplies were disrupted by blizzards around [[Zagreb]], hurricanes around [[Rijeka]] and a mixture of both in [[Dalmatia]]. Both [[Istria]], the northern Adriatic coast and [[Lika]], had electricity supply problems, according to [[Croatian Power Company]] (HEP).<ref>[http://www.mia.com.mk/default.aspx?vId=72207163&lId=2&pmId=502 Macedonian Information Agency - Snow blizzards disrupt road traffic and power supply in Croatia] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323052118/http://www.mia.com.mk/default.aspx?vId=72207163&lId=2&pmId=502 |date=March 23, 2012 }}. MIA. Retrieved August 16, 2010.</ref>

March 13, 2010.</ref>
{{main|March 2010 nor'easter}} The fourth major winter storm to strike the [[East coast of the United States]] caused widespread flooding, severe [[coastal erosion|beach erosion]], and tree and structural damage from [[Virginia]] to [[Maine]] on the 13th. The storm killed at least nine people, and left over 1 million without electricity.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/us/2010/03/15/stubborn-storm-darkens-floods-northeast/ Stubborn Storm Darkens, Floods Northeast, Fox News Channel. On March 16, [[BBC Weather]] reported that areas of Portugal and Spain witnessed the highest recorded levels of [[Precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]], since [[World War II]].
Australia faced the worst flooding in 60 years as 134 people in the small rural town of [[Wanaaring]], just south of the [[Queensland]]/[[New South Wales]] border, remains cut off on the 18th. Heavy [[Dust storm|sandstorms]] hit [[Beijing]] between March 20 and 22.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1974013,00.html |work=Time |title=Beijing: Onslaught of The Mongolian Cyclone |date=March 22, 2010}}</ref> On March 23, a major storm sweeps of the lens west of the [[Bohai Sea]] and the [[Yellow Sea]], and finally falls on the [[North Korea]] and [[South Korea]]. ===March 28–31 ===
The UK was expecting one last shot at winter a huge snow storm is expected to drive up from the [[South West England|South West]] with rain turning to snow Midlands northwards. The UK [[Met Office]] has issued [[severe weather warning]]s for the following regions: Northern Ireland, [[North West England]], [[Wales]], [[Yorkshire & Humber]], [[West Midlands (region)|West Midlands]], [[S.W. Scotland]], [[Lothian and Borders]], [[East Midlands]] and [[North East England]]. Temperatures are expected to go sub zero once again. Snow is forecast from [[Cardiff]], Wales northwards. The warnings come a day after top British [[meteorologists]] from outside the UK Met Office predicted the UK's hottest summer on record for 2010 on the 28th.
Snow fell in [[Scotland]] on March 30, stranding drivers on a motorway leaving them to dig out their cars, the MetOffice released weather alerts for only Scotland and [[Northern Ireland]] as the south wasn't as cold as forecasted however heavy snow is falling on higher ground in England and Wales, however temperatures in the South West of the UK fell dramatically around lunch time of the 30th of march and snow is falling in some areas in South Wales and [[South West England]].
The Met Office updated its warnings on March 30, the following areas of the UK are in severe weather warnings; [[Wales]], Scotland and Northern Ireland. The Met Office has also issued extreme weather warnings of Severe Blizzards, Severe Drifting Snow & Very Heavy Snowfall in [[Western Northern Ireland]] and [[North East Scotland]] where 40–50 cm of snow is now forecasted to fall with drifts over 5 feet tall. Heavy thunder storms hit parts of [[Hampshire]] <ref>{{youtube|id=bL1hK7cXyJw}}</ref> and temperatures begin to rise in [[Southern England]] and [[Greater London]].
On March 31, 48,000 Northern Irish, 24,000 [[Scotland|Scottish]] and 150 [[Ireland|Irish]] homes are without power as heavy snow falls in both [[Northern Ireland]], parts of [[Staffordshire]], and Scotland's [[Southern Uplands]].<ref name="Girl killed as heavy snow hits UK">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8596056.stm |work=BBC News |title=Girl killed as heavy snow hits UK |date=April 1, 2010 |accessdate=April 6, 2010}}</ref> About 300 people are freed by rescue services when 120 vehicles ventured out during a blizzard in [[County Londonderry]]'s [[Glenshane Pass]].<ref name="Girl killed as heavy snow hits UK"/> Sadly, 17-year-old Natasha Paton, from [[Cleghorn, Lanarkshire|Cleghorn]] in southern [[Lanarkshire]] dies as the coach she was in skids and crashes in the snow on the A73 road, outside [[Wiston, South Lanarkshire|Wiston]], also in southern Lanarkshire.<ref name="Girl killed as heavy snow hits UK"/> She was om a trip to visit [[Alton Towers]], [[Staffordshire]] on a trip from [[Biggar, Lanarkshire|Biggar]] in Lanarkshire, that was organised by [[Lanark Grammar School]] <ref name="Girl killed as heavy snow hits UK"/> The UK [[Met Office]] has issued severe weather warnings for the next day in the following regions:Northern Ireland, Northern England, Wales and Scotland.<ref name="Girl killed as heavy snow hits UK"/>
The storm follows the coldest winter in decades to hit the UK and this is the second most severe storm to hit the UK this year, the most severe was the January 6 snowfall in [[Southern England]] and [[South Wales]], despite lower snow depth of 40 cm the south is less prepared and has a higher population density than [[Northern Ireland]] and [[Scotland]] so caused more chaos and damage to the UK economy. [[First Great Western]] closed both [[Islip railway station]] and [[Bicester Town railway station]] for part of the day due to heavy snow fall on exposed stretches of track. Snow also causes travel disruption for [[bus]]es and cars in [[South Glamorgan]].
Both the [[Rhone]] and the [[Danube]] begin to swell at their upper sections due to heavy rain and snow related melt water on the 31st.

===May 16 – June 1=== {{main|2010 Central European floods}} The 2010 Central European floods were a particularly devastating series of weather events that occurred across several Central European countries during May, June and August 2010. Poland was the worst affected. Austria, the Czech Republic, Germany, Hungary, Slovakia, Serbia and the Ukraine were also affected.

On May 16, in southern Serbia about 300 people were evacuated due to flooding after heavy rainfall in the country. The flooded area was left with no electricity, telephone lines, or running mains water. Two people drowned in a flooded [[Pčinja (river)|Pčinja River]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/5841848-serbia-heavy-floods-claim-two-lives |title=Serbia heavy floods claim two lives |date=May 16, 2010 |accessdate=May 12, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313123206/http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/5841848-serbia-heavy-floods-claim-two-lives |archivedate=March 13, 2012 |df=}}</ref>
On May 17, one person died in the Hungarian town of [[Miskolc]], while two others died in the Serbian town of [[Trgovište]] due to flooding created by heavy rainfall.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/hungary/7731766/Three-die-in-heavy-flooding-in-Hungary-and-Serbia.html |title=Three die in heavy flooding in Hungary and Serbia |work=The Telegraph |date=May 17, 2010}}</ref>
===May 20–26===
====May 20–26: Americas==== Heavy rain began to fall in [[Guatemala City]] on the 24th, causing local rivers to flood.<ref name="news.yahoo.com">{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100529/ap_on_re_la_am_ca/tropical_weather |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100602041316/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100529/ap_on_re_la_am_ca/tropical_weather |archivedate=June 2, 2010 |title=Tropical weather |date=May 29, 2010 |work=Yahoo}}</ref><ref name="usatoday.com">{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/weather/storms/2010-05-29-storm-guatemala_N.htm |title=First tropical storm of season kills 12 in Guatemala |work=USA Today |date=June 1, 2010 |accessdate=May 12, 2012}}</ref> Heavy rain was also reported in parts of Mexico, Honduras,<ref name="news.yahoo.com"/><ref name="usatoday.com"/> and southwestern Brazil.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
As the storm moved inland, torrential rains triggered flash flooding and landslides in parts of Honduras on May 30. At least 45 homes were destroyed and one person was killed in the country.<ref>{{cite news |agency=Associated Press |work=KOKH Fox 25 |date=May 30, 2010 |accessdate=May 30, 2010 |title=Agatha leaves at least 16 dead in Guatemala, Honduras |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q7JHLBiS?url=http://www.wgme.com/template/inews_wire/wires.international/3bdf09b0-www.wgme.com.shtml |url=http://www.wgme.com/template/inews_wire/wires.international/3bdf09b0-www.wgme.com.shtml |archivedate=May 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy}}</ref> On May 31, the presidents of both El Salvador and Honduras declared a state of emergency for their respective countries.<ref>{{cite news |work=Cadena Ser |date=May 31, 2010 |accessdate=May 31, 2010 |title=La tormenta tropical Agatha deja 95 muertos a su paso por Centroamérica |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q8hCaVtk?url=http://www.cadenaser.com/internacional/articulo/tormenta-tropical-agatha-deja-95-muertos-paso-centroamerica/csrcsrpor/20100531csrcsrint_2/Tes |url=http://www.cadenaser.com/internacional/articulo/tormenta-tropical-agatha-deja-95-muertos-paso-centroamerica/csrcsrpor/20100531csrcsrint_2/Tes |language=Spanish |archivedate=May 31, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy}}</ref> Tropical Storm Agatha had picked up speed and strength over the [[Central American]] state of [[Belize]], in the [[Atlantic basin]], on May 31.<ref name="June1 outlook">{{cite web |first1=John |last1=Cangialosi |first2=James |last2=Franklin |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/text/refresh/MIATWOAT+shtml/011733.shtml |title=Atlantic Tropical Weather Outlook |date=June 1, 2010 |work=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=June 1, 2010}}</ref>
====May 20–26: Asia==== The [[2010 Indian heatwave]] was a period of extremely hot weather occurring during the summer of 2010 in India and much of South Asia. Said to be the harshest summer since 1800, the [[heat wave]] killed hundreds of people due to [[heat exhaustion]] and [[food poisoning]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/india/india-heatwave-scorches-the-country-casualties-shoot-up_100373320.html |title=India Heatwave Scorches The Country, Casualties Shoot Up |work=Thaindian |date=June 1, 2010 |accessdate=May 12, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/may/30/india-heatwave-deaths |location=London |work=The Guardian |title=Hundreds die in Indian heatwave |first=Jason |last=Burke |date=May 30, 2010}}</ref><ref name="guardian1">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jun/01/pakistan-record-temperatures-heatwave |location=London |work=The Guardian |title=Temperatures reach record high in Pakistan |first1=John |last1=Vidal |first2=Declan |last2=Walsh |date=June 1, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ecanadanow.com/world/2010/06/01/200-dead-in-india-heatwave/ |title=200 Dead In India Heatwave |work=eCanadaNow |date=June 1, 2010 |accessdate=May 12, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717072522/http://www.ecanadanow.com/world/2010/06/01/200-dead-in-india-heatwave/ |archivedate=July 17, 2010 |df=mdy}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-05-27/india/28314939_1_maximum-temperature-heat-wave-degree-c-mark |work=The Times Of India |title=Relentless heatwave sweeps across hills too |date=May 27, 2010}}</ref>
On May 24, 400 people held a protest in the 1,500-strong village of [[Altit]] over the lack of aid provision,{{clarify |date=May 2012 |reason=For what?}} following a visit to the settlement by Pakistan's Prime Minister. One protestor said he was sheltering in a Gilgit school building and that there were too few doctors in the camp. The only reliable means of transport in the [[disaster zone]] was by [[Army]] [[helicopter]].<ref name="irinnews.org">{{cite news |url=http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?ReportId=89244 |title=Flood alert targets 50,000 at risk |work=IRIN |accessdate=August 16, 2010}}</ref> About 32 villages in the [[Hunza–Nagar District]] were said by the local administration to be flooded.<ref name="irinnews.org"/> The flooding lake was formed after a {{convert|2.5|m|ft|adj=on|sp=us}} deep landslide in January.<ref name="irinnews.org"/>
The hottest temperature ever recorded in Asia was reached in [[Mohenjo-daro]], [[Sindh]], Pakistan at {{convert|53.7|C|F}}, on May 26, and multiple cities in Pakistan saw temperatures above {{convert|43|C|F}}.<ref name="guardian1"/> The previous record for Pakistan, and for all of Asia, was reached at {{convert|52.7|C|F}} in Sindh Province on June 12, 1919.<ref name="MastersAsia">{{cite web |last=Masters |first=Jeff |title=Asia records its hottest temperature in history; Category 4 Phet threatens Oman |url=http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=1498 |work=Weather Underground |publisher=Jeff Masters' WunderBlog |accessdate=July 21, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Vidal |first=John |title=Temperatures reach record high in Pakistan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jun/01/pakistan-record-temperatures-heatwave |accessdate=July 21, 2010 |newspaper=Guardian |date=June 1, 2010 |author2=Declan Walsh |location=London}}</ref> By May 27, after temperatures higher than {{convert|45|C|F}} hit areas across the country, at least 18 people died in Pakistan from the heat.<ref name="News Service">{{cite news |agency=Pakistan News Service |title=Heatwave kills 18 across Pakistan |url=http://paktribune.com/news/index.shtml?227943 |accessdate=July 21, 2010 |newspaper=PakTribune |date=May 27, 2010}}</ref>
====May 20–26: Europe==== [[Warsaw]] faced imminent rain-related flooding as the [[Vistula]] river burst its banks and inundated many nearby villages on May 20.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE64J5GL20100520 |work=Reuters |title=Polish floods threaten Warsaw |date=May 20, 2010}}</ref>
The Vistula river burst its banks on May 21 and flooded nearby towns. Warsaw was put on flood alert. 23,000 people were displaced in the worst Polish floods in 160 years. [[European Union|EU]] officials said Poland would receive 100 million [[euro]]s in aid from the [[European Union solidarity fund]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.euronews.net/2010/05/21/polish-flood-death-toll-rises-to-nine/ |date=May 21, 2010 |title=Polish flood death toll rises to nine |work=euronews}}</ref> The Vistula was at a 160-year high and £2,000,000 worth of damage was done in Poland. Austria, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Poland all witness heavy rainfall,<ref>{{youtube|id=6x4eJtsXmQo}}{{unreliable source?|date=May 2012}}</ref> as rivers begin to swell in Slovenia and eastern Germany.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
On May 23, the floods hit the city of [[Wrocław]] as the [[Ślęza]] river broke a dyke and flooded into the Kozanow neighborhood. The Vistula River reached {{convert|7.8|m|ft|sp=us}} in height and, like the floods in general, was at a level not seen in 60 years.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/05/23/2906917.htm |title=PM says deadly floods are Poland's worst ever |work=Abc.net.au |date=May 23, 2010 |accessdate=August 16, 2010}}</ref>
On May 24, [[levee]]s failed or were tactically dynamited, southern Poland was hopelessly flooded, and the River Oder began to flood Germany.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/10151089.stm |work=BBC News |title=More misery for flood-hit Poland |date=May 24, 2010}}</ref> $2,500,000,000 worth of damage was done in Poland as the river Vistula flooded along its entire length and Poland's death toll reached 15.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/37301511/ns/weather/ |title=Floods drive thousands from homes in Poland |work=MSNBC |date=May 24, 2010 |accessdate=August 16, 2010}}</ref>
By May 25, another £400,000,000 worth of damage was done and 15 Poles were reported dead. Flooding also affected nearby parts of Germany.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.sky.com/home/world-news/article/15638174 |title=Poland Floods, Germany On Flood Alert After Severe Polish Flooding Risks Damage On Border |date=May 25, 2010 |accessdate=May 12, 2012 |work=SKY |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110908071910/http://news.sky.com/home/world-news/article/15638174 |archivedate=September 8, 2011 |df=}}</ref>
Parts of [[Lower Austria]], the [[Poland|Polish]] town of Slubice and the German city of [[Frankfurt an der Order]] started to be flooded from the rivers [[Spree]] and [[Oder]] on May 27 due to heavy rain.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.euronews.net/2010/05/27/high-river-alerts-across-german-polish-border/ |title=High river alerts across German-Polish border |date=May 27, 2010 |accessdate=May 12, 2012 |work=euronews}}</ref> Heavy rain fell across the [[English Midlands]].{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
====May 20–26: Middle East==== A large dust storm swept across both Libya and Egypt on May 26.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://saweatherobserver.blogspot.com/2010/06/dust-storm-over-egypt-and-libya.html |title=Dust storm over Egypt and Libya |date=June 4, 2010 |accessdate=May 12, 2012}}</ref>
===May 27–30=== On May 30, [[Guatemala]]n President [[Alvaro Colom]] declared a ‘state of calamity’ as the first tropical storm of the Eastern Pacific hurricane season, [[Tropical Storm Agatha (2010)|Hurricane Agatha]] flooded about 600 homes and killed 12 people the day after a volcanic eruption. The rain made the [[volcanic ash]] set like [[concrete]] on and around Guatemala City and the city's main airport.<ref name="bloomberg.com2">{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-05-29/tropical-storm-agatha-floods-homes-kills-five-in-guatemala-el-salvador.html |work=Bloomberg |first1=Blake |last1=Schmidt |first2=Dan |last2=Hart |title=Tropical Storm Agatha Floods 600 Homes; 13 Die in Guatemala, El Salvador |date=May 29, 2010}}</ref> A total of thirteen people had already died in [[El Salvador]] the day before. In El Salvador, one person drowned when a river flooded, according to civil protection agency spokesman [[Armando Vividor]]. People living in or traveling to flood zones in the capital and five other cities were to relocate to shelters, according to a statement on the civil protection agency's website.<ref name="bloomberg.com2"/> The [[Miami]]-based [[National Hurricane Centre]] issued an advisory that the storm had strengthened, with maximum sustained winds of {{convert|45|mph|km/h}} or more predicted during the next 48 hours.<ref name="bloomberg.com2"/>
==June==
===June 1–6===
====June 1–6: Americas==== On June 1, the National Hurricane Centre stated that the remnants of Tropical Storm Agatha had only a low chance of regeneration in the western Caribbean Sea.<ref name=autogenerated1b>{{cite web |author=John Cangialosi and James Franklin |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/text/refresh/MIATWOAT+shtml/011733.shtml |title=Atlantic Tropical Weather Outlook |date=June 1, 2010 |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=June 1, 2010}}</ref> By the next day, the thunderstorm activity associated with Agatha in the western Caribbean had dissipated and it was only a bad storm. The storm had severely damaged Guatemala's principal airport with rain induced floods. It also resulted in the death of 1 person in [[Nicaragua]], 152 people killed and 100 left missing in Guatemala (due to landslides), 13 deaths in El Salvador and 16 fatalities in [[Honduras]]. On June 6, the remnants of Tropical Storm Agatha dissipated completely, after hitting Honduras.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
====June 1–6: Asia==== 25 died between June 2 and 4 in a heavy rainstorm in Pakistan's Punjab Province<ref name="surviving-21st-december1"/> and a blizzard hit the Pakistani-held parts of [[Jammu and Kashmir]].<ref name="surviving-21st-december1">{{cite web |url=http://surviving-21st-december-2012.com/snow-storm-asia-pakistan/ |title=Snow Storm – Asia – Pakistan |publisher=surviving-21st-december-2012 |date= |accessdate=May 13, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314221211/http://surviving-21st-december-2012.com/snow-storm-asia-pakistan/ |archivedate=March 14, 2012 |df=}}</ref>
====June 1–6: Europe==== On June 2, police in the Czech Republic warned of vehicles’ [[aquaplaning]] after a man died in a flooded street due to it. In Slovakia, a 38-year-old man died searching for another man who had fallen into a swollen river. 2,000 people were evacuated in the northern Hungarian town of [[Paszto]]. Major flood alerts hit Serbia and [[Bosnia]] as their rivers swelled with floodwater. Government officials in Serbia said the situation was "critical".<ref name="dw-world1">{{cite news |url=http://www.dw.de/dw/article/0,,5643318,00.html |title=Floods in central Europe claim at least two lives |work=Deutsche Welle |date=February 6, 2010 |accessdate=August 16, 2010}}</ref> A Croatian drowned in a flooding [[Istria]]n river.<ref>{{cite web |title=Error 404 |url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,5643318,10.html |accessdate=June 15, 2010}}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> A total of {{convert|250|L/m2|USgal/sqft|sp=us}} of rain fell in [[Zupanja]], Croatia, on June 3. The [[Croatia]]n government sent 5,000 {{convert|1.5|L|USqt|adj=on}} bottles to the Zupanja region, and the Croatian Red Cross launched an emergency appeal. Meanwhile, there was more rain in Croatia and [[Slovenia]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.croatiantimes.com/news/General_News/2010-06-03/11403/East_Croatia_continues_to_fight_with_floods |title=East Croatia continues to fight with floods |work=Croatian Times |date=June 3, 2010 |accessdate=May 12, 2012}}</ref> On June 2, several heavy [[thunderstorms]] also hit the high [[Swiss Alps]], accompanied by heavy snow in some places.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
The Hungarian flood level was critical on June 5.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://article.wn.com/view/2010/06/06/Flood_situation_critical_in_Hungary/ |title=Flood situation critical in Hungary |work=Worldnews |date=June 6, 2010 |accessdate=May 12, 2012}}</ref>
====June 1–6: Middle East==== The {{convert|93|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} [[Cyclone Phet]] hit [[Oman]]'s [[Masirah Island]] after 1,000 Omanis and 50,000 Pakistanis were evacuated on June 4.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-49030320100603 |work=Reuters |title=Cyclone Phet weakens before hitting Omani coast |date=June 3, 2010}}</ref> (''Phet'' ({{lang-th|เพชร}}) is a [[Thai language|Thai]] word meaning [[diamond]].) Cyclone Phet made landfall at [[Thatta District|Thatta]] about {{convert|50|km|mi}} south from [[Karachi]], Pakistan on June 6, 2010 at about 4:30{{nbsp}}pm GMT.<ref>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qBkoSTqw?url=http://pakmet.com.pk/mon%26tc/Tcyclone.pdf |title=Tropical Cyclone "PHET" Made Landfall South of Karachi at 2130 PST |format=PDF |url=http://pakmet.com.pk/mon&tc/Tcyclone.pdf |archivedate=June 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=October 2, 2016}}</ref>
====June 1–6: Oceania==== A waterspout unexpectedly moved onshore as a tornado at [[Lennox Head, New South Wales]], [[Australia]] on June 3. 40–100 houses were damaged, and several people were injured by the tornado.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/waterspout-wrecks-homes-in-nsw-town-as-storm-hits-hard-20100603-x0fy.html |title=Waterspout wrecks homes in NSW town as storm hits hard |first=Paul |last=Tatnell |date=June 3, 2010 |publisher=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=[[Sydney]], [[Australia]]}}</ref>
===June 6–8=== June 6 saw heavy rain hit the sun-scorched UK and Ireland. Heathrow Airport had June 6‘s hottest spot at {{convert|28|C|F}}.<ref name="mirror.co.uk">{{cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/top-stories/2010/06/06/stormy-end-to-the-heatwave-115875-22313316/ |title=Stormy End to the Heatwave |date=June 6, 2010}}</ref>
On June 7, 150 Polish schools were closed, flood hit Slovakia received 25,000,000 Euros ($30,000,000) in EU aid, and river levels in [[Budapest]] reached {{convert|8.2|m|ft|sp=us}}. The death toll included 1 Hungarian, 3 Slovaks, and 25 Poles.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5g3qPG0bGSASDqbk-Fq7I7Tx-8C_g |work=AFP |title=Warsaw braces for flood, Slovakia and Hungary reel |date=June 7, 2010 |accessdate=August 16, 2010}}</ref>
The Polish towns of [[Wilków, Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship|Wilkow]] and [[Winiary, Sandomierz County|Winiary]] flooded. The river level in Warsaw reached {{convert|7.80|m|ft|sp=us}} and a local dam collapsed, flooding part of the city on June 8.<ref>[https://archive.is/20120804004749/http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/327766,flooding-spreads-in-poland-capital-braces-for-high-waters-arrival.html Flooding spreads in Poland, capital braces for high water's arrival]</ref> The Polish city of [[Sandomierz]] was cut off by flooding.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://polishrail.wordpress.com/2010/06/08/floods-poland-holds-its-breath/ |title=Floods – Poland holds its breath |date=June 8, 2010 |accessdate=May 12, 2012}}</ref>
The mayor of [[Janowiec]] appealed for aid and criticized the Polish government's handling of the affair. 42,000 people were affected and more than 12,000 houses were flooded in the province of [[Podkarpackie]]. 20 Poles were confirmed as dead as the Vistula river ran amok in Poland on June 9. The general elections on June 20 were suspended due to the chaos caused by the floods.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.ntdtv.com/ntdtv_en/ns_europe/2010-06-09/895853842825.html |title=Polish Government under Pressure over Floods |work=NTDTV |date=June 9, 2010 |accessdate=August 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722154516/http://english.ntdtv.com/ntdtv_en/ns_europe/2010-06-09/895853842825.html |archivedate=July 22, 2011 |df=}}</ref>
On June 8, a flood alert was issued in [[Belgrade]] as the river Danube was rising by {{convert|1|cm|in}} per hour in the city.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKLDE6531K0._CH_.2420 |work=Reuters |title=Floods threaten Serbian capital |first=Aleksandar |last=Vasovic |date=June 4, 2010}}</ref>
On June 8, heavy thunderstorms hit the British Isles, ending the 6-day-long [[heat wave]].{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
===June 13–17===
====June 13–17: Asia==== About 42 people were killed by heavy monsoon-related landslides, winds and flash floods in the south of [[Bangladesh]] on June 15.<ref name="theaustralian1">{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/breaking-news/bangladesh-landslides-flash-floods-leave-42-dead-thousands-trapped/story-fn3dxity-1225880128909 |title=Bangladesh landslides, flash floods leave 42 dead, thousands trapped |date=June 15, 2010 |accessdate=May 15, 2012 |work=The Australian}}</ref> Some flooding was also reported in India's [[Tamil Nadu]] and [[West Bengal]] provinces.<ref name="theaustralian1"/>
====June 13–17: Europe==== Over June 15 and 16 about {{convert|40|cm|in|abbr=on}} of rain fell in the French [[Côte d'Azur]] region. At least 1,000 people were evacuated and spent the night in empty schools or other temporary shelters, and some 175,000 houses were estimated to have been left without power as rescue teams moved 436 prisoners from a flooded jail in [[Draguignan]]. The rain was worst in [[Roquebrune-sur-Argens]] and [[Frejus]]; it continued into June 17. Both rail and air travel in the region were interrupted, with 300 or so passengers who were traveling on a high-speed train between [[Nice]] and [[Lille]] trapped by floodwater spilling over the tracks near Nice. The railway line between [[Toulon]] and Frejus was closed until the morning of June 17, due to water-induced [[subsidence]] of the track and debris on the line. Fallen trees and landslides also blocked many roads for the next 24 hours. Meteorologists said it was the worst such event in the region since 1827.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10327034 |work=BBC News |title=Deadly floods hit southern France |date=June 16, 2010 |accessdate=May 16, 2012}}</ref> The ultimate death toll was 22.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.videowired.com/video/940737798/ |title=Worst French floods for two centuries |work=The Australian |publisher=VideoWired.com |accessdate=August 16, 2010}}</ref>
===June 21–30===
====June 21–30: Americas==== On June 21, the [[Salvadoran Red Cross Society]] said the El Salvador flood emergency appeal funds were nearly exhausted.<ref>[http://www.ifrc.org/docs/appeals/09/MDRSV00203.pdf MDRSV00203.pdf]. ifrc.org.</ref>
The price of oil rose to $77 per barrel on June 24 as a [[cyclone]] began to form in the south-western Caribbean.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://af.reuters.com/article/energyOilNews/idAFSGE65O02G20100625 |work=Reuters |title=Oil rises towards $77 as Caribbean storm brews |date=June 25, 2010}}</ref>
On June 25, the [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 3]] strength [[Hurricane Darby (2010)|Hurricane Darby]] hit [[Pacific coast of Mexico|Mexico's Pacific coast]] (passing {{convert|395|km|mi|order=flip}} south-west of [[Acapulco]]) with hurricane-force winds reaching up to {{convert|35|km|mi|order=flip}} from the eye.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://wireupdate.com/local/hurricane-darby-becomes-category-three-storm-off-mexicos-southern-coast/ |title=Hurricane Darby becomes category three storm off Mexico's southern coast |date=June 25, 2010 |work=WireUpdate}}</ref>
On June 30, [[Hurricane Alex (2010)|Hurricane Alex]] hit north-eastern Mexico. An area {{convert|35|–|40|mi|km}} north of the town of [[La Pesca]] was hit by winds up to {{convert|105|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} as the storm moved northward.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2010-07-01/news/fl-storm-alex-first-20100626_1_soto-la-marina-hurricane-alex-national-hurricane-center |date=July 1, 2010 |accessdate=May 17, 2012 |title=Hurricane Alex makes landfall in Mexico |work=Sun Sentinel |first=Ken |last=Kaye}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20100630-716843.html |title=Hurricane Alex Makes Landfall In Mexico – NHC |work=Wall Street Journal |date=June 30, 2010 |accessdate=August 16, 2010}}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref>[http://www.einnews.com/mexico/newsfeed-mexico-tropical-cyclones Mexico Tropical Cyclones] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100607073519/http://www.einnews.com/mexico/newsfeed-mexico-tropical-cyclones |date=June 7, 2010 }}</ref>
====June 21–30: Asia==== [[File:Flooding along Ganjiang, Jiangxi, June 2010.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Flooding along the [[Gan River]] in [[Zhangshu]], [[Jiangxi]] on June 21]]
The rain-swollen [[Gan River]] burst its banks and flooded [[Zhangshu]], Jiangxi, [[China]] on June 21.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
June 27 to 29 saw the heaviest rainfall for 300 years in the [[Luolou]] township of the Chinese [[Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region]].<ref name="english.peopledaily.com.cn">{{cite news |url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90783/91300/7049617.html |title=Guangxi township isolated by flood |date=July 2, 2010 |work=People's Daily}}</ref> 6,673 people were affected; the town was cut off, schools were closed, and people traveled by boat.<ref name="english.peopledaily.com.cn"/>
On July 30, [[Malteser International]], the relief service of the [[Order of Malta]], gave disaster relief to about 10,000 in the flood-ravaged [[Swat District]] of Pakistan. The [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] saw at least 400,000 people affected by the floods, which were the most severe ones since 1929. The abnormally heavy rain killed 300 Pakistanis and a [[cholera]] [[epidemic]] was expected{{clarify|date=May 2012|reason=Did it happen?}} in its wake.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900sid/EKIM-87U35D?OpenDocument&rc=3&cc=pak |title=Over 200 killed in torrential rains; 106 dead, 30 injured in KP, thousands homeless |work=Reliefweb |date=July 30, 2010 |accessdate=August 16, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900sid/CJUE-87UHHU?OpenDocument&rc=3&cc=pak |title=Pakistan: More than 550,000 people affected by torrential rainfalls and floods, Malteser International starts medical emergency relief in Swat District |work=Reliefweb |date=July 30, 2010 |accessdate=August 16, 2010}}</ref>
====June 21–30: Europe==== {{Main|2010 Romanian floods}} Heavy rainfall happened in central and north-eastern [[Romania]] between June 22 and June 29.<ref name="hindustantimes.com">{{cite news |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/Europe/Romania-floods-kill-21/Article1-565018.aspx |work=Hindustan Times |title=Romania floods kill 21 |date=June 29, 2010 |accessdate=May 12, 2012 |agency=AFP |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018090717/http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/Europe/Romania-floods-kill-21/Article1-565018.aspx |archivedate=October 18, 2012 |df=}}</ref>
1,870 people were evacuated from 10 villages in [[Suceava county]], as the [[Siret river]] threatened to overflow on the afternoon of June 28.<ref name="hindustantimes.com"/> Some 1,100 sheep were moved to higher ground in the mostly rural region.<ref name="hindustantimes.com"/> Refugees were taken by local monasteries, schools, cultural centers, and relatives.<ref name="hindustantimes.com"/> [[Gheorghe Flutur]], president of Suceava county, said his region was one of the worst hit in the country.<ref name="hindustantimes.com"/> Later that day, the Siret river threatened to break through the [[dike (construction)|dikes]] protecting the town of [[Şendreni]], as locals and [[emergency services]] reinforced the dikes with sandbags by the truck-full to prevent the river from breaking out and flooding the town.<ref name="hindustantimes.com"/>
The north-eastern town of [[Dorohoi]] witnessed six deaths on June 29 as floods rose to just over {{convert|1|m|ft|sigfig=2|sp=us}} in some places. Several roads into Dorohoi remained either washed away or under water.<ref name="hindustantimes.com"/> Ten people were killed by the floods in total.<ref name="nce.co.uk">{{cite news |url=http://www.nce.co.uk/news/water/10-dead-in-romanian-floods/8602367.article |title=10 dead in Romanian floods |work=New Civil Engineer |date=June 29, 2010}} {{subscription required|date=May 2012}}</ref> The railway line to the Ukraine, electricity pylons, bridges, and roads were damaged across northern and eastern Romania.<ref name="nce.co.uk"/>
The Romanian counties of [[Alba County|Alba]], [[Arad County|Arad]], [[Bacău County|Bacău]], [[Botoşani County|Botoşani]], [[Brașov County|Brașov]], [[Cluj County|Cluj]], [[Hunedoara County|Hunedoara]], [[Iaşi County|Iași]], [[Mehedinţi County|Mehedinţi]], [[Neamţ County|Neamţ]], [[Olt County|Olt]], [[Prahova County|Prahova]], [[Sălaj County|Sălaj]], [[Sibiu County|Sibiu]], [[Suceava County|Suceava]], [[Timiş County|Timiş]], [[Tulcea County|Tulcea]], [[Vâlcea County|Vâlcea]], and [[Vrancea County|Vrancea]] were flooded in late June.{{clarify|date=May 2012|reason=This originally said "early July", but that doesn't make sense with the dates of the citations.}} Botoşani, Suceava, and Tulcea counties took the brunt of the damage.<ref name="Bloomberg"/> Also affected was [[Chernivtsi Oblast|Chernivtsi province]] in the neighboring [[Ukraine]].<ref name=Bloomberg2>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-06-30/romania-rain-flooding-leave-20-dead-as-wrecked-houses-force-evacuations.html |title=Romanian, Ukrainian Floods Leave 21 Dead, Force Evacuations From Homes |work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date=June 30, 2010 |accessdate=June 30, 2010 |first1=Irina |last1=Savu |first2=Daryna |last2=Krasnolutska}}</ref><ref name="KyivP1">{{cite news |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/71149/ |title=Chernivtsi region partially flooded after heavy rains |work=[[Kyiv Post]] |date=June 27, 2010 |accessdate=June 29, 2010}}</ref><ref name="KyivP2">{{cite news |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/71330/ |title=Additional police units sent to flood-hit Chernivtsi region to prevent looting |work=[[Kyiv Post]] |date=June 29, 2010 |accessdate=June 29, 2010}}</ref><ref name="KyivP3">{{cite news |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/71510/ |title=Russia to deliver 70 tonnes of humanitarian aid to Ukraine |work=[[Kyiv Post]] |date=June 30, 2010 |accessdate=June 30, 2010}}</ref>
On June 29 and 30, Romanian Prime Minister [[Emil Boc]] toured the devastated regions in the north-east of the country.<ref name="hindustantimes.com"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/10465678.stm |work=BBC News |title=Romania floods kill at least 20 |date=June 30, 2010}}</ref><ref name="uk.reuters.com">{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKLDE65T176._CH_.2420 |title=Floods kill 24, Romania to seek emergency EU aid |work=Reuters |date=June 30, 2010 |accessdate=May 13, 2012 |first=Radu |last=Marinas}}</ref> Romanian Interior Minister [[Vasile Blaga]] told parliament that the losses were equivalent to 0.6% of [[GDP]]. The [[agriculture]] ministry estimated that, of {{convert|2000000|ha|sqmi km2|sigfig=2}} of [[arable land]], {{convert|12000|ha|sqmi km2}} were damaged.<ref name="uk.reuters.com"/> [[Moldova]] and the Ukraine had yet to assess the crisis in their flooded regions.<ref name="uk.reuters.com"/> Russia gave {{convert|70|t|ST LT}} of humanitarian aid to the Ukraine.<ref name="KyivP3"/><ref name="uk.reuters.com"/>
On July 9, the [[European Union]]'s [[ECHO (European Commission)|Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection]] representative, [[Kristalina Georgieva]], let{{clarify|date=May 2012|reason=Would it not have been able to otherwise?}} [[Belgium]] send aid to Romania.<ref name="earthtimes.org">{{cite news |url=http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/news/334108,visits-romania-flood-zone.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130415055931/http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/news/334108,visits-romania-flood-zone.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=April 15, 2013 |title=EU crisis management commissioner visits Romania flood zone |work=Earth Times News |date=July 9, 2010 |accessdate=August 16, 2010 |df=}}</ref> The [[fortnight]]-long floods in Rumania killed 23–24 people, injured 43, made 7,000–18,000 homeless, and caused 60,000,000 Euros (US$76,000,000) of damage.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nce.co.uk/news/water/romanian-death-toll-reaches-24/8602590.article |title=Romanian death toll reaches 24 |date=July 2, 2010 |work=New Civil Engineer}} {{subscription required|date=May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gulfinthemedia.com/index.php?m=gcc_press&id=2258739&cnt=171&lang=en&PHPSESSID= |title=EU crisis management commissioner visits Romania flood zone |work=gulf in the media |agency=SPA |date=July 9, 2010 |accessdate=May 17, 2012}}</ref> Romania is part of the EU‘s [[Civilian Solidarity Mechanism]].<ref name="earthtimes.org"/> One Ukrainian was killed by the floods in the Ukraine's [[Chernivtsi region]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/71590/ |title=One killed, three missing after floods in Chernivtsi region |work=[[Kyiv Post]] |date=July 1, 2010}}</ref>
==July== {{Main|2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat waves}}
===July 2–9===
====July 2–9: Americas==== On July 2, 2010, Hurricane Alex made landfall in [[Monterrey]], [[Mexico]], causing flooding in most of northern Mexico and killing 2 people.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nce.co.uk/news/water/two-killed-as-hurricane-alex-batters-gulf-coast/8602594.article |title=Two killed as Hurricane Alex batters Gulf coast |work=New Civil Engineer |date=July 2, 2010 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}} {{subscription required|date=May 2012}}</ref>
====July 2–9: Asia==== Unusually heavy rain hit [[Phnom Penh]], causing transport chaos. The chief of [[Phnom Penh Municipality]]'s [[sewage system]] department said that several hours of rain had overwhelmed the city's drains and flooded most streets. {{convert|30|–|60|cm|in}} of rain fell on June 2.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90777/90851/7051031.html |title=Cambodia's capital flooded by heavy rain hit |work=People's Daily Online |date=July 2, 2010 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}}</ref>
On July 7, 2010, five people died and eight were missing after torrential rains caused [[flash flood]]s in [[Huangyuan County]], in China's overheating [[Qinghai Province]].<ref name="English People Daily">{{cite news |url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90776/90882/7055980.html |title=Five dead, eight missing in flash floods in northwest China |work=People's Daily Online |date=July 7, 2010 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}}</ref> The rain hit six towns at about 10 pm and lasted for about 40 minutes that night. It triggered floods that cut transport links, phone, power, and water supplies.<ref name="English People Daily"/> Over 80 homes collapsed and 770 were flooded. Disaster relief operations were under way during the heavy flooding, but the county government was still assessing the full losses and financial implications of the heat wave and flash flood.<ref name="English People Daily"/> Rumors that a homeless old man had been crushed to death in a partly collapsed house were denied by rescue workers.<ref name="English People Daily"/>
July 8 saw the highest temperature across the People's Republic of China so far in the summer of 2010, along with heavy rainstorms.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90776/90882/7057909.html |title=Rain set to break heatwave in China: NMC |work=People's Daily Online |accessdate=August 16, 2010 |date=July 8, 2010}}</ref> Local authorities and the National Meteorological Center also issued an orange [[flood alert]] in central and southwest China; the worst floods for 40 years hit these regions.<ref name="english.cri.cn">{{cite news |url=http://english.cri.cn/6909/2010/07/09/167s581821.htm |title=China to Battle Storms Following Heat Wave |work=English.cri.cn |date=July 8, 2010 |accessdate=August 16, 2010}}</ref> Part of the floods in southeastern [[Sichuan province]] was sewage from a failed [[Sewerage|sewer]].<ref name="autogenerated10">{{cite news |date=July 21, 2010 |url=http://www.nce.co.uk/news/international/1000-feared-dead-in-chinese-floods/8603514.article |title=1,000 feared dead in Chinese floods |work=New Civil Engineer |accessdate=August 16, 2010}} {{subscription required|date=May 2012}}</ref>
Heavy rains hit the [[Hubei]] and [[Anhui]] provinces on July 8, and caused a {{convert|1|m|ft|order=flip|adj=on}} deep flood which killed 1 person and made 500,000 homeless.<ref name="english.cri.cn"/> On July 9 over {{convert|27370|ha|sqmi km2}} of farmland were flooded, 242 houses collapsed, and at least 10,157 residents were evacuated in Hubei province according to the [[Civil Affairs Bureau]].<ref name="english.cri.cn"/> Anhui saw 10-year flood and 50-year temperature records, the latter increasing both air-conditioner sales and electricity consumption in [[Beijing]] and nearby cities. Both the [[Golmud river]] and the [[Wenquan reservoir]] overflowed.<ref name="english.cri.cn"/>
July 8 saw the Indian states of [[Haryana]], [[Punjab (India)|Punjab]], and [[Himachal Pradesh]] flooded and arterial highways connecting [[Delhi]] to northern towns cut or directly threatened with flooding.<ref name="timesofindia.indiatimes.com">{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-07-08/india/28283676_1_flash-floods-manali-danger-mark |title=Flash floods leave north India in deep trouble |work=The Times of India |date=July 8, 2010 |accessdate=August 16, 2010}}</ref> [[National Highway 21 (India)|Delhi-Manali National Highway 21]] remained closed for a second day after water from the rain swollen [[Beas river]] flooded in several places near Aut.<ref name="timesofindia.indiatimes.com"/>
A {{convert|160|ft|m|adj=on}} breach opened up in the rain-swollen [[Sutlej Yamuna link canal]] and two army columns{{clarify|date=May 2012|reason=That isn't an Indian Army unit name}} were deployed for rescue and evacuation missions in the disaster zone. The overflowing [[Ghaggar-Hakra River]] also flooded Punjab's [[Patiala district]], killing three people.<ref name="timesofindia.indiatimes.com"/>
====July 2–9: Europe==== As the floods eased in [[Central Europe]] and the [[Balkans]], except for in Romania, temperatures began to climb across Western Europe and the UK between June 30 and July 2.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
On July 2 Brussels saw its hottest day since 1976. France, Germany, and the Spanish resort [[Benidorm]] had record temperatures as part of Europe's July heat wave.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.euronews.net/2010/07/02/heatwave-hits-Europe/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100902185345/http://www.euronews.net/2010/07/02/heatwave-hits-europe/ |archivedate=September 2, 2010 |title=Heatwave Hits Europe |date=July 2, 2010 |work=euronews}}</ref> Several heavy thunderstorms hit the low Swiss Alps, accompanied by heavy [[rain and snow mixed|sleet]] in some places.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
On July 3 a heat wave hit parts of [[Ryazan Oblast|Ryazan province]] and the cities of [[Bucharest]] and Budapest, killing a [[Romanians|Romanian]] man with [[heatstroke]]. Heavy thunderstorms hit the high Swiss Alps, accompanied by heavy snow in some locations.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
===July 10–14===
====July 10–14: Asia==== {{Main|2010 Pakistan floods}} On July 11, heavy floods hit Haryana in India and damaged the [[archaeological site]] of [[Jognakhera]], where ancient copper smelting had been found dating back almost 5,000 years. The [[Indus valley civilization]] site was hit by almost {{convert|10|ft|m}} of water as the Sutlej Yamuna Link Canal overflowed.<ref name="indiatimes1">{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-07-11/india/28284466_1_furnaces-site-floods |title=Indus Valley site ravaged by floods |date=July 11, 2010 |newspaper=The Times of India}}</ref>
====July 10–14: Europe==== A [[thunderstorm]] with heavy rain hit [[Zürich]] and the Swiss-French border on July 10.<ref>{{youtube|id=mVx3XaBC2G0}}{{unreliable source?|date=May 2012}}</ref><ref name="oleole.com">[http://www.oleole.com/blogs/we-all-live-in-a-toblerone-world/posts/mountain-tops-thunderstorms--power-cuts Mountain tops thunderstorms – power cuts]{{unreliable source?|date=May 2012}} {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100816132430/http://www.oleole.com/blogs/we-all-live-in-a-toblerone-world/posts/mountain-tops-thunderstorms--power-cuts |date=August 16, 2010 }}</ref> The storm also threatened to close the [[Avoriaz]] stage of the [[Tour de France]] cycle race.<ref name="oleole.com"/>
On July 11, temperatures skyrocketed in [[Vienna]], [[Berlin]], [[Munich]], [[Amsterdam]], [[Madrid]], [[Lisbon]], Zürich, and Bucharest. More heavy thunderstorms hit the high Swiss Alps, accompanied by heavy snow in some places.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
On July 12, France and Belgium also saw record temperatures.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/0,1518,705963,00.html |title=Heatwave Grips Europe: Germany Swelters Amid Soaring Temperatures |work=Spiegel |date=July 12, 2010 |accessdate=May 14, 2012}}</ref>
[[Alps|Alpine]] and [[North Sea]] thunderstorms swept across south-east and north-west Germany respectively. Heavy rain fall was also reported in parts of the Netherlands, Ireland, [[Normandy]] and the [[English Midlands]] on July 13.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
Thunderstorms hit the English Midlands, [[Oxfordshire]], Ireland, and [[Northern Ireland]]. The heatwave ended in the British Isles and north-west Europe.{{when|date=May 2012}}{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
Heavy storms also hit [[Warsaw]], Vienna and [[Kiev]] between July 14 and July 16.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
====July 10–14: Middle East==== Heavy rain and thunderstorms hit the town of [[Samail]] in Oman's northern coastal mountain range on July 14.<ref>[http://forum.netweather.tv/topic/63341-thunderstorm-july-14-2010-in-mountains-of-oman/ Thunderstorm, July, 14, 2010. In Mountains Of Oman – Netweather Community Forums]. Forum.netweather.tv (August 11, 2010). Retrieved August 16, 2010.{{unreliable source?|date=May 2012}}</ref> On that day, heavy rain also fell in most of [[Iran]]'s [[East Azerbaijan Province|East Azerbaijan]] and [[West Azerbaijan Province|West Azerbaijan]] provinces.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
===July 15–22===
====July 15–22: Americas==== The [[2010 Milwaukee flood]] was a series of two disasters in the [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]] area of the United States; they happened from July 15 to 23, 2010.<ref>{{cite news |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723220808/http://www.fox6now.com/news/witi-100723-sinkhole-pg%2C0%2C2549976.photogallery |url=http://www.fox6now.com/news/witi-100723-sinkhole-pg,0,2549976.photogallery |title=PICTURES: Milwaukee sinkhole swallows up SUV |work=WITI |archivedate=July 23, 2011 |accessdate=May 14, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=}}</ref>{{better source|date=May 2012}}
[[Iowa]], [[Wisconsin]], [[Minnesota]], [[Texas]], [[Kansas]] and [[Nebraska]] had heavy thunderstorms with a bad tornado in [[Northfield, Minnesota]] on July 16.<ref name="accuweather.com">{{cite news |url=http://www.accuweather.com/video/129306689001/an-extreme-week-for-wisconsin-and-minnesota.asp |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100719225707/http://www.accuweather.com/video/129306689001/an-extreme-week-for-wisconsin-and-minnesota.asp |title=An extreme week for Wisconsin and Minnesota |archivedate=July 19, 2010 |date=July 16, 2010 |work=AccuWeather}}</ref> Later in the day all of [[Manitoba]], Nebraska, Kansas, [[Missouri]], [[Tennessee]], [[Mississippi]], Wisconsin, and Minnesota had heavy storms.<ref name="accuweather.com"/> The heat wave was at last dead and blown away by the storms.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
Flash flooding in [[Arizona]] swept a 12-year-old girl to her death on July 20, 2010.<ref>{{cite news |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100730021026/http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3%26stormfile%3Dflagstaffflooding_21_07_2010 |url=http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/storm_watch_stories3&stormfile=flagstaffflooding_21_07_2010 |title=Girl dies in Arizona floods |date=July 21, 2010 |archivedate=July 30, 2010 |work=The Weather Network |deadurl=yes |df=}}</ref>
====July 15–22: Europe==== The [[2010 Var floods]] were the result of heavy rainfall in southern France that caused severe floods in the [[Var (department)|Var]] [[Departments of France|department]] in the evening of July 15, 2010. As well as generalized flooding, there were also flash floods. Meteorologists said the floods were the worst in the region since 1827,<ref name="BBC16">{{cite news |title=Deadly flash floods hit southern France |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/europe/10327034.stm |work=BBC News |date=June 16, 2010}}</ref> with more than {{convert|400|mm|in|abbr=on|order=flip}} of rain falling in less than 24 hours.<ref name=autogenerated2b>{{cite news |title=French flash floods death toll 'expected to rise' |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/europe/10337433.stm |work=BBC News |date=June 17, 2010}}</ref> At least 25 people were killed,<ref name="LeMonde17">{{cite news |title=Var: Le bilan des inondations s'alourdit à 25 morts |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/planete/article/2010/06/17/le-bilan-des-inondations-s-alourdit-a-22-morts_1374337_3244.html#ens_id=1373507 |newspaper=''Le Monde'' |language=French |date=June 17, 2010}}</ref> and 14 people were missing.<ref>{{cite news |title=Inondations: quatorze personnes disparues |url=http://www.varmatin.com/article/actualites/inondations-quatorze-personnes-disparues |newspaper=Var Matin |date=June 17, 2010}}</ref>
Trees and chimney pots fell as {{cvt|84|mph|km/h}} winds hit parts of [[Wales]] and the [[Bristol Channel]] area, between July 15 and 16.<ref name="ukweatherworld.co.uk">[https://archive.is/20110716132222/http://www.ukweatherworld.co.uk/forum/forums/thread-view.asp?tid=37872&posts=4 Viewing a thread – Storm Damage News – July 15, 2010<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name="walesonline.co.uk">{{cite news |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/2010/07/16/storms-batter-parts-of-wales-91466-26866111/ |work=WalesOnline |title=Storms batter parts of Wales |date=July 16, 2010}}</ref> The winds hit [[Cardiff]], [[Porthmadog]], [[Pontcanna Fields]] near Cardiff, coastal [[Pembrokeshire]], southern [[Monmouthshire]], [[Cheltenham]], [[Gloucester]], [[Aberystwyth]], [[Portmeirion]], and [[Prenteg]] as heavy gales passed over [[South Wales]] and the Bristol Channel.<ref name="ukweatherworld.co.uk"/><ref name="walesonline.co.uk"/>
====July 15–22: Asia==== On July 15, the regional representative of the [[American Red Cross]] had praise for the Chinese people, the [[Red Cross Society of China|Chinese Red Cross]], and China‘s [[Ministry of Civil Affairs]] for their efforts in fighting the flood.<ref name="language.globaltimes.cn">{{cite news |url=http://language.globaltimes.cn/bilingual/2010-07/552207.html |title=Chinese floods test country's resources |work=GlobalTimes |date=July 15, 2010 |accessdate=August 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100719194901/http://language.globaltimes.cn/bilingual/2010-07/552207.html |archivedate=July 19, 2010 |df=}}</ref> The [[People's Liberation Army]] (PLA) was praised for sending contingents of soldiers across the country to any location where a disaster had struck.<ref name="language.globaltimes.cn"/>
Both the [[Xinjiang region]] in the northwest and [[Yunnan province]] in the south were affected by flooding. In all, flood waters inundated parts of at least 24 of China's 34 provinces and regions on July 20.<ref name="autogenerated10"/> By July 20, the Yangtze River at the [[Three Gorges Dam]] experienced its highest river discharge in 130 years, and the highest since the dam was built. The dam's walls released {{convert|40000|m3|USgal L}} of water, while {{convert|30000|m3|USgal L}} per second of the river [[Discharge (hydrology)|flow]] was held back in behind the dam, after water levels in the Reservoir had risen {{convert|4|m|ft|sp=us}} overnight.<ref>{{cite news |title=China's Three Gorges dam faces flood test |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-10703890 |accessdate=August 6, 2010 |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=July 20, 2010}}</ref> The reservoir's water levels peaked at {{convert|158.86|m|ft|sp=us}} on the morning of July 23; the alarm level for the reservoir was {{convert|145|m|ft|sp=us}}. All ferry service in the reservoir was halted when the total flow rate exceeded {{convert|45000|m3|USgal L}} per second, although the crest of the flooding passed the dam by July 24.<ref name="Xinhua24">{{cite news |last=Mu |first=Xuequan |title=Flooding temporarily eased at Three Gorges Dam: flood control office |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2010-07/25/c_13413632.htm |accessdate=August 6, 2010 |newspaper=Xinhua |date=July 24, 2010}}</ref> A second peak in the river arrived at the dam on July 28,<ref name="AFPlandslide">{{cite news |title=Landslide in China leaves 21 missing |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jTNGhcdn4__-Z42oY0BlHdwsSPnQ |accessdate=August 6, 2010 |newspaper=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=July 26, 2010}}</ref> when the peak flow from the dam was a record {{convert|56000|m3|USgal L}} per second.<ref name="guardian28">{{cite news |agency=Associated Press |title=China's Three Gorges dam close to limit as heavy rains persist |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jul/28/china-dam-rain-floods |accessdate=August 6, 2010 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=July 28, 2010 |location=London}}</ref>
It was officially revealed on July 21 that more than 701 people were dead, and that 347 were missing due to the severe flooding in China so far; the floods caused the highest death toll since 1998, which saw the highest water levels in 50 years.<ref name="autogenerated10"/> The floods have affected 100 rivers, 117 million people in 27 provinces, and seven cities.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/07/20/china.floods/#fbid=YaotAGgV2l3 |work=CNN |title=More than 700 dead in Chinese floods |date=July 21, 2010}}</ref> {{convert|9000000|ha|sqmi km2}} of farmland and 645,000 houses have been destroyed, and 8,000,000 people have been evacuated (about the population of [[New Jersey]]).<ref name="businessinsider.com">{{cite news |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/stunning-photos-of-chinas-worst-flood-in-a-decade-2010-7 |title=Stunning Photos Of China's Worst Flood In A Decade |work=Businessinsider |date=July 21, 2010 |accessdate=August 16, 2010}}</ref>
The overall damage totaled 142,200,000,000 [[Chinese yuan|Yuan]] or £13,700,000,000.<ref name="autogenerated10"/> The Three Gorges Dam project prevented floods like those in 1998, which killed several thousands. The shipping channels in the Three Gorges Dam were closed, but the dam wall was still holding for the time being.<ref name="businessinsider.com"/>
===July 25–31=== {{Main|2010 Pakistan floods}}
About 70 people were killed and 100,000 left homeless between July 19 and 25 in flash floods in Pakistan's south-western [[Baluchistan]] province.<ref name="Pakistan floods">{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2010/07/20107291546874240.html |title=Scores dead in Pakistan floods |date=July 29, 2010 |work=Al Jazeera}}</ref>
Due to the bad weather, an [[Airblue]] passenger jet crashed into the [[Margalla Hills]] outside [[Islamabad]] killing all 152 passengers on July 28.<ref name="ft.com2">[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/18a17850-9d6d-11df-a37c-00144feab49a.html?ftcamp=rss FT.com / Asia-Pacific – Death toll from Pakistan floods passes 1,100<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{subscription required|date=May 2012}}</ref><ref name="cbsnews.com">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/07/31/world/main6731097.shtml |work=CBS News |title=Pakistan Flood Death Toll Rises Above 800 |date=July 31, 2010}}</ref>
The Pakistan Meteorological Department said that over {{convert|200|mm|in|sp=us}} of rain fell over a 24-hour period over a number of places in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Punjab.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=1572 |title=Wunder Blog |publisher=Weather Underground |date= |accessdate=August 24, 2010}}</ref> A record breaking {{convert|274|mm|in|sp=us}} rain fell in [[Peshawar]] over one 24-hour period;<ref name="pakmet.com.pk">https://web.archive.org/web/20110716143644/http://www.pakmet.com.pk/FFD/index_files/rainfalljuly10.htm</ref> the previous record was {{convert|187|mm|in|sp=us}} of rain in 24 hours, recorded in April 2009.<ref>{{cite web |title=Mean FOR THE PERIOD 1961 - 2009 |url=http://www.pakmet.com.pk/cdpc/Climate/Peshawar_Climate_Data.txt |accessdate=September 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613053333/http://www.pakmet.com.pk/cdpc/Climate/Peshawar_Climate_Data.txt |archivedate=June 13, 2010}}</ref> Many areas of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa saw more than {{convert|200|mm|in|sp=us}} of rain over July 28 and 29, breaking a 35-year-old record. Heavy rainfall was reported all over the [[Hindu Kush]] mountains. 80 died in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, mostly in the [[Swat Valley]].<ref name="Pakistan floods"/>
A unnamed river flooded the town of [[Behrain]], destroyed a [[hotel]], and caused heavy damage.<ref name="Pakistan floods"/>
A recently built part of a dam in the [[Charsadda District, Pakistan|Charsadda District]] collapsed; the ensuing wave killed two people and destroyed all the local farms.<ref name="Pakistan floods"/>
On July 31, the [[information minister]] of Pakistan's northwestern [[Khyber-Pakhtoonkhwa]] province, [[Mian Iftikhar Hussain]], said the latest deaths were in this region. Eight hundred died and thousands had [[diarrhea]], fever and other waterbourne illnesses. About 45 bridges were destroyed in the worst floods since 1928; this severely hampered rescuers, who lacked helicopters.<ref name="cbsnews.com"/>
On July 31, Peshawar in Pakistan was cut off and Pakistani-held parts of [[Kashmir]] were also flooded, while the abnormally strong [[monsoon]] killed 65 people in mountainous areas across the border in Afghanistan.<ref name="over 900 dead">{{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5g0PhnTb4o3duUzEmhpSNiZ8WZvWA |title=Over 900 dead as floods sweep Asia |first=Lehaz |last=Ali |date=July 31, 2010}}</ref> The EU pledged to give €30,000,000 to Pakistan in aid supplies.<ref name="over 900 dead"/>{{clarify|date=May 2012|reason=Did they?}} 1600 were confirmed dead in Pakistan by the end of August and 60 were dead in Afghanistan by July 31. All 300,000 people in [[Peshwar]] were cut off by the flood waters, but helicopters were still able to land there, according to a Khyber-Pakhtoonkhwa provincial official (Mian Iftikhar Hussain).<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-10826105 |work=BBC News |title=Pakistan floods 'kill 800' people and affect a million |date=August 1, 2010}}</ref> It remained so on August 1, 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/MCOI-87XAQZ?OpenDocument |work=ReliefWeb |title=Pakistan: Floods Emergency Humanitarian Action, Situation Report 2 |date=August 1, 2010}}</ref>
==August==
===August 1–2===
====August 1–2: Asia==== On August 1 floods occurred in south-east Afghanistan and continued in the [[Indus Valley]]. 1,100–1,400 Pakistani people had been killed and 27,000–30,000 were trapped on high ground, clinging to rooftops and trees. India also suffered substantial dislocations of its road network as rescue workers used boats and [[helicopter]]s in both nations.<ref name="ft.com"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-08/01/c_13425288.htm |title=Floods kill 1,400, maroon 30,000 in Pakistan |date=August 1, 2010 |work=Xinhua |access-date=August 5, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100804225917/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-08/01/c_13425288.htm |archive-date=August 4, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>http://www.newsopi.com/world/pakistan-floods-2010–27000-stranded/3404/</ref><ref name="mirror1">{{cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/top-stories/2010/08/03/pakistan-floods-cholera-fears-as-aid-crews-struggle-with-health-crisis-115875-22460131/ |title=Pakistan floods: Cholera fears as aid crews struggle with health crisis |work=mirror.co.uk |date=August 3, 2010}}</ref><ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-10834414 |work=BBC News |title='2.5m people affected' by Pakistan floods officials say |date=August 2, 2010}}</ref> There were 900 cases of water-carried illness in Pakistan; the town of [[Nowshera, Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa|Nowshera]] was flooded.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.torontosun.com/news/world/2010/08/03/14909261.html |title=Death toll in Pakistan floods exceeds 1,400 |work=Toronto Sun |date=August 3, 2010}}</ref>
The rain continued to fall on parts of Pakistan, [[Afghanistan]], and Iranian Baluchistan, and snow blanketed the [[Pamir Mountains]] and [[Ladakh]] on August 2. About 2,500,000 Pakistanis were now homeless according to the [[International Red Cross]] and Mian Iftikhar Hussain said there might be a cholera epidemic in his Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.<ref name="mirror1"/><ref name="bbc.co.uk"/>
====August 1–2: Europe==== {{Main|2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat wave}} Some 4,000 soldiers were called in to help fight both the 6 rumoured and several known fires in the [[Moscow Oblast]].<ref name="rferl1">{{cite news |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Russian_Patriarch_Prays_For_Rain_As_Fires_Spread/2115547.html |title=Russian Patriarch Prays For Rain As Fires Spread |work=Radio Free Europe |publisher=Radio Liberty |date=August 1, 2010 |accessdate=August 16, 2010}}</ref> Over 5,000 people were evacuated from their homes and [[Vladimir Putin]] organised an emergency meeting for August 2 with the governors of the various regions in the [[Central Federal District|Central]] and [[Southern Federal District|Southern]] Federal Districts devastated by the fires. The grain harvest in the disaster zone was destroyed.<ref name="rferl1"/>
===August 6–11===
====August 6–11: Americas==== On August 11, the U.S. [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] (FEMA) issued a warning that about {{frac|1|3}} of America's 80,000 dams and levees had a "high" or "significant" hazard to life and property if a catastrophic structural failure occurred.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fema.gov/hazard/damfailure/index.shtm |title=Dam Failure |publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] |date=November 9, 2011 |accessdate=May 14, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120513212203/http://www.fema.gov/hazard/damfailure/index.shtm |archivedate=May 13, 2012 |df=}}</ref>
====August 6–11: Asia==== August 7 in China had 700 people known to have been killed and more than 1,000 people still missing and presumed dead as [[landslides]] demolished hundreds of buildings, including several seven stories high buildings in the remote [[Zhouqu county]] of [[Gansu province]] after several days of heavy rain in the county.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/7938784/Chinas-deadly-landslide-not-an-accident.html |location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph |first=Peter |last=Foster |title=China's deadly landslide 'not an accident' |date=August 11, 2010}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated2C">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-10922991 |work=BBC News |title=China landslide: More than 700 people confirmed dead |date=August 10, 2010}}</ref>
The major landslides were triggered by torrential rains and covered an area of {{convert|5|km|mi|sp=us}} by {{convert|500|m|ft|sp=us}}. 45,000 people in Zhouqu county were evacuated as 7,000 soldiers, fire-fighters and medical staff deployed to tackle the disaster.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/><ref name="autogenerated2C"/> The worst floods for a decade killed over 2,100 and millions more were displaced nationwide.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/><ref name="autogenerated2C"/>
A report compiled by [[Lanzhou University]] in 2006 had warned that the felling of the forests around Zhouqu for coal mining and agriculture would cause heavy [[soil erosion]] and destabilize hillsides.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/><ref name="autogenerated2C"/> The construction of a major highway and more than 40 hydroelectric dam and recovery systems in the steep valleys acted to further destabilize the local [[geology]], according to leading Chinese geologist [[Fan Xiao]].<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/><ref name="autogenerated2C"/>
The rain stopped on August 10 and the situation became less chaotic as the army and fire-fighters continued to look for survivors.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/><ref name="autogenerated2C"/>
August 10 saw China's state-run [[Xinhua]] news agency report that the authorities sent nearly 3,000 soldiers and about 100 medical experts to help in search and rescue effort in the [[Gannan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture|Gannan]] and [[Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture|Tibetan]] Autonomous Prefectures in [[Gansu]] province after record floods hit the province. Reports said Zhouqu county had at least 337 dead as rescuers searched for up to 1,148 others who were still missing.<ref name="english.aljazeera.net">{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia-pacific/2010/08/2010881446366388.html |title=China landslide death toll soars |work=Al Jazeera |date=August 10, 2010}}</ref> Landslides up to five stories deep buried three villages, destroyed roads and bridges, disrupted [[mobile telecommunications]] equipment, and cut phone lines, water, and [[electricity]] supplies in parts of the region.<ref name="english.aljazeera.net"/>
The [[Government of the People's Republic of China|Chinese government]] sent experts by helicopter to survey the flooding in devastated villages, and examine how to blast open the remaining flood-induced blockages at the end of the valley, according to Chinese state television. In total, about 875,000 homes were destroyed, 9,610,000 million people were evacuated, {{convert|22,000,000|acre|km2 sqmi}} of crops were destroyed, and tens of billions of dollars in damage were caused by the floods in 28 provinces and regions.<ref name="english.aljazeera.net"/>
The storms in north-east [[Jilin]] province also killed several people and left more than 100 people missing; heavy snowfall was reported in the [[Himalayas]].<ref name="english.aljazeera.net"/>
====August 6–11: Europe==== August 8 had heavy rainfalls in southwest [[Kosovo]], killing an elderly man, who fell into a swollen river on the [[Albania]]/Kosovo border.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
===August 13–29===
====August 13–29: Africa==== {{Main|2010 Nigerien floods}} On August 20 the worst floods for 80 years hit Africa's [[Sahara Desert]] region. The [[UN]] warned that [[Niger]], [[Chad]], [[Burkina Faso]], [[Cameroon]] and northern [[Nigeria]] were also in the grip of the worst regional [[food crisis]] since 2006. In the [[Sudanian Savanna]] city of [[Kano]], Nigeria, over 2,000 families were displaced by floods, and in the nearby [[Jigawa]] region, an entire village was evacuated due to heavy flooding. A [[Mauritania]]n child was swept away in a flood that damaged bridges and many homes in the mountain town of [[El Aioun, Mauritania|Aioun]]. Heavy flooding happened around parts of [[Lake Chad]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=129316900 |title=In Grip Of Drought, Floods, Niger Faces Hunger Crisis |work=Morning Edition |publisher=[[NPR]] |first=Ofeibea |last=Quist-Arcton |date=August 20, 2010 |accessdate=May 14, 2012}}</ref>
====August 13–29: Europe==== After weeks without rain, heavy downpours soaked Moscow and nearby areas, bringing further relief for the extended heat wave. However, in [[Sarov]] (about {{convert|480|km|mi}} east of Moscow) a new fire started near the country's top nuclear research center. Earlier in August, radioactive and explosive materials were moved out of the facility due to the threat of forest fires; however, they were later returned when the threat lessened.<ref>{{cite news |first=Vladimir |last=Isachenkov |work=Associated Press |date=August 13, 2010 |accessdate=August 13, 2010 |title=Rain refreshes Moscow, but wildfires still burning |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rxQNQbrN?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iX-16FttPkCulMdckFjFJyOJCXlAD9HIM7A01 |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iX-16FttPkCulMdckFjFJyOJCXlAD9HIM7A01 |archivedate=August 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy}}</ref> Over 3,400 fire-fighters battled the forest blaze, assisted by a special fire-fighting train.<ref>{{cite news |agency=AFP |work=The Standard |date=August 13, 2010 |accessdate=August 13, 2010 |title=Fires stoke nuclear fears |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rxQYexB8?url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?we_cat=6&art_id=101687&sid=29245399&con_type=1&d_str=20100813&fc=7 |url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?we_cat=6&art_id=101687&sid=29245399&con_type=1&d_str=20100813&fc=7 |archivedate=August 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=}}</ref> The front end of the forest [[peat]] fire-fighting came near the town of [[Roshal (town)|Roshal]] (in the [[Shatursky District|Shatursky district]]) at one point on August 13.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
Heavy rain and thunder storms hit the [[British Isles]] between August 13 and 22, leading to heavy flooding in parts of [[Sussex]], Oxfordshire and [[Buckinghamshire]]. The low cloud and rain led to the closure of the [[Bournemouth Air Festival]] on August 21 and 22.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-dorset-11048908 |work=BBC News |title=Low cloud affects Bournemouth air festival displays |date=August 21, 2010}}</ref> The morning of August 23 saw heavy storms hit Pembrokeshire, the English Midlands and [[Argyll]].<ref name="weatheronline.co.uk">{{cite news |url=http://www.weatheronline.co.uk/cgi-app/reports?ARCHIV=0&LANG=en&JJ=2010&MM=08&TT=23&MENU=211&FILE=scratchbox_1482&DAY=234 |title=ScratchBox |work=WeatherOnline |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=May 14, 2012}}</ref> Some flooding was reported in Oxfordshire and Pembrokeshire. As the day went on the storms lined up on the east coast between [[The Wash]] and [[Aberdeen]], with isolated storms in south-west [[Gloucestershire]], Oxfordshire, south [[Cambridgeshire]], south-west [[Yorkshire]], [[Leicestershire]], and [[Moray]].<ref name="weatheronline.co.uk"/>
==September==
===September 1–7=== [[File:West African floods of 2010.png|thumb|right|200px|This map shows the nations hit by the 2010 West African floods; the worst hit are colored blue.]]
====September 1–7: Africa==== {{Main|2010 Nigerien floods }}
On September 1, floods hit the [[Niger River]]. Flooded ruins were all that was left of three districts of the West African country's capital [[Niamey]] ([[Zarmagandaye]], [[Lamorde]] and [[Karadje]]) It was the worst flooding by the Niger recorded since 1929.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.terradaily.com/reports/Niger_floods_bring_disaster_on_top_of_food_crisis_999.html |title=Niger floods bring disaster on top of food crisis |work=TerraDaily |accessdate=November 19, 2010 |date=September 1, 2010 |agency=AFP}}</ref>
====September 1–7: Americas==== September 4 saw a landslide killing 12 people by hitting a bus, as record amounts of rain started falling in parts of [[Guatemala]] and south-eastern [[Mexico]]. Thousands were evacuated from the [[Mexican Gulf]] coastline by the state of [[Tabasco]], as the flooding continued to grow.<ref name="euronews2">{{cite web |url=http://www.euronews.net/2010/09/05/scores-buried-by-guatemala-landslide/ |publisher=Euronews |title=Scores buried by Guatemala landslide |date=September 5, 2010}}</ref>
September 5 saw up to 100 people trapped in a bus by a landslide as torrential rains continued to swamp parts of Guatemala. Most were rescued, but 18 people were killed in the incident.<ref name="euronews2"/>
On September 6, the region's first major [[tropical storm]] of the year killed at least 145 people in Guatemala, with at least 53 missing and thousands homeless as emergency crews struggled to reach isolated communities. [[Tropical Storm Agatha (2010)|Tropical Storm Agatha]] washed away hundreds of roads and collapsed many bridges in the country.<ref name="msnbc.msn.com">{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/37418183/ns/weather/ |title=Central America floods, mudslides kill 142 |work=MSNBC |date=September 6, 2010 |agency=AP |accessdate=May 17, 2012}}</ref> The [[Chimaltenango]] [[departments of Guatemala|department's]] governor, [[Erick de Leon]], said that the landslides buried dozens of small rural [[Amerindian]] communities and killed at least 60 around the local village of [[Santa Apolonia, Chimaltenango|Santa Apolonia]] alone. Local volunteers worked desperately to recover the bodies of two brothers, aged four and eight, who were buried by a landslide in the village of [[Parajbei]].<ref name="msnbc.msn.com"/>
September 6 also saw an overnight landslide (caused by a flood) burying around 100 people who were trying to rescue victims of the previous bus trapped by a landslide along the [[Inter-American Highway]] in the [[Guatemalan Highlands]]. 23 people were killed in the incident near the town of [[Santa Maria Ixtaguacan]], and 12 had died in the original landslide. The floods were estimated by the government to have killed 45 people on the highway so far, with 38 dying over the last two days of heavy rain and landslides far.<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/americas/2010/09/20109504110783907.html |date=September 6, 2010 |title=Guatemala landslides bury hundreds |work=Al Jazeera}}</ref> President [[Alvaro Colom]] declared a nationwide [[state of emergency]] and urged that citizens to stay off the nation's highways due to the likelihood of more landslides. The week-long heavy rain and floods affected some 40,000 people in the country and caused $350–500 million in damage. He also warned that 24,000 more people were at risk and the government was running out of funds.<ref name="aljazeera1"/>
Thousands more fled their homes in [[Honduras]] after [[mudslides]] and [[landslip]]s killed 15 on September 6.
