State officials warned people to stay away from any swollen waterways as the rain-swollen [[reservoir]]s behind two dams near the capital of [[Tegucigalpa]] overflowed the dam walls' ramparts and spilled into a nearby river.<ref name="msnbc.msn.com"/>
Meanwhile, a [[weather forecast]] of yet more rain was issued{{clarify|date=May 2012|reason=Was it accurate?}} across [[Central America]]; it prompted officials in Mexico to take precautions against rain induced landslides. Heavy flooding made thousands homeless in the southern Mexican states of [[Veracruz]], Tabasco, [[Chiapas]] and [[Oaxaca]]. Mexican president [[Felipe Calderón]] pledged to send aid to the devastated regions on his [[Twitter|Twitter page]]. Mexico's national power company opened floodgates on some [[hydroelectric]] dams in the region, worsening the flooding in some low-lying areas but causing no deaths and avoiding a catastrophic [[dam burst]] situation.<ref name="aljazeera1"/>
====September 1–7: Asia==== The Pakistan government said on September 2 that 1,500 had died across Pakistan so far. Basera (near [[Muzaffargarh]] in [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab province]]), [[Jatti]] (near [[Thatta]] in Sindh province, Pakistan), and [[Larkana]] (in [[Sindh province]]) were still in chaos and choked with refugees on September 2. The United Nations warned that up to 3,5000,000 children were at risk from water-borne diseases like [[cholera]] in the disaster areas and [[refugee camp]]s.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/southasia/features/article_1582354.php/Pakistan-Flood-Pictures-Sept-4th |title=Pakistan Flood Pictures Sept 4th |work=Monsters and Critics |date=September 4, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100907032854/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/southasia/features/article_1582354.php/Pakistan-Flood-Pictures-Sept-4th |archivedate=September 7, 2010 |df=}}</ref>
The [[Oxford]] mosque's Pakistan flood charitable fund reached £30,000 on September 4, 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/news/yourtown/oxford/8372158.Oxford_mosques____flood_fund_hits___30k |title=Oxford mosques’ flood fund hits £30k |work=Oxford Mail}}</ref>
On September 5 floods hit the squalid refugee camps in [[Azakhel]], miles from [[Peshawar]], [[Pakistan]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/sep/05/pakistan-floods-photograph-children |title=Behind the photograph: the human face of Pakistan's deadly flood |work=The Guardian |date=September 5, 2010 |location=London |first=Rania |last=Abouzeid}}</ref>
On September 4 storms swept into the [[prefecture-level city]] of [[Luoyang]] in [[China]]'s [[Henan province]] at 7 am. A total of 15 villages were hit by gales, hail, flood and heavy rain. Several small boats were sunk in a river running through a local scenic spot in Luoyang. One person was reported dead, and electricity poles and telecommunication links were cut down in some villages as well as three bridges destroyed, farm crops destroyed, and several roads blocked, causing about 900,000,000 [[Chinese yuan|Yuan]] or $132,000,000 in material losses.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/photo/2010-09/05/content_11258202.htm |title=Storm hits central China, one dead |date=September 5, 2010 |work=ChinaDaily}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.sina.com/china/p/2010/0905/337873.html |title=Storm hits central China, one dead |work=SINA |date=September 5, 2010}}</ref>
====September 1–7: Europe==== A second day of heavy rain hit the UK on September 6. August 2010 was the coolest since 1993, with the average maximum temperatures {{convert|1|C|F}} below normal. The rainfall was much above average in both south-east England and Wales, and the third-wettest August on record had happened in East Anglia; over twice the average August rainfall occurred in 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/sep/06/severe-weather-warnings-west-uk |date=September 6, 2010 |title=Severe weather warnings in west as UK braces for deluge |work=The Guardian |location=London |first=Maev |last=Kennedy}}</ref>
====September 1–7: Oceania==== The [[2010 Victorian floods]] were a widespread series of flood events across the Australian state of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] from September 2 to 7. Heavy rainstorms hit New Zealand's South Island on September 2; the same rain system then hit Victoria in Australia.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} Flooding followed heavy rain across south-eastern Australia and caused the inundation of about 250 homes, hundreds of evacuations, and millions of dollars of damage.<ref name="Army to evacuate"/><ref name="Floods, landslides"/> [[Weather warnings]] were initially issued for Victoria on Thursday, September 2 and rain began to fall on that Friday, continuing through the weekend to Tuesday, September 7. Heavy rain fell in most regions of the state, particularly higher altitudes in the state's west and north-east, flooding the upper reaches of many of Victoria's major rivers. A state of emergency was declared with [[State Emergency Service]] crews arriving from Queensland, South Australia, and Tasmania.<ref name="rbfp">{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/victoria/regions-brace-for-flooding-peak-20100906-14y0i.html |title=Regions brace for flooding peak |first1=David |last1=Rood |first2=Paul |last2=Millar |accessdate=September 8, 2010 |date=September 7, 2010 |work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |publisher=Fairfax Media}}</ref> In [[Skipton, Victoria|Skipton]] in the state's [[Western District, Victoria|Western District]], 20 properties were put on evacuation alert, while in the [[Central Highlands (Victoria)|Central Highlands]] 120 people sought refuge in the town hall at [[Creswick, Victoria|Creswick]] and 30 people were evacuated from a caravan park in [[Clunes, Victoria|Clunes]].<ref name="Army to evacuate">{{cite news |title=Army to evacuate Victorian flood victims |date=September 5, 2010 |work=ABC News |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/09/05/3002955.htm?section=justin |accessdate=September 6, 2010}}</ref><ref name="Floods, landslides">{{cite news |first1=Gary |last1=Tippet |first2=Maris |last2=Beck |first3=Mark |last3=Russell |first4=Natalie |last4=Craig |title=Floods, landslides, chaos across state |date=September 5, 2010 |work=Sydney Morning Herald |url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/floods-landslides-chaos-across-state-20100904-14vd5.html |accessdate=September 6, 2010}}</ref> In northern Victoria, 150 extra police and 50 military personnel were deployed to assist with evacuations and [[sandbag]]ging.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
===September 8–23=== [[Image:Igor sept 21 2010 1445Z.jpg|thumb|left|alt=a|The [[Eye (cyclone)|eyewall]] of [[Hurricane Igor]] east of [[Cape Race|Cape Race, Newfoundland]]]] {{Main|Hurricane Igor}}
Although Hurricane Igor was several hundred miles from the [[Leeward Islands]] on September 9, large swells produced by Igor swept two people out to sea in the [[U.S. Virgin Islands]] and [[Puerto Rico]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Jason |last=Bronis |work=Associated Press |date=September 19, 2010 |accessdate=September 19, 2010 |title=Big waves pound Bermuda as Hurricane Igor nears |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sra5C6O2?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gVWjsPEiqe1tEu2mhBIRaxxGi8owD9IB2L3O0 |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gVWjsPEiqe1tEu2mhBIRaxxGi8owD9IB2L3O0 |archivedate=September 19, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy}}</ref>
Since the storms started on September 9, 144 people were killed and 13,000 affected people were moved to temporary relief shelters. Five of El Salvador's fourteen [[Departments of El Salvador|departments]] were still seeing heavy rainfall. More than 20 homes were destroyed, 24 bridges and 1,600 houses were damaged, as the town of San Vicente ({{convert|48|km|mi|sp=us}} east of [[San Salvador]]) was buried under landslides on November 11, killing several people.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T57cP2FFJoE |title=Raw Video: Storm Pounds El Salvador, Kills 100+ |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=May 12, 2012}}{{unreliable source?|date=May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/El-Salvador-flood-toll-rises-to-144/Article1-475111.aspx |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120905114444/http://www.hindustantimes.com/El-Salvador-flood-toll-rises-to-144/Article1-475111.aspx |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 5, 2012 |title=El Salvador flood toll rises to 144 |work=Hindustan Times |date=November 11, 2009 |accessdate=May 12, 2012}}</ref>
Mexico experienced its worst rainy season on record starting beginning on September 10. Mexico's President Felipe Calderón said that 900,000 people were affected in the latest tropical storms. It was the worst such event since [[Hurricane Alex (2010)|Hurricane Alex]] killed 22 and left 40,000 homeless in July 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.theage.com.au/breaking-news-world/mexico-has-worst-ever-rainy-season-20100910-153iw.html |location=Melbourne |work=The Age |title=Mexico has 'worst ever' rainy season}}</ref>
September 13, 2010 saw [[2010 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Julia|Tropical Storm Julia]] hit the [[Cape Verde Islands]] with winds at {{convert|65|km/h|mph|sp=us}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.voanews.com/breaking-news/2010/09/13/page/10/ |title=Indonesian President Orders Arrest of Assailants Who Attacked Christians |deadurl=yes |website=blogs.voanews.com |archivedate=July 22, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722165422/http://blogs.voanews.com/breaking-news/2010/09/13/page/10/ |accessdate=October 2, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Error 404 |url=http://voanews.com/breaking-news/2010/09/13/page/10/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130209050159/http://voanews.com/breaking-news/2010/09/13/page/10/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 9, 2013 |accessdate=January 6, 2015 |df=}}</ref>
===September 14–18===
====September 14–18: Asia==== A record cloudburst hit northern India on September 18 and 19, causing deadly flooding.<ref name="oneindia1">{{cite news |url=http://news.oneindia.in/2010/09/20/uttarakhand-flooded-death-toll-reaches-to-63.html |title=Flood in Uttarakhand; Death Toll 63; Cloudburst, Heavy Rain, Landslides |work=Oneindia News |date=September 20, 2010}}</ref>
====September 14–18: Europe==== The [[2010 Slovenia floods|2010 Slovenian floods]] on the weekend of September 17–19 were caused by heavy rains in [[Slovenia]], resulting in one of the worst floods in the country's history. Among the regions affected were the capital [[Ljubljana]], the [[Central Sava Valley]], [[Laško]], the [[Slovenian Littoral]] and the [[Lower Carniola]] region.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://delo.si/clanek/121962 |title=Vodna ujma ohromila dobršen del Slovenije |publisher=Delo.si |date=August 29, 2010 |accessdate=September 20, 2010 |language=Slovenian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |agency=AP |url=http://www.etaiwannews.com/etn/news_content.php?id=1379022&lang=eng_news |title=Torrential rain triggers floods in Slovenia |work=Taiwan News Online |publisher=Etaiwannews.com |date=September 18, 2010 |accessdate=September 20, 2010}}</ref> Initial damage was estimated to reach €15 million.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.rtvslo.si/slovenija/po-prvih-ocenah-v-poplavah-za-vec-kot-10-milijonov-evrov-skode/239645 |title=Pahor napoveduje sanacijo, Janković pa ugotavljanje odgovornosti :: Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC |work=RTV Slovenija |date= |accessdate=September 20, 2010 |language=Slovenian}}</ref> Three people were killed.<ref name="bilanca">{{cite news |url=http://www.rtvslo.si/crna-kronika/moski-iz-poplavljenega-avtomobila-umrl-v-sentjurju-nasli-utopljenca/239688 |title=Bilanca poplav: dva mrtva, eden pogrešan |work=RTV Slovenija |date=September 20, 2010 |accessdate=September 20, 2010 |language=Slovenian}}</ref><ref name="delo.si">{{cite web |url=http://www.delo.si/clanek/122407 |title=Našli tretjo smrtno žrtev poplav |publisher=Delo.si |date=September 22, 2010 |accessdate=September 22, 2010 |language=Slovenian}}</ref>
On September 17, north-east England's [[firefighter]]s, [[medics]] and [[emergency]] [[rescue]] teams did flood and [[rainstorm]] related [[training exercise]]s at [[Hurworth Burn Reservoir]], near [[Middleton St George]] in [[County Durham]], as well as at [[Rothbury]] and [[Otterburn, Northumberland|Otterburn]] in [[Northumberland]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-11340849 |work=BBC News |title=Fire services in the North East test flood response |accessdate=May 15, 2012 |date=September 17, 2010}}</ref>
Three Spaniards died as heavy rains hit southern Spain on September 17. A man died when a wall collapsed in [[Bujalance]] in eastern [[Córdoba (Spanish province)|Córdoba]] province, while a man and a woman died in [[Aguilar de la Frontera]] in the south of the province. Storm warnings were announced by the national weather authority later in the day.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.expatica.com/es/news/spanish-news/three-dead-in-spanish-storm_90223.html |title=Three dead in Spanish storm |work=Expatica |date=September 17, 2010 |accessdate=May 12, 2012}}</ref>
====September 14–18: Oceania==== Heavy rainstorm and [[snowstorm]]s hit [[Invercargill]], New Zealand on September 16 and 17.<ref name="yahoo2">{{cite news |url=http://nz.news.yahoo.com/a/-/top-stories/7969356/weather-bomb-cuts-power-and-closes-roads/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100919192150/http://nz.news.yahoo.com/a/-/top-stories/7969356/weather-bomb-cuts-power-and-closes-roads/ |title=Weather bomb cuts power and closes roads |work=Yahoo!Xtra News |agency=NZPA |archivedate=September 19, 2010 |date=September 18, 2010 |accessdate=May 15, 2012}}</ref><ref name="tvnz.co.nz">{{cite news |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100921045111/http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/weather-bomb-affecting-power-roads-3784819 |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/weather-bomb-affecting-power-roads-3784819 |title=Weather bomb cuts power, closes roads across the country |work=TVNZ |agency=NZPA/ONE News |date=September 18, 2010 |accessdate=May 15, 2012 |archivedate=September 21, 2010}}</ref>
On September 18, heavy [[flooding]] closed a {{convert|100|m|ft|adj=on|sp=us}} stretch covered in water up to {{convert|1.5|m|ft}} deep on and off [[New Zealand State Highway 1|State Highway 1]] north of [[Bulls, New Zealand|Bulls]] as high winds and rain created major disturbances around the country. [[State Highway 3]] was entirely closed and there were also landslips on [[New Zealand State Highway 4|State Highway 4]] at the [[Manawatu Gorge]]. The [[NZ Transport Agency]] said State Highway 1 between [[Woodlands, New Zealand|Woodlands]] and [[Edendale, New Zealand|Edendale]] in Southland had reopened after the ending of heavy snowfalls. Similar weather incidents and some minor car crashes closed parts of [[New Zealand State Highway 99|State Highway 99]]. Heavy floods under railway overbridge closed the highway near [[Marton, New Zealand|Marton]], forcing a local diversion.<ref name="yahoo2"/><ref name="tvnz.co.nz"/>
[[Powerco]] restored supply to around 28,000 customers as a severe wind and rain storm continued to pound the [[North Island]]. The storm had caused [[power cut]]s to around 45,000 customers through the middle of the North Island; the worst affected areas were [[Thames]], [[Coromandel, New Zealand|Coromandel]], [[Thames-Coromandel]], [[Tirau]] and [[Putaruru]], parts of the western [[Bay of Plenty]], parts of [[Wanganui]], [[Wairarapa]], and [[Manawatu]], [[Hauraki-Piako]], and parts of [[Taranaki]].<ref name="yahoo2"/><ref name="tvnz.co.nz"/>
Overnight between September 17 and September 18, snow and ice settled on [[Southland, New Zealand|Southland]]'s roads causing slippery conditions on rural roads and treacherous conditions in Invercargill as the local police asked people to stay indoors and off the roads. An [[autistic]] 7-year-old boy nearly died after falling in [[Paeroa]], and hundreds of cars were damaged or destroyed nationwide. A big tree fell on [[New Zealand State Highway 5|State Highway Five]], the [[Napier-Taupo Road]], about {{convert|3|km|mi|sp=us}} on the [[Napier, New Zealand|Napier]] side of the [[Tarawera Tavern]].<ref name="yahoo2"/><ref name="tvnz.co.nz"/> Sheep died in the worst winter since 1996.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nz.news.yahoo.com/a/-/top-stories/7973320/lambs-dying-in-southland-snowstorm/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100921123348/http://nz.news.yahoo.com/a/-/top-stories/7973320/lambs-dying-in-southland-snowstorm/ |title=Lambs dying in Southland snowstorm |work=Yahoo!Xtra News |agency=NZPA |date=September 19, 2010 |archivedate=September 21, 2010 |accessdate=May 15, 2012}}</ref>
The [[MetService]] reported more than 100 [[lightning]] strikes in the [[Hutt Valley]] and Wairarapa region yesterday,{{when|date=May 2012}} setting fire to a shed and igniting several trees early in the day.<ref name="yahoo2"/><ref name="tvnz.co.nz"/>
[[WeatherWatch.co.nz]] reported that some gusts had peaked at {{convert|154|km/h|mph|sp=us}}, collapsing power lines and cutting electricity in [[Warkworth, New Zealand|Warkworth]], [[Remuera]], [[Mangere]] and west [[Auckland]]. The electricity supply line company [[Vector Limited|Vector]] believes about 30,000 people lost power in the Auckland area and in [[Piha]] to the west of the city.<ref name="yahoo2"/><ref name="tvnz.co.nz"/>
===September 19–22===
====September 19–22: Americas==== [[Bermuda]] closed government-run schools for September 20 and 21 in anticipation of [[Hurricane Igor]]. In addition to school closures, the [[Bermuda International Airport|Bermuda International Airport (BDA)]] was shut down in advance of the storm. During the storm, the major causeway leading to the airport was shut down earlier than anticipated due to the threat of [[tornado]]es.<ref>{{cite news |work=Bernews |date=September 19, 2010 |accessdate=September 20, 2010 |title=Causeway Closed, Expected To Remain |url=http://bernews.com/2010/09/causeway-closed-expected-to-remain/}}</ref>
Despite initial fears that Hurricane Igor would cause immense damage across Bermuda, the storm passed after causing relatively minimal structural damage.<ref name="AFP1"/> Heavy rains fell across the islands between September 18 and 19, amounting to {{convert|2.97|in|mm|abbr=on}}; sustained winds were recorded over hurricane force and gusts reached {{convert|93|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. An [[AWOS]] on St. David's Lighthouse recorded a peak sustained wind of {{convert|91|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and gusts of {{convert|117|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Bermuda Weather Service |date=October 1, 2010 |accessdate=October 16, 2010 |title=BWS Daily Climatology Written Summary: September 1–30, 2010 |url=http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091216052441/http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |archivedate=December 16, 2009}}</ref> Although roughly 27,500 of the 35,000 residences across the island were without power, the damage was limited mainly to downed trees. No reports of loss of life or serious injuries came after the storm's passage. Officials in Bermuda stated that the biggest loss from Igor would be lessened tourism revenue following a mass exodus prior to the hurricane's arrival.<ref name="AFP1b">{{cite news |first=James |last=Whittaker |work=Agence France-Presse |date=September 20, 2010 |accessdate=September 20, 2010 |title=Bermuda emerges unscathed from Hurricane Igor |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5stC3aNsB?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i_gL6c04MxhoEcrfqrHLJ5NMUzRQ |archivedate=September 20, 2010 |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i_gL6c04MxhoEcrfqrHLJ5NMUzRQ |deadurl=yes |df=mdy}}</ref> Catastrophe modeler AIR Worldwide indicated that insured losses in Bermuda were less than $100 million.<ref name="Losses">{{cite news |author=AIR Worldwide |work=Bloomberg |date=September 20, 2010 |accessdate=September 20, 2010 |title=Insured Losses For Hurricane Igor In Bermuda Seen Under $100M |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=conewsstory&tkr=AIG:US&sid=aNYH8dKBk2rs}}</ref>
====September 19–22: Asia==== September 19 saw thirteen more people perish in [[Uttar Pradesh]] because of the Yamuna river floods. The maximum temperature in the capital city of [[New Delhi]] rose to {{convert|34.6|C}}. Several food prices rose because of the destroyed farmland.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.business-standard.com/commodities/storypage.php?autono=409526 |date=September 29, 2010 |title=All eyes on India amid firm global sugar prices |work=Business Standard |first=Ajay |last=Modi |accessdate=May 17, 2012}}</ref>
Uttar Pradesh [[Chief Minister]] [[Mayawati]] demanded that a national government team be sent to assess the losses suffered during the floods. After taking an [[aerial survey]] of the flood-hit areas, she requested that the national government provide [[Image:Indian Rupee symbol.svg|8px]] 2,175 [[crore]] for a flood relief team.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/Flood-relief-work--Maya-demands-Rs-2-175-cr/690387/ |title=Flood relief work: Maya demands Rs 2,175 cr |date=September 30, 2010 |work=The Indian Express |agency=Press Trust of India |accessdate=May 15, 2012}}</ref>
Not much happened in Pakistan on September 19, but the victims of the [[2010 Pakistan floods|Pakistan flood]] struggled to rebuild on their own. People swarmed around any cars, begging for help: their homes and everything were completely destroyed; their fields were turned into rubbish. One villager said "[n]obody has visited our village. Nobody has helped us. My house, my furniture & and everything else was destroyed. We had no support from the government."<ref>[https://archive.is/20120715051646/http://archives.dawn.com/archives/144650 DAWN.COM | Pakistan | Pakistan flood victims struggle to rebuild alone]</ref>
On September 20, heavy rain and landslides inflicted a [[death toll]] of 63 in [[Uttarakhand]]; [[Naintal]] lost 11, [[Haridwar]] 7 and [[Pauri]] 3.<ref name="oneindia1"/> The river [[Ganges]] flooded several low-lying areas as it passed {{convert|2|m|ft|sp=us}} above the danger mark in Haridwar, as [[Har-Ki-Puari]] was completely submerged underneath the floodwaters.<ref name="oneindia1"/> The state-run rescue operation to the region said that seven people were still trapped under the debris of flattened houses; local volunteers and police were already there. All the schools in the province were closed for three days. Uttarakhand's Chief Minister, [[Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank]], requested further help from both the [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] leader, [[Sushma Swaraj]], and the Indian prime minister.<ref name="oneindia1"/>
On September 22, the [[Yamuna river]] flooded the [[Yamuna Sports Complex]] and left mosquito-attracting pools of floodwater, further disrupting preparations for the [[Commonwealth Games]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-11403204 |work=BBC News |title=Games should not have gone to Delhi, says Australia |date=September 24, 2010}}</ref>
====September 19–22: Europe==== On September 22, in the morning after a night of steady rainfall [[Strathclyde Fire and Rescue]] received 117 calls about flooding in [[Kilbirnie]], [[Glengarnock]], [[Fairlie]], and [[Largs]] in [[North Ayrshire]], [[Scotland]].<ref name="dailyrecord.co.uk">{{cite news |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/2010/09/23/40-evacuated-from-care-home-and-schools-shut-as-flooding-causes-havoc-86908-22583123/ |title=40 evacuated from care home and schools shut as flooding causes havoc |date=September 23, 2010 |work=Daily Record |accessdate=November 19, 2010}}</ref> There were similar downpours in parts of Northumberland and [[Cumbria]] at the same time as the Scottish floods took place.<ref name="dailyrecord.co.uk"/> At one point later on September 22, 65 firefighters were called to flooding in the [[Rothesay, Argyll and Bute|Rothesay]] and [[Helensburgh]] areas of [[Argyll and Bute]].<ref name="dailyrecord.co.uk"/> Just after 9:00 pm on September 22, a storm-weakened wall collapsed over the [[Glasgow to Largs main railway line]] near [[Pencil View]] in Largs, forcing [[Network Rail]] to close the line.<ref name="dailyrecord.co.uk"/>
====September 19–22: Oceania==== On September 19 the roof of the 2,000 seat [[Stadium Southland]] tennis stadium in Invercargill, New Zealand collapsed and imploded after a storm dumped a near-record amount of snow on it during a tennis match. A tennis player narrowly evaded death when the air pressure's [[shock wave]] hit him as he loitered outside the stadium's entrance.<ref name="Stuff.co.nz_4144286">{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/southland-times/news/4144286/Players-run-as-roof-falls-behind-them |title=Players run as roof falls behind them |last=MacKay |first=Scot |date=September 20, 2010 |work=[[The Southland Times]] |accessdate=October 1, 2011}}</ref> In contrast, in [[Christchurch]] the weather was sunny and bright, with a temperature of {{convert|15|C|F}} not {{convert|-10|C|F}}. [[New Zealand State Highway 1|State Highway 1]] near Woodlands, Invercargill and Edendale was closed after a [[Fonterra]] truck [[jackknifed]].<ref name="stuff.co.nz">{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/4141614/Storm-causes-damage-across-country |title=Storm causes chaos across country |author=Paul Gorman and NZPA |date=September 18, 2010 |work=[[The Press]] |accessdate=October 1, 2011}}</ref> Fonterra had difficulty picking up milk from some areas due to [[tanker truck]]s jack-knifing on the roads; 400 farmers dumped their milk for hygiene reasons as it began to [[Fermentation (biochemistry)|ferment]] and [[mold]].<ref name="Stuff.co.nz_4144287">{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/southland-times/news/4144287/Dairy-farmers-told-to-dump-milk |title=Dairy farmers told to dump milk |date=September 20, 2010 |work=[[The Southland Times]] |accessdate=October 1, 2011}}</ref> Similar automotive incidents closed most of [[New Zealand State Highway 99|State Highway 99]] as {{convert|10|cm|in|sp=us}} of snow hit Invercargill that day and blocked most of its streets. The airport was closed and [[Air New Zealand]] crews were sent home. Overnight snowfalls hit [[Lumsden, New Zealand|Lumsden]] and [[Queenstown, New Zealand|Queenstown]] for the second night running.<ref name="stuff.co.nz"/>
The morning of September 20 saw roof collapses from heavy snow of [[the Wren building]] and neighbouring retailer [[Briscoes]] in [[Yarrow St]], Invercargill.<ref name="Stuff.co.nz_4144271">{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/southland-times/news/4144271/City-store-in-ruins-after-roof-collapses |title=City store in ruins after roof collapses |last=Lamont |first=Sarah |date=September 20, 2010 |work=[[The Southland Times]] |accessdate=October 1, 2011}}</ref>
Heavy snow destroyed a {{convert|1000|m2|sqft|sp=us|adj=on}} [[greenhouse|glasshouse]] at [[Eldon Gardens]], [[Donald McDonald's drive]] in [[Tweed St]], killing 2,000 young tomato plants. The weight of the snow buckled the metal support poles of the glasshouse and most of the eight bays collapsed. The NZ$100,000 glass house was 18 years old.<ref name="Stuff.co.nz_4144290">{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/southland-times/news/4144290/Heavy-snow-destroys-100k-glasshouse-in-city |title=Heavy snow destroys $100k glasshouse in city |last=Hotton |first=Mark |date=September 20, 2010 |work=[[The Southland Times]] |accessdate=October 1, 2011}}</ref> The snowfall in Invercargill was about {{cvt|10|–|14|cm|in}} deep, and was probably the worst in the town for at least 50 years.<ref name="Stuff.co.nz_4144288">{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/southland-times/news/4144288/City-snowfall-biggest-in-50-years |title=City snowfall biggest in 50 years? |last=Lamont |first=Sarah |date=September 20, 2010 |work=[[The Southland Times]] |accessdate=October 1, 2011}}</ref>
===September 23–25===
====September 23–25: Asia==== September 23 saw northern India's storm devastating railways with 22 [[Delhi]] (inbound and outbound) trains canceled and another 65 diverted due to the severe flooding in Delhi as the river [[Yamuna]] reached the {{convert|207.06|m|ft|adj=on|sp=us}} danger mark. The [[Old Yamuna Bridge]] between [[East Delhi]] and New Delhi was closed for safety reasons as the Yamuna river's level rose menacingly. Residents in low-lying areas were evacuated to shelters in New Delhi.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.oneindia.in/2010/09/23/flood-fury-in-delhi-22-trains-cancelled.html |title=22 Trains Cancelled; Flood in Delhi; Yamuna Water Crossed Danger Mark |work=Oneindia News |date=September 23, 2010}}</ref>
The Yamuna river reached a record high above the {{convert|495|ft|m|adj=on}} danger mark in the worst [[monsoon]] rains for 30 years, leaving [[mosquito]]-attracting pools and coming dangerously near the [[Taj Mahal]]; more water was discharged from the [[Gokul]] and [[Okhla]] [[Barrage (dam)|barrages]].<ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Yamuna-water-rising-flood-situation-grim-in-Agra-/articleshow/6618027.cms#ixzz10Qv5PCSL Yamuna water rising, flood situation grim in Agra – The Times of India] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100927231342/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Yamuna-water-rising-flood-situation-grim-in-Agra-/articleshow/6618027.cms#ixzz10Qv5PCSL |date=September 27, 2010 }}</ref>
====September 24–25: Europe==== In Scotland, [[Grampian Police]] warned of treacherous conditions as flooding hit [[Aberdeenshire]] and Aberdeen on September 23.<ref name="dailyrecord.co.uk" /> Residents of the [[Meadows Care Home]] in [[Huntly, Aberdeenshire|Huntly]], Aberdeenshire were moved to temporary shelder as the level of the [[River Deveron]] rose to danger level. 40 other local residents were given shelter at [[the Gordon Schools]].<ref name="dailyrecord.co.uk"/> [[Grampian Fire and Rescue Service]] said a number of crews from Huntly, [[Elgin, Moray|Elgin]], and the former [[Tayside]] region, along with the [[British Red Cross]] and a local coast-guard team, were all involved in the evacuation.<ref name="dailyrecord.co.uk"/> Some schools were shut after several hours of torrential rain dramatically raised the level of a nearby Aberdeenshire river, while about 10 households in Soy Avenue and Durn Road, [[Portsoy]] were evacuated to a nearby care home.<ref name="dailyrecord.co.uk"/> Parts of North Ayrshire, [[Glasgow]], [[Lothian]], and Argyll and Bute were also affected.<ref name="dailyrecord.co.uk"/> [[Lothian and Borders Police]] later reported some flooding on [[West Maitland Street]], [[Edinburgh]], and [[High Street]] in [[Prestonpans]].<ref name="dailyrecord.co.uk"/>
The [[Met Office]] said that {{convert|37|mm|in|sp=us}} of rain had fallen in 12 hours overnight; Glasgow normally has {{convert|95|mm|in|sp=us}} of rain in all of September. Aberdeenshire also had {{convert|25|mm|in|sp=us}} of rain in 12 hours, and it continued to rain for the rest of the day leaving an extra {{convert|10|–|20|mm|in|sp=us}} of rain by nightfall.<ref name="dailyrecord.co.uk"/> September 24 and 25 also saw patches of heavy rain hit various parts of Ireland, Belgium, and the Netherlands.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
===September 26–30===
====September 26–30: Africa==== {{Main|2010 Nigerien floods}} In [[Hadejia]] and [[Kararar Rima]], Nigeria, the flood victims slept wherever they could; the men searched for dry spots on the roads, while women and children kept piling into the houses still standing, as huge numbers of displaced people returned to flood-hit villages in northern Nigeria. Over two million people were affected by the flood waters and more than fifty thousand families were made homeless. Most of the houses were made of clay, so they [[Dissolution (chemistry)|dissolved]] in the flood waters.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iguvcTEOiu7FW6ptKz_UKMeKNOgQ?docId=CNG.df9e6a188a034ac23300ab0760b91861.8f1 |work=AFP |title=Flood victims sleep by roadsides in northern Nigeria |date=September 28, 2010 |accessdate=May 15, 2012}}</ref>
====September 26–30: Americas==== The [[Mississippi]] river started to rise and threatened [[St. Paul, Minnesota]], with Mayor [[Chris Coleman (politician)|Chris Coleman]] declaring an emergency. The previous week's rain caused the [[Minnesota]] and Mississippi rivers to reach flood levels. Rising water levels after last week's heavy rainfall in southern Minnesota forced [[Water Street (Saint Paul)|Water Street]] between [[Plato Boulevard]] and [[Minnesota 13]] to be closed on September 28.<ref>[http://www.twincities.com/localnews/ci_16200541?nclick_check=1 St. Paul / As river rises, mayor declares emergency – TwinCities.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402184909/http://www.twincities.com/localnews/ci_16200541?nclick_check=1 |date=April 2, 2012 }}</ref>
In Canada, the [[Welfare (financial aid)|financial assistance]] department announced that up to CA$300,000 per claim would be available to the people harmed by heavy rains and flooding in the North Island and [[Central Coast Regional District|Central Coast]] areas. Areas including [[Port Alice]], [[Port Hardy]], [[Zeballos, British Columbia|Zeballos]], and the Central Coast region's [[Bella Coola, British Columbia|Bella Coola]], [[Kingcome, British Columbia|Kingcome]], and the Highway 20 corridor between Bella Coola and [[Anahim Lake]] would be covered.<ref>[http://www.canada.com/Financial+assistance+announced+areas+hammered+weather/3593804/story.html Financial assistance announced for areas hammered by bad weather] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006145021/http://www.canada.com/Financial%2Bassistance%2Bannounced%2Bareas%2Bhammered%2Bweather/3593804/story.html |date=October 6, 2014 }}</ref>
====September 26–30: Asia==== September 26 saw heavy rain (causing more massive flooding) moving into [[Bihar]] and devastating an area around [[Patna]]. The [[Danapur Diyara]] district was the worst affected. Locals complained about a lack of emergency housing and supplies. The river Ganges breached its banks and flooded all low-lying areas, leaving many stranded due to flooded roads, collapsed bridges, and precautionary closures.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.oneindia.in/2010/09/26/heavy-rain-flood-paralyse-bihar.html |date=September 26, 2010 |title=Massive Rain; Bihar Stranded; North India Flood; Patna Houses Collapsed |work=Oneindia News}}</ref>
September 27 and 28 saw the flood situation reaching its worst at [[Agra]] where the river water level touched {{convert|152.4|m|ft|sp=us}} on the morning of September 27. Many neighborhoods and [[ghat]]s, such as the Taj Ganj [[cremation]] ghat, were submerged after several thunderstorms brought very heavy rainfall. Almost half of the city was without drinking water. Tourists visiting the Taj Mahal were asked to stay far away from the raging river. Settlements in the [[Balkeshwar]] and [[Dayalbagh]] areas have been inundated. More than 30 villages in the [[Bah tehsil]] have also been badly hit by the Yamuna river floods.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.southasiamail.com/news.php?id=82868 |work=South Asia Mail |title=Flood situation in Agra worsens |date=September 27, 2010 |agency=IANS}}</ref><ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Yamuna-water-rising-flood-situation-grim-in-Agra-/articleshow/6618027.cms Yamuna water rising, flood situation grim in Agra – The Times of India] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100927231342/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Yamuna-water-rising-flood-situation-grim-in-Agra-/articleshow/6618027.cms |date=September 27, 2010 }}</ref>
====September 26–30: Oceania==== In [[Waikato]], people started preparing for floods as heavy rain threatened to push already-swollen rivers past their limits. Preparations were made for the worst as the region had already been hit by a storm the previous week.<ref name="NZ_Herald_10676910">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10676910 |title=Waikato prepares for floods |date=September 29, 2010 |agency=[[NZPA]] |newspaper=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=October 1, 2011}}</ref> While further rain did fall, the most serious flooding at the start of October 2010 turned out to be south of Waikato in the central region of New Zealand.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10677320 |title=Central areas mop up after heavy rain |date=October 1, 2010 |accessdate=May 16, 2012 |first=Jarrod |last=Booker |work=The New Zealand Herald}}</ref>

{{Global surveillance}} {{about||earlier global surveillance disclosures|Global surveillance disclosures (1970–2013)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2015}} Ongoing news reports in the international media have revealed operational details about the United States [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) and its international partners' [[global surveillance]]<ref>{{cite news |last=[[Barton Gellman]] |title=Edward Snowden, after months of NSA revelations, says his mission's accomplished |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/edward-snowden-after-months-of-nsa-revelations-says-his-missions-accomplished/2013/12/23/49fc36de-6c1c-11e3-a523-fe73f0ff6b8d_story.html |date=December 24, 2013 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=December 25, 2013 |quote=Taken together, the revelations have brought to light a global surveillance system...}}</ref> of foreign nationals and U.S. citizens. The reports mostly emanate from a cache of [[top secret]] documents [[Leak (news)|leaked]] by ex-NSA contractor [[Edward Snowden]], which he obtained whilst working for [[Booz Allen Hamilton]], one of the largest contractors for defense and intelligence in the United States.<ref name="WP20130610Security">{{cite news |title=Who holds security clearances? |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/who-holds-security-clearances/2013/06/10/983744e4-d232-11e2-a73e-826d299ff459_graphic.html |accessdate=February 12, 2014 |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=June 10, 2013}}</ref> In addition to a trove of U.S. federal documents, Snowden's cache reportedly contains thousands of Australian, British and Canadian intelligence files that he had accessed via the exclusive "[[Five Eyes]]" network. <ref name="WP20130610Security" /> In June 2013, the first of Snowden's documents were published simultaneously by ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and ''[[The Guardian]]'', attracting considerable public attention.<ref>{{cite web |last=Greenwald |first=Glenn |title=NSA collecting phone records of millions of Verizon customers daily |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/06/nsa-phone-records-verizon-court-order |work=The Guardian |accessdate=August 16, 2013 |quote=Exclusive: Top secret court order requiring [[Verizon]] to hand over all call data shows scale of domestic surveillance under [[Barack Obama|Obama]]}}</ref> The disclosure continued throughout 2013, and a small portion of the estimated full cache of documents was later published by other media outlets worldwide, most notably ''[[The New York Times]]'' (United States), the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]], the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]], ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' (Germany), ''[[O Globo]]'' (Brazil), ''[[Le Monde]]'' (France), ''[[L'espresso]]'' (Italy), ''[[NRC Handelsblad]]'' (the Netherlands), ''[[Dagbladet]]'' (Norway), ''[[El País]]'' (Spain), and [[Sveriges Television]] (Sweden).<ref>{{cite web |title=NSA Primary Sources |url=https://www.eff.org/nsa-spying/nsadocs |publisher=[[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] |accessdate=December 14, 2013}}</ref>
These media reports have shed light on the implications of several [[Secret treaty|secret treaties]] signed by members of the [[UKUSA Agreement|UKUSA community]] in their efforts to implement [[global surveillance]]. For example, ''Der Spiegel'' revealed how the German [[Bundesnachrichtendienst]] (BND) transfers "massive amounts of intercepted data to the NSA",<ref name="spiegelsendnsa">{{cite web |author1=Hubert Gude |author2=Laura Poitras |author3=Marcel Rosenbach |title=German intelligence Sends Massive Amounts of Data to the NSA |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/german-intelligence-sends-massive-amounts-of-data-to-the-nsa-a-914821.html |work=[[Der Spiegel]] |accessdate=December 14, 2013 |date=August 5, 2013}}</ref> while Swedish Television revealed the [[National Defence Radio Establishment (Sweden)|National Defence Radio Establishment]] (FRA) provided the NSA with data from its [[diplomatic cable|cable collection]], under a secret treaty signed in 1954 for bilateral cooperation on surveillance.<ref>{{cite web |last=Gunnar Rensfeldt |title=NSA 'asking for' specific exchanges from FRA – Secret treaty since 1954 |url=http://www.svt.se/ug/nsafra4 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |accessdate=December 14, 2013 |quote=This document, dated 18 April of this year, clearly shows that the relation is very close indeed, seemingly growing even closer. 'NSA's relationship with the FRA, an extremely competent, technically innovative, and trusted Third Party partner, continues to grow. The FRA provided NSA with access to its cable collection in 2011'}}</ref> Other security and intelligence agencies involved in the practice of [[global surveillance]] include those in Australia ([[Australian Signals Directorate|ASD]]), Britain ([[Government Communications Headquarters|GCHQ]]), Canada ([[Communications Security Establishment Canada|CSEC]]), Denmark ([[Politiets Efterretningstjeneste|PET]]), France ([[Directorate-General for External Security|DGSE]]), Germany ([[Bundesnachrichtendienst|BND]]), Italy ([[Agenzia Informazioni e Sicurezza Esterna|AISE]]), the Netherlands ([[Algemene Inlichtingen en Veiligheidsdienst|AIVD]]), Norway ([[Norwegian Intelligence Service|NIS]]), Spain ([[Centro Nacional de Inteligencia|CNI]]), Switzerland ([[Swiss intelligence agencies|NDB]]), Singapore ([[Security and Intelligence division|SID]]) as well as Israel ([[Unit 8200|ISNU]]), which receives raw, unfiltered data of U.S. citizens that is shared by the NSA.<ref On June 14, 2013, United States [[prosecutor]]s [[Criminal charge|charged]] Edward Snowden with [[Espionage Act of 1917|espionage]] and [[theft of property|theft of government property]].<ref name="washcomplaints">[https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/documents/world/us-vs-edward-j-snowden-criminal-complaint/496/ U.S. vs. Edward J. Snowden criminal complaint]. ''[[The Washington Post]]''.</ref> In late July 2013, he was granted a one-year temporary [[Right of asylum|asylum]] by the Russian government,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/17/world/europe/snowden-submits-application-for-asylum-in-russia.html |title=Leaker Files for Asylum to Remain in Russia |work=The New York Times |date=July 16, 2013 |accessdate=December 16, 2013 |first=David M. |last=Herszenhorn}}</ref> contributing to a deterioration of [[Russia–United States relations]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323681904578641610474568782 |title=Snowden Asylum Hits U.S.-Russia Relations |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=August 1, 2013 |accessdate=December 16, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2013/08/01/207831950/snowden-has-left-moscows-airport-as-russia-grants-asylum |title=.S. 'Extremely Disappointed' At Russia's Asylum For Snowden |publisher=NPR |date=August 1, 2013 |accessdate=December 16, 2013}}</ref> On August 6, 2013, U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] made a public appearance on national television where he told Americans that "We don't have a domestic spying program" and that "There is no spying on Americans".<ref>{{cite web |last=Henderson |title=Obama To Leno: 'There Is No Spying On Americans' |url=http://m.npr.org/news/U.S./209692380 |publisher=NPR |accessdate=August 16, 2013}}</ref> Towards the end of October 2013, the British Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] warned ''[[The Guardian]]'' [[prior restraint|not to publish]] any more leaks, or it will receive a [[DA-Notice]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Francis Elliott |title=Cameron hints at action to stop security leaks |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/politics/article3906802.ece |work=[[The Times]] |accessdate=November 13, 2013}}</ref> In November 2013, a criminal investigation of the disclosure was being undertaken by Britain's [[Metropolitan Police Service]].<ref name="criminaluk">{{cite news |author=Satter, Raphael |title=UK Pursuing Criminal Investigation Into Guardian Leaks |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/13/uk-investigation-guardian-leaks_n_4266026.html |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=November 13, 2013 |accessdate=September 23, 2014}}</ref> In December 2013, ''The Guardian'' editor [[Alan Rusbridger]] said: "We have published I think 26 documents so far out of the 58,000 we've seen."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-25205846 |title=Only 1% of Snowden files published – Guardian editor |publisher=BBC |date=December 3, 2013 |accessdate=December 29, 2013}}</ref>
The extent to which the media reports have responsibly informed the public is disputed. In January 2014, Obama said that "the sensational way in which these disclosures have come out has often shed more heat than light"<ref name="npr.org">[https://www.npr.org/blogs/itsallpolitics/2014/01/17/263480199/transcript-of-president-obamas-speech-on-nsa-reforms Transcript Of President Obama's Speech On NSA Reforms] [[NPR]] January 17, 2014</ref> and critics such as [[Sean Wilentz]] have noted that many of the Snowden documents released do not concern domestic surveillance.<ref name="newrepublic.com">[[Sean Wilentz]] (January 19, 2014), [https://newrepublic.com/article/116253/edward-snowden-glenn-greenwald-julian-assange-what-they-believe Would You Feel Differently About Snowden, Greenwald, and Assange If You Knew What They Really Thought?] ''[[The New Republic]]''</ref> The US & UK Defense establishment weigh the strategic harm in the period following the disclosures more heavily than their civic public benefit. In its first assessment of these disclosures, [[the Pentagon]] concluded that Snowden committed the biggest "theft" of U.S. secrets in the [[history of the United States]].<ref name="mostpentagon" /> Sir [[David Omand]], a former director of GCHQ, described Snowden's disclosure as the "most catastrophic loss to British intelligence ever".<ref name="omandsnowden">{{cite news |title=Snowden leaks 'worst ever loss to British intelligence' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-24486649 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=February 4, 2014 |date=October 11, 2013}}</ref>

=== Disclosures === Although the exact size of Snowden's disclosure remains unknown, the following estimates have been put up by various government officials: * At least 15,000 [[Australian Intelligence Community|Australian intelligence]] files, according to Australian officials<ref name="australian20k">{{cite news |author1=Cameron Stewart |author2=Paul Maley |title=Edward Snowden stole up to 20,000 Aussie files |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/policy/edward-snowden-stole-up-to-20000-aussie-files/story-fn59nm2j-1226775491490# |work=[[The Australian]] |accessdate=February 1, 2014 |date=December 5, 2013}}</ref> * At least 58,000 British intelligence files, according to British officials<ref>{{cite news |title=David Miranda row: Seized files 'endanger agents' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-23898580 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=February 1, 2014 |date=August 30, 2013}}</ref> * About 1.7 million U.S. intelligence files, according to [[U.S. Department of Defense]] talking points<ref name="mostpentagon">{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-01-09/pentagon-finds-snowden-took-1-7-million-files-rogers-says.html |title=Pentagon Says Snowden Took Most U.S. Secrets Ever |accessdate=2014-02-01 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140110092104/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-01-09/pentagon-finds-snowden-took-1-7-million-files-rogers-says.html |archivedate=January 10, 2014 |df=}}</ref><ref name="ViceNewsJune2015">{{cite news |last=Leopold |first=Jason |title=Exclusive: Inside Washington's Quest to Bring Down Edward Snowden |url=https://news.vice.com/article/exclusive-inside-washingtons-quest-to-bring-down-edward-snowden |work=[[Vice News]] |accessdate=June 4, 2015 |date=June 4, 2015}}</ref>
As a contractor of the NSA, Snowden was granted access to U.S. government documents along with [[top secret]] documents of several [[Western allies|allied]] governments, via the exclusive [[Five Eyes]] network.<ref>{{cite news |last=Corera |first=Gordon |title=Spying scandal: Will the 'five eyes' club open up? |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-24715168 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=February 1, 2014 |date=October 29, 2013}}</ref> Snowden claims that he is currently not in physical possession of any of these documents, after having surrendered all copies to the journalists he met in Hong Kong.<ref>{{cite news |last=Risen |first=James |title=Snowden Says He Took No Secret Files to Russia |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/18/world/snowden-says-he-took-no-secret-files-to-russia.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=February 1, 2014 |date=October 17, 2013}}</ref>
According to his lawyer, Snowden has pledged not to release any documents while in Russia, leaving the responsibility for further disclosures solely to journalists.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Timothy Heritage |author2=Steve Holland |title=Russia gives Snowden asylum, Obama-Putin summit in doubt |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/08/01/us-usa-security-snowden-russia-idUSBRE9700N120130801 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=February 1, 2014 |date=August 1, 2013}}</ref> As of 2014, the following news outlets have accessed some of the documents provided by Snowden: [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]], [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]], [[Channel 4]], ''[[Der Spiegel]]'', ''[[El Pais]]'', ''[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]'', ''[[L'espresso]]'', ''[[Le Monde]]'', [[NBC]], ''[[NRC Handelsblad]]'', ''[[Dagbladet]]'', ''[[O Globo]]'', ''[[South China Morning Post]]'', ''[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]]'', [[Sveriges Television]], ''[[The Guardian]]'', ''[[The New York Times]]'', and ''[[The Washington Post]]''.
=== Historical context === {{Main|Global surveillance disclosures (1970–2013)}} In the 1970s, NSA analyst [[Perry Fellwock]] (under the pseudonym "Winslow Peck") revealed the existence of the [[UKUSA Agreement]], which forms the basis of the [[ECHELON]] network, whose existence was revealed in 1988 by [[Lockheed Corporation|Lockheed]] employee Margaret Newsham.<ref name="ramparts">{{cite news |title=U.S. Electronic Espionage: A Memoir |work=Ramparts |date=August 1972 |pages=35–50 |quote=The SIGINT community was defined by a TOP SECRET treaty signed in 1947. It was called the UKUSA treaty. The National Security Agency signed for the U.S. and became what's called First Party to the Treaty.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://duncan.gn.apc.org/echelon-dc.htm |last=Campbell |first=Duncan |authorlink=Duncan Campbell (journalist) |title=Somebody's Listening |newspaper=[[New Statesman]] |date=August 12, 1988 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420093650/http://duncan.gn.apc.org/echelon-dc.htm |archivedate=April 20, 2013 |quote=The Congressional officials were first told of the Thurmond interception by a former employee of the Lockheed Space and Missiles Corporation, Margaret Newsham, who now lives in Sunnyvale, California. |postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. In the aftermath of Snowden's revelations, [[The Pentagon]] concluded that Snowden committed the biggest theft of U.S. secrets in the [[history of the United States]].<ref name="mostpentagon" /> In Australia, the coalition government described the leaks as the most damaging blow dealt to [[Australian Intelligence Community|Australian intelligence]] in history.<ref name="australian20k" /> Sir [[David Omand]], a former director of GCHQ, described Snowden's disclosure as the "most catastrophic loss to British intelligence ever".<ref name="omandsnowden"/>
== Timeline == {{Main|Timeline of global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)}} [[File:The Mira.jpg|thumb|[[The Mira Hong Kong|The Mira]] hotel in Hong Kong, where Edward Snowden hosted his first meeting with [[Glenn Greenwald]], [[Laura Poitras]], and journalist Ewen MacAskill of ''[[The Guardian]]''<ref name="mira" />]]
In April 2012, NSA contractor [[Edward Snowden]] began downloading documents.<ref name="reuterschrono">Mark Hosenball (August 15, 2013), [https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/08/15/us-usa-security-snowden-dell-idUSBRE97E17P20130815 Snowden downloaded NSA secrets while working for Dell, sources say] ''[[Reuters]]</ref> That year, Snowden had made his first contact with journalist [[Glenn Greenwald]], then employed by ''[[The Guardian]]'', and he contacted documentary filmmaker [[Laura Poitras]] in January 2013.<ref name="poitras-how">{{cite news |url=http://www.salon.com/2013/06/10/qa_with_laura_poitras_the_woman_behind_the_nsa_scoops/singleton/ |title=How we broke the NSA story |last=Carmon |first=Irin |date=June 10, 2013 |work=[[Salon (website)|Salon]] |accessdate=June 11, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615053746/http://www.salon.com/2013/06/10/qa_with_laura_poitras_the_woman_behind_the_nsa_scoops/singleton/ |archivedate=June 15, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Maass">[[Peter Maass]] (August 18, 2013), [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/18/magazine/laura-poitras-snowden.html "How Laura Poitras Helped Snowden Spill His Secrets"]. ''The New York Times''</ref>
=== 2013 ===
==== May ==== In May 2013, Snowden went on temporary leave from his position at the NSA, citing the pretext of receiving treatment for his [[epilepsy]]. Towards the end of May, he traveled to Hong Kong.<ref name="guardian-reveal">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/09/edward-snowden-nsa-whistleblower-surveillance |title=Edward Snowden: the whistleblower behind the NSA surveillance revelations |last=Greenwald |first=Glenn |last2=MacAskill |first2=Ewen |last3=Poitras |first3=Laura |date=June 9, 2013 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=June 9, 2013 |location=London}}</ref><ref name="cnn-hotel">{{cite news |first1=Matt |last1=Smith |first2=Michael |last2=Pearson |title=NSA leaker holed up in Hong Kong hotel, running low on cash |publisher=CNN |date=June 10, 2013 |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/06/10/politics/nsa-leak/index.html |accessdate=June 10, 2013}}</ref> Greenwald, Poitras and the Guardian's defence and intelligence correspondent [[Ewen MacAskill]] flew to Hong Kong to meet Snowden.
==== June ==== After the U.S.-based editor of ''[[The Guardian]]'', [[Janine Gibson]], held several meetings in [[New York City]], it was decided that Greenwald, Poitras and the ''Guardian''{{'}}s defence and intelligence correspondent Ewen MacAskill would fly to Hong Kong to meet Snowden. On June 5, in the first media report based on the leaked material,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/defense/everything-we-learned-from-edward-snowden-in-2013-20131231 |title=Everything We Learned from Edward Snowden in 2013 |work=National Journal}}</ref> ''The Guardian'' exposed a [[top secret]] court order showing that the NSA had collected phone records from over 120 million [[MAINWAY|Verizon subscribers]].<ref name="guardiangg621">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/06/nsa-phone-records-verizon-court-order |title=NSA collecting phone records of millions of Verizon customers daily |author=[[Glenn Greenwald]] |work=The Guardian |date=June 6, 2013 |accessdate=September 16, 2013 |location=London}}</ref> Under the order, the numbers of both parties on a call, as well as the location data, unique identifiers, time of call, and duration of call were handed over to the FBI, which turned over the records to the NSA.<ref name="guardiangg621" /> According to ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', the Verizon order is part of a controversial data program, which seeks to stockpile records on all calls made in the U.S., but does not collect information directly from [[T-Mobile US]] and [[Verizon Wireless]], in part because of their foreign ownership ties.<ref>{{cite news |title=T-Mobile, Verizon Wireless Shielded from NSA Sweep |url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887324049504578543800240266368 |accessdate=February 10, 2014 |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |date=June 14, 2013 |author1=Danny Yadron |author2=Evan Perez}}</ref>
On June 6, 2013, the second media disclosure, the revelation of the [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM surveillance program]] (which collects the e-mail, voice, text and video chats of foreigners and an unknown number of Americans from Microsoft, Google, Facebook, Yahoo, Apple and other tech giants),<ref name="WaPo1">{{cite news |author=[[Barton Gellman|Gellman, Barton]]; [[Laura Poitras|Poitras, Laura]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/us-intelligence-mining-data-from-nine-us-internet-companies-in-broad-secret-program/2013/06/06/3a0c0da8-cebf-11e2-8845-d970ccb04497_story.html |title=US Intelligence Mining Data from Nine U.S. Internet Companies in Broad Secret Program |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=June 6, 2013 |accessdate=June 15, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Greenwald1">{{cite news |author=[[Glenn Greenwald|Greenwald, Glenn]]; MacAskill, Ewen |title=NSA Taps in to Internet Giants' Systems to Mine User Data, Secret Files Reveal – Top-Secret Prism Program Claims Direct Access to Servers of Firms Including Google, Apple and Facebook – Companies Deny Any Knowledge of Program in Operation Since 2007 – Obama Orders US to Draw Up Overseas Target List for Cyber-Attacks |work=[[The Guardian]] |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/06/us-tech-giants-nsa-data |accessdate=June 15, 2013 |date=June 6, 2013 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=NSA slides explain the PRISM data-collection program |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/special/politics/prism-collection-documents/ |accessdate=February 11, 2014 |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=June 6, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Inner workings of a top-secret spy program |url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/inner-workings-of-a-top-secret-spy-program/282/ |accessdate=February 11, 2014 |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=June 29, 2013 |author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Todd Lindeman}}</ref> was published simultaneously by ''The Guardian'' and ''[[The Washington Post]]''.<ref name="mira">{{cite web |title=How Edward Snowden led journalist and film-maker to reveal NSA secrets |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/19/edward-snowden-nsa-secrets-glenn-greenwald-laura-poitras |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=August 20, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=U.S., British intelligence mining data from nine U.S. Internet companies in broad secret program |url=https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-06-06/news/39784046_1_prism-nsa-u-s-servers |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=August 20, 2013 |first1=Barton |last1=Gellman |first2=Laura |last2=Poitras |date=June 7, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130824083615/http://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-06-06/news/39784046_1_prism-nsa-u-s-servers |archivedate=August 24, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
[[File:Xkeyscore-worldmap.jpg|thumb|right|245px|Slide from a 2008 NSA presentation about [[XKeyscore]], showing a worldmap with the locations of XKeyscore servers]] ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' revealed NSA spying on multiple diplomatic missions of the [[European Union]] (EU) and the [[United Nations Headquarters]] in New York.<ref>{{cite news |last=[[Laura Poitras]], Marcel Rosenbach, Fidelius Schmid and Holger Stark |title=NSA Spied on European Union Offices |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/nsa-spied-on-european-union-offices-a-908590.html |newspaper=[[Der Spiegel]] |date=June 29, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=[[Laura Poitras]], Marcel Rosenbach and Holger Stark |title=How America Spies on Europe and the UN |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/secret-nsa-documents-show-how-the-us-spies-on-europe-and-the-un-a-918625.html |newspaper=[[Der Spiegel]]}}</ref> During specific episodes within a four-year period, the NSA hacked several Chinese mobile-phone companies,<ref>[http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1266821/us-hacks-chinese-mobile-phone-companies-steals-sms-data-edward-snowden EXCLUSIVE: US hacks Chinese mobile phone companies], ''South China Morning Post''</ref> the [[Chinese University of Hong Kong]] and [[Tsinghua University]] in Beijing,<ref>[http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1266892/exclusive-nsa-targeted-chinas-tsinghua-university-extensive-hacking NSA targeted China's Tsinghua University in hacking attacks], ''South China Morning Post''</ref> and the Asian fiber-optic network operator [[Pacnet]].<ref>Lam, Lana (June 23, 2013). [http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1266875/exclusive-us-hacked-pacnet-asia-pacific-fibre-optic-network-operator "US hacked Pacnet, Asia Pacific fibre-optic network operator, in 2009"]. ''South China Morning Post'' (Hong Kong). Retrieved June 25, 2013.</ref> Only [[Five-eyes|Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the UK]] are explicitly exempted from NSA attacks, whose main target in the EU is Germany.<ref>{{cite web |last=Laura Poitras, Marcel Rosenbach und Holger Stark |title=Geheimdokumente: NSA überwacht 500 Millionen Verbindungen in Deutschland |url=http://www.spiegel.de/netzwelt/netzpolitik/nsa-ueberwacht-500-millionen-verbindungen-in-deutschland-a-908517.html |work=[[Der Spiegel]] |accessdate=June 30, 2013 |language=German}}</ref> A method of bugging encrypted fax machines used at an EU embassy is codenamed [[Dropmire]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/30/nsa-leaks-us-bugging-european-allies |title=New NSA leaks show how US is bugging its European allies |author1=MacAskill, Ewen |author2=Borger, Julian |date=June 30, 2013 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London}}</ref>
During the [[2009 G-20 London summit]], the British intelligence agency [[Government Communications Headquarters]] ('''GCHQ''') intercepted the communications of foreign diplomats.<ref name="guardiangchq">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/jun/16/gchq-intercepted-communications-g20-summits |title=GCHQ intercepted foreign politicians' communications at G20 summits |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=June 17, 2013 |accessdate=April 11, 2015 |author1=MacAskill, Ewen |author2=Davies, Nick |author3=Hopkins, Nick |author4=Borger, Julian |author5=Ball, James}}</ref> In addition, GCHQ has been intercepting and storing mass quantities of fiber-optic traffic via [[Tempora]].<ref name="tempora">{{cite news |last=MacAskill |first=Ewen |last2=Borger |first2=Julian |last3=Hopkins |first3=Nick |last4=Davies |first4=Nick |last5=Ball |first5=James |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/jun/21/gchq-cables-secret-world-communications-nsa |title=GCHQ taps fiber-optic cables for secret access to world's communications |newspaper=The Guardian |date=June 21, 2013 |location=London}}</ref> Two principal components of Tempora are called "[[Mastering the Internet]]" (MTI) and "[[Global Telecoms Exploitation]]".<ref name="Guardian45136fdh">{{cite news |author1=Ewen MacAskill |author2=Julian Borger |author3=Nick Hopkins |author4=Nick Davies |author5=James Ball |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/jun/21/gchq-cables-secret-world-communications-nsa |title=GCHQ taps fibre-optic cables for secret access to world's communications |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=June 21, 2013 |accessdate=June 21, 2013 |location=London}}</ref> The data is preserved for three days while [[metadata]] is kept for thirty days.<ref name=bump>{{cite web |url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/national/2013/06/uk-tempora-program/66490/ |author=Philip Bump |title=The UK Tempora Program Captures Vast Amounts of Data – and Shares with NSA |work=The Atlantic Wire |date=June 21, 2013 |accessdate=June 23, 2013}}</ref> Data collected by GCHQ under Tempora is shared with the [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) of the United States.<ref name="Guardian45136fdh" />
From 2001 to 2011, the NSA collected vast amounts of metadata records detailing the email and internet usage of Americans via [[Stellar Wind (code name)|Stellar Wind]],<ref>{{cite news |title=NSA collected US email records in bulk for more than two years under Obama |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/27/nsa-data-mining-authorised-obama |accessdate=August 1, 2013 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=June 27, 2013 |author=[[Glenn Greenwald]] and [[Spencer Ackerman]]}}</ref> which was later terminated due to operational and resource constraints. It was subsequently replaced by newer surveillance programs such as ShellTrumpet, which "''processed its one trillionth metadata record''" by the end of December 2012.<ref name="GuardianShell20130627">{{cite news |title=How the NSA is still harvesting your online data |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/27/nsa-online-metadata-collection |accessdate=August 1, 2013 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=June 27, 2013 |author=[[Glenn Greenwald]] and [[Spencer Ackerman]]}}</ref>
The NSA follows specific procedures to target non-U.S. persons<ref>{{cite news |title=Procedures Used by NSA to Target Non-US Persons: Exhibit A – Full Document – Top-Secret Documents Show Fisa Judges Have Signed Off on Broad Orders Allowing the NSA to Make Use of Information 'Inadvertently' Collected from Domestic US Communications Without a Warrant – Revealed: The Secret Rules That Allow NSA to Use US Data Without a Warrant |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/interactive/2013/jun/20/exhibit-a-procedures-nsa-document |accessdate=July 13, 2013 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=June 20, 2013 |location=London}}</ref> and to minimize data collection from U.S. persons.<ref>{{cite news |title=Procedures Used by NSA to Minimize Data Collection from US Persons: Exhibit B – Full Document – The Documents Detail the Procedures the NSA Is Required to Follow to Target 'Non-US Persons' under Its Foreign Intelligence Powers – And What the Agency Does to Minimize Data Collected on US Citizens and Residents – Revealed: The Secret Rules That Allow NSA to Use US Data Without a Warrant |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/interactive/2013/jun/20/exhibit-b-nsa-procedures-document |accessdate=July 13, 2013 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=June 20, 2013 |location=London}}</ref> These court-approved policies allow the NSA to:<ref name="Guardian20130720">{{cite news |title=The Top Secret Rules That Allow NSA to Use US Data Without a Warrant – Fisa Court Submissions Show Broad Scope of Procedures Governing NSA's Surveillance of Americans' Communication – Document One: Procedures Used by NSA to Target Non-US Persons – Document Two: Procedures Used by NSA to Minimise Data Collected from US Persons |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/20/fisa-court-nsa-without-warrant |accessdate=July 13, 2013 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=June 20, 2013 |author=[[Glenn Greenwald|Greenwald, Glenn]]; Ball, James |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=New documents reveal parameters of NSA's secret surveillance programs |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/new-documents-reveal-parameters-of-nsas-secret-surveillance-programs/2013/06/20/54248600-d9f7-11e2-a9f2-42ee3912ae0e_story.html |accessdate=February 13, 2014 |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=June 21, 2013 |author1=Ellen Nakashima |author2=Barton Gellman |author3=Greg Miller}}</ref> * keep data that could potentially contain details of U.S. persons for up to five years; * retain and make use of "inadvertently acquired" domestic communications if they contain usable intelligence, information on criminal activity, threat of harm to people or property, are encrypted, or are believed to contain any information relevant to cybersecurity; * preserve "foreign intelligence information" contained within [[Attorney–client privilege|attorney–client communications]]; and * access the content of communications gathered from "U.S. based machine[s]" or phone numbers in order to establish if targets are located in the U.S., for the purposes of ceasing further surveillance.
According to [[Boundless Informant]], over 97 billion pieces of intelligence were collected over a 30-day period ending in March 2013. Out of all 97 billion sets of information, about 3 billion [[data set]]s originated from U.S. computer networks<ref>{{cite web |last=[[Glenn Greenwald]] and Ewen MacAskill |title=Boundless Informant: the NSA's secret tool to track global surveillance data |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/08/nsa-boundless-informant-global-datamining |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=January 1, 2014 |date=June 11, 2013}}</ref> and around 500 million metadata records were collected from German networks.<ref>{{cite web |last=[[Laura Poitras]], Marcel Rosenbach and Holger Stark |title=Partner and Target: NSA Snoops on 500 Million German Data Connections |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/nsa-spies-on-500-million-german-data-connections-a-908648.html |work=[[Der Spiegel]] |accessdate=January 1, 2014}}</ref>
In August 2013, it was revealed that the [[Bundesnachrichtendienst]] (BND) of Germany transfers massive amounts of metadata records to the NSA.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Hubert Gude |author2=Laura Poitras |author3=Marcel Rosenbach |title=German Intelligence Sends Massive Amounts of Data to the NSA |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/german-intelligence-sends-massive-amounts-of-data-to-the-nsa-a-914821.html |work=[[Der Spiegel]] |accessdate=January 1, 2014}}</ref>
''Der Spiegel'' disclosed that Germany is the most targeted country of the 27 members of the European Union due to the NSA systematic monitoring and storage of Germany's telephone and Internet connection data. According to the magazine the NSA stores data from around half a billion communications connections in Germany each month. This data includes telephone calls, emails, mobile-phone text messages and chat transcripts.<ref>{{cite news |title=Partner and Target: NSA Snoops on 500 Million German Data Connections |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/nsa-spies-on-500-million-german-data-connections-a-908648.html |accessdate=March 30, 2014 |newspaper=Der Spiegel |date=June 30, 2013 |author1=Laura Poitras |author2=Marcel Rosenbach |author3=Holger Stark}}</ref>
[[File:Boundless-heatmap-large-001.jpg|thumb|center|720px|On June 11, 2013, ''[[The Guardian]]'' published a snapshot of the NSA's global map of electronic data collection for the month of March 2013. Known as the [[Boundless Informant]], the program is used by the NSA to track the amount of data being analyzed over a specific period of time. The color scheme ranges from green (least subjected to surveillance) through yellow and orange to red (most surveillance). Outside the Middle East, only China, Germany, India, [[Kenya]], Colombia, the United Kingdom, and the United States are colored orange or yellow]]
==== July ==== The NSA gained massive amounts of information captured from the monitored data traffic in Europe. For example, in December 2013, the NSA gathered on an average day metadata from some 15 million telephone connections and 10 million Internet datasets. The NSA also monitored the European Commission in Brussels and monitored EU diplomatic Facilities in Washington and at the United Nations by placing bugs in offices as well as infiltrating computer networks.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cover Story: How the NSA Targets Germany and Europe |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/secret-documents-nsa-targeted-germany-and-eu-buildings-a-908609.html |accessdate=March 30, 2014 |newspaper=Der Spiegel |date=July 1, 2013 |author1=Laura Poitras |author2=Marcel Rosenbach |author3=Fidelius Schmid |author4=Holger Stark |author5=Jonathan Stock}}</ref>
The U.S. government made as part of its [[PRISM (surveillance program)#Related U.S. government surveillance programs|UPSTREAM data collection program]] deals with companies to ensure that it had access to and hence the capability to surveil undersea fiber-optic cables which deliver e-mails, Web pages, other electronic communications and phone calls from one continent to another at the speed of light.<ref>{{cite news |title=Agreements with private companies protect U.S. access to cables' data for surveillance |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/technology/agreements-with-private-companies-protect-us-access-to-cables-data-for-surveillance/2013/07/06/aa5d017a-df77-11e2-b2d4-ea6d8f477a01_story.html |accessdate=February 12, 2014 |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=July 7, 2013 |author1=Craig Timberg |author2=Ellen Nakashima}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Lindemann |first=Todd |title=A connected world |url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/business/a-connected-world/305/ |accessdate=February 12, 2014 |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=July 6, 2013}}</ref>
According to the Brazilian newspaper ''[[O Globo]]'', the NSA spied on millions of emails and calls of Brazilian citizens,<ref>[http://oglobo.globo.com/mundo/eua-espionaram-milhoes-de-mails-ligacoes-de-brasileiros-8940934 EUA espionaram milhões de e-mails e ligações de brasileiros], ''[[O Globo]]'', July 6, 2013. ==== August ==== Documents leaked by Edward Snowden that were seen by ''[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]]'' (SZ) and ''[[Norddeutscher Rundfunk]]'' revealed that several [[Telecommunication|telecom]] operators have played a key role in helping the British intelligence agency [[Government Communications Headquarters]] (GCHQ) tap into worldwide [[fiber-optic communication]]s. The telecom operators are: * [[Verizon Business]] (codenamed "Dacron")<ref name=gtbp /><ref name="Süddeutsche">{{cite web |author1=John Goetz |author2=Frederik Obermaier |title=Snowden enthüllt Namen der spähenden Telekomfirmen |url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/digital/internet-ueberwachung-snowden-enthuellt-namen-der-spaehenden-telekomfirmen-1.1736791 |work=[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]] |accessdate=August 2, 2013 |language=German |quote=In den internen Papieren des GCHQ aus dem Jahr 2009 stehen sie nun aufgelistet: Verizon Business, Codename: Dacron, British Telecommunications (codenamed "Remedy"), Vodafone Cable ("Gerontic"), Global Crossing ("Pinnage"), Level 3 (codenamed "Little"), Viatel ("Vitreous") und Interoute ("Streetcar").}}</ref> * [[British Telecommunications]] (codenamed "Remedy")<ref name=gtbp /><ref name="Süddeutsche" /> * [[Vodafone|Vodafone Cable]] (codenamed "Gerontic")<ref name=gtbp /><ref name="Süddeutsche" /> * [[Global Crossing]] (codenamed "Pinnage")<ref name=gtbp /><ref name="Süddeutsche" /> * [[Level 3 Communications|Level 3]] (codenamed "Little")<ref name=gtbp /><ref name="Süddeutsche" /> * [[Viatel]] (codenamed "Vitreous")<ref name=gtbp /><ref name="Süddeutsche" /> * [[Interoute]] (codenamed "Streetcar")<ref name=gtbp /><ref name="Süddeutsche" />

It can also retain and analyse nearly the entire European internet traffic.<ref name="SZAug28" />
GCHQ is collecting all data transmitted to and from the United Kingdom and Northern Europe via the undersea fibre optic telecommunications cable [[SEA-ME-WE 3]]. GCHQ is also developing the technology to "exploit any mobile phone at any time."<ref name="GCHQpay">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/aug/01/nsa-paid-gchq-spying-edward-snowden |title=Exclusive: NSA pays £100m in secret funding for GCHQ |author1=James Ball |author2=Luke Harding |author3=Juliette Garside |date=August 1, 2013 |accessdate=August 2, 2013}}</ref> The NSA has under a legal authority a secret backdoor into its databases gathered from large Internet companies enabling it to search for U.S. citizens' email and phone calls without a warrant.<ref>{{cite news |title=NSA loophole allows warrantless search for US citizens' emails and phone calls – Exclusive: Spy agency has secret backdoor permission to search databases for individual Americans' communications |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/09/nsa-loophole-warrantless-searches-email-calls |accessdate=August 12, 2013 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=August 9, 2013 |author=James Ball and [[Spencer Ackerman]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Farivar |first=Cyrus |title=New leak: NSA can search US e-mail data but theoretically won't |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/08/new-leak-nsa-can-search-us-e-mail-data-but-theoretically-isnt-allowed-to/ |publisher=Ars Technica |accessdate=August 13, 2013 |date=August 10, 2013}}</ref>
The [[Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board]] urged the U.S. intelligence chiefs to draft stronger US surveillance guidelines on domestic spying after finding that several of those guidelines "[[Mastering the Internet]]" (MTI) is part of the [[Interception Modernisation Programme]] (IMP) of the British government that involves the insertion of thousands of DPI ([[deep packet inspection]]) "black boxes" at various [[internet service provider]]s, as revealed by the British media in 2009.<ref name="times1a">{{cite news |title=Jacqui Smith's secret plan to carry on snooping |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article6211101.ece |author1=David Leppard |author2=Chris Williams |work=The Sunday Times |date=May 3, 2009 |accessdate=May 3, 2009 |location=London}}</ref>

==== September ==== The ''Guardian'' and ''The New York Times'' reported on secret documents leaked by Snowden showing that the NSA has been in "collaboration with technology companies" as part of "an aggressive, multipronged effort" to weaken the [[encryption]] used in commercial software, and GCHQ has a team dedicated to cracking "Hotmail, Google, Yahoo and Facebook" traffic.<ref name="guardian-bullrun">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/sep/05/nsa-gchq-encryption-codes-security |title=US and UK spy agencies defeat privacy and security on the internet |work=The Guardian |date=September 5, 2013 |accessdate=September 5, 2013 |author1=James Ball |author2=Julian Borger |author3=Glenn Greenwald}}</ref><ref name="nyt-bullrun">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/06/us/nsa-foils-much-internet-encryption.html |title=N.S.A.
